questions.text: A 68-year-old male is undergoing a hernia operation. On the table, the surgeon asked the nurse to hand over the diathermy for the procedure. The machine attached to the diathermy shows the waveform given in the picture below. Which of the following option best correlates with this waveform?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Cutting:

  • Diathermy uses a high-frequency alternating polarity radio-wave electrical current during surgery to cut or coagulate tissue.
  • It enables accurate incisions with minimal blood loss and is utilized in practically all surgical fields.
  • The radio-frequencies created by diathermy heat the tissue by causing internal oscillation of molecules within the cells, allowing for cutting and coagulation.
  • Depending on the temperature, several outcomes occur: at 60º C, cell death (fulguration) happens; between 60-99º C, dehydration occurs, and tissues coagulate; and at 100º C, tissues vaporize (cutting).
  • Diathermy has two primary settings: cutting and coagulation.
  • Cutting uses a low-voltage continuous waveform. In cutting mode, the electrode achieves a high enough power level to vaporize the water content. As a result, it can make a clean cut but is less effective in coagulating.
  • The cutting mode focuses heat at the surgical site, with sparks being the more focused means to disperse heat; consequently, the cutting mode should be utilized with the tip away from the tissue.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Fulguration:

  • Fulguration is an electrosurgical procedure. Healthcare personnel employ electrosurgery equipment to guide high-frequency electrical currents from an electrosurgical generator to electrodes on the skin.
  • In fulguration, healthcare personnel ignites the instrument and the electrodes on the skin.
  • Fistulas and persistent cysts can be cauterized, and small hemorrhages can be halted using fulguration.

Option C - Coagulation:

  • Coagulation can also be accomplished using a pulsed waveform with a high voltage. The waveform has a lower average power in coagulation, creating enough heat for thermal coagulation but not enough for explosive vaporization.
  • Although the tip should be held somewhat away from the tissue, the sparks are dispersed over a larger region, producing charring rather than cutting.

Option D - Blended waveform:

  • The 'Blend' approach combines short-wave diathermy and galvanic current into a single therapy.
  • This short wave diathermy generates heat, while the galvanic generates a chemical reaction at the hair's root due to water, salts, and a low current mixing.
  • It has both cutting and coagulation advantages.

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman presents to the community health center for a routine check-up. She complains of occasional fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion. Her blood pressure is 147/82 mmHg. On examination, her weight is 80 kg and her height is 160 cm. The physician orders a few blood tests and educates the patient about obesity. Which of the following is a height-independent indicator of obesity?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Corpulence index:

  • The corpulence index is one of the formulae used to calculate the body weight.
  • It is a height-independent indicator of obesity.
  • It is calculated using the following formula:
  • Actual weight / desirable weight
  • The corpulence index should not exceed 1.2.
  • This is a height-independent indicator of Obesity

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Ponderal index:

  • Like BMI, the ponderal index is a height-dependent measure of obesity.

Option C - Brocca index:

  • Brocca index is a height-dependent formula used to estimate a person's ideal weight.
  • It is calculated as follows: Ideal Body Weight (kg) = Height (cm) - 100.
  • It is not an indicator of obesity but rather a reference for determining appropriate body weight ranges.

Option D - Lorentz formula:

  • The Lorentz formula is another height-dependent method used to estimate ideal body weight.
  • It is calculated as follows: Ideal Body Weight (kg) = Height (cm) - 100 -  for men, and Ideal Body Weight (kg) = Height (cm) - 100 - for women.
  • Similar to the Broca index, it is not a measure of obesity but rather a reference for ideal weight estimation.

questions.text: A viva examination was conducted in the Community medicine department. During the exam, a professor asked the student about the Conjugate vaccine. Which among the following is an example of Conjugate vaccines?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pneumococcal vaccine:

  • This is an example of the conjugate vaccine.
  • Conjugate vaccine: Polysaccharide antigen is chemically linked to a protein T cells recognize.
    • Advantage: More effective in children < 2 years
    • Disadvantage: Serotype-specific

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, D - 

  • These are all examples of recombinant vaccines.
  • Recombinant vaccines rely on the capacity of one or more defined antigens to induce immunity against the pathogen, when administered with adjuvants or when expressed by plasmids or harmless bacterial/viral vectors.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents to the fertility clinic for evaluation of infertility. He and his wife have been trying to have children for two years. His wife was recently evaluated and found to be normal and healthy. The patient denies any pain in his testicular region. However, he reports occasional feelings of heaviness in his scrotum. On physical exam, his scrotum looks distended. At rest, a "bag of worm"-like finding is visible and palpable in the testicle. What is the grade of the given condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Grade III:

  • In the above case, the heaviness and distension of the scrotum, with a "bag of worm" finding on palpation, suggestive of a varicocele. As it is visible and palpable at rest, it is grade III.
  • Varicocele is an abnormal dilatation of the pampiniform plexus of the internal spermatic venous system.
  • They are unusual in boys and typically develop during late childhood and adolescence
  • Sometimes, the dilated vessels are cremasteric veins and not part of the pampiniform plexus. The usual cause is the absence or incompetence of valves in the proximal testicular vein.
  • Etiology:
  • While most varicoceles are idiopathic, obstruction of the left testicular vein by a renal tumor or nephrectomy is a cause of varicocele in later life; characteristically, in such cases, the varicocele does not decompress in the supine position.
  • Signs and symptoms:
  • Varicoceles may be asymptomatic, or patients may experience an annoying dragging discomfort that is worse on standing at the end of the day. This presumably reflects distension of the testicular veins.
  • When examined in the erect position, the scrotum on the affected side hangs lower than normal; on standing, the varicose plexus feels like a bag of worms. There may be a cough impulse.
  • Diagnosis
  • ultrasonography and color Doppler.              
  • Treatment:
  • percutaneous embolization of the gonadal veins is the usual first-line intervention.
  • If this is impossible or if the varicocele recurs, then surgical ligation of the testicular veins is the appropriate treatment, although recurrence can occur even after surgery.

Varicocele Grading

  

Grade 1

Palpable during Valsalva maneuver, but not otherwise

Grade 2

Palpable at rest but not visible

Grade 3

Visible and palpable at rest

​​​​​​Incorrect Options:

Option A - Grade I:

  • If a varicocele is palpable during the Valsalva manoeuvre but not otherwise, it will be grade 1.
  • If it is visible and palpable at rest, it is under grade 3.

Option B - Grade II:

  • If the varicocele is palpable at rest but not visible, it will fall in grade 2.
  • If it is visible at rest and also palpable, then it will be grade 3.

Option D - Grade IV:

  • There are usually three grades of varicocele.
  • According to Sarteschi's classification of varicocele, grade 4 vessels appear to enlarge in the supine position.
  • Testicular hypotrophy is very common in this stage.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct about the enzyme cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2)?

choices.text: It is not inhibited by indomethacin
It generates cytoprotective prostaglandins in gastric mucosa
It is found only in fetal tissues

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - It is inducible:

  • Cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2) enzyme is an inducible enzyme
  • COX-1 is a housekeeping enzyme responsible for the generation of gastroprotective prostaglandins.
  • COX-2 is normally present in insignificant amounts in tissues and is an inducible enzyme.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - It is not inhibited by indomethacin:

  • Indomethacin inhibits both COX-1 and COX-2 effectively.

Option C - It generates cytoprotective prostaglandins in gastric mucosa:

  • COX-1 induces synthesis of PGE2 and PGI2, promoting gastric mucosal protection.
  • COX-2 inhibitors lack the side effect of gastritis because they don't affect these protective prostaglandins.

Option D - It is found only in fetal tissues:

  • COX-2 is present in various adult tissues, including the kidney, brain, and fetal tissues.
  • While more prominent during fetal development, COX-2 is expressed in adults, particularly in response to inflammation.

questions.text: What's the likely cause of a thick whitish vaginal discharge and significant vaginal itching in a 56-year-old diabetic woman recently treated with a 2-week course of antibiotics for a skin infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - C. albicans:

  • C. albicans is a major cause of vulvovaginitis. The opportunistic pathogenic yeast Candida albicans is a common component of the human gut flora. It is detected in the oral cavity and gastrointestinal tract of approximately 40% to 60% of individuals in a state of good health.
  • The patient presents with thick white vaginal discharge.
  • The majority of vaginal yeast infections are caused by Candida albicans.
  • A healthy balance of yeast, including candida, and bacteria naturally exists in the vagina.
  • Several bacteria, including Lactobacillus, inhibit the overgrowth of yeast. Nevertheless, this delicate equilibrium may be disrupted.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - C. granulomatis:

  • C. granulomatis causes granuloma inguinale. Chancroid results in painful genital ulcers caused by the organism H. ducreyi.
  • The genital ulcerative disease granuloma inguinale (donovanosis) is brought on by the intracellular gram-negative bacterium Klebsiella granulomatous (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).
  • One or more painless lumps, commonly located in the genitalia, anal region, or groin, are among the signs and symptoms of donovanosis. The lump or lumps gradually enlarge and eventually ulcerate.
  • These sores are often beefy-red in color, quickly bleed, and have a rolled edge. The sore may occasionally smell unpleasant.

Option C - Chancroid:

  • Chancroid gives rise to lesions on the genitalia, presenting as a soft chancre or an ulcer characterized by irregular edges. These sores may induce discomfort and exhibit purulent discharge.
  • Chancroid is caused by the Haemophilus ducreyi, resulting in painful, superficial ulcers, often with regional lymphadenopathy.
  • It is characterized by painful necrotizing genital ulcers that may accompany inguinal lymphadenopathy. It is a highly contagious but curable disease.
  • No laboratory testing can immediately confirm the diagnosis of chancroid. Chancroid can only be diagnosed with certainty by isolating H ducreyi on a specialized medium. However, these assays are only commonly available in some centres.

Option D - Neisseria meningitidis:

  • N. meningitidis can cause meningitis.
  • Neisseria meningitidis bacteria are the causative agents of meningococcal disease. Approximately one in ten individuals harbor these microorganisms in the posterior nasopharynx without exhibiting any signs of illness.
  • Neisseria meningitidis septicemia triggers disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), causing compromised blood vessel integrity and subsequent hemorrhage in dermal and visceral tissues. Clinical symptoms may include chills and fever.

questions.text: Which quantification method is used for the diagnosis of hirsutism in women?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option C: Ferriman-Gallwey score

  • The Ferriman-Gallwey score is a standardized method for quantifying hirsutism. 
  • Within this system, abnormal hair distribution is assessed in 9 body areas and scored from 0-4. Increasing numeric scores correspond to greater hair density within a given area.
  • A score ≥ 8 is suggestive of mild hirsutism and the score of ≥15 is suggestive of moderate to severe hirsutism.

Ferriman-Gallwey scoring:

  • Upper lip: Score 0 (no terminal hairs) to 4 (extensive terminal hairs).
  • Chin: Score 0 (no terminal hairs) to 4 (extensive terminal hairs).
  • Chest: Score 0 (no terminal hairs) to 4 (extensive terminal hairs).
  • Upper back: Score 0 (no terminal hairs) to 4 (extensive terminal hairs).
  • Lower back: Score 0 (no terminal hairs) to 4 (extensive terminal hairs).
  • Upper abdomen: Score 0 (no terminal hairs) to 4 (extensive terminal hairs).
  • Lower abdomen: Score 0 (no terminal hairs) to 4 (extensive terminal hairs).
  • Thighs: Score 0 (no terminal hairs) to 4 (extensive terminal hairs).
  • Upper arms: Score 0 (no terminal hairs) to 4 (extensive terminal hairs).

Incorrect options:

Option A: Bishop score

  • The Bishop score is used in obstetrics to assess the cervix’s readiness for labor induction. It evaluates cervical dilation, effacement, station, consistency, and position. It is not relevant to the assessment of hirsutism.

Option B: Rotterdam Criteria

  • The Rotterdam Criteria are not a quantification method for hirsutism. Instead, they are criteria used in the diagnosis of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). These criteria include the presence of irregular menstrual cycles, clinical or biochemical signs of hyperandrogenism, and ultrasound findings of polycystic ovaries.

Option D: None of the above

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D- Eczema:

  • Eczema is one of the characteristic features of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS).
  • WAS is an X-linked recessive disorder characterized by the classic triad of eczema, thrombocytopenia (low platelet count), and immunodeficiency.
  • It occurs due to a mutation in the gene encoding the Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASP), located at Xp11.23 (causes impaired cytoskeleton remodeling - impaired cell migration).
  • In this disease, IgM levels in the serum are low, while levels of IgA and IgE are paradoxically elevated.
  • The only treatment is HSC transplantation.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A- Autosomal recessive disorder:

  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is an X-linked recessive disease.

Option B - High serum IgM level:

  • Patients with Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome typically have low levels of IgM, not high. They often have elevated IgA and IgE levels instead.

Option C- Thrombocytosis:

  • Thrombocytosis refers to an increased platelet count. Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is characterized by thrombocytopenia, which is a decreased platelet count.

questions.text: What is associated with the condition of a 28-year-old pregnant female with fever, swollen lymph nodes, and Giemsa-stained sickle-shaped tachyzoites on blood smear, who recently traveled to Indonesia during her 3rd trimester?

choices.text: Subclinical in the least cases among adults
IgM Ab in newborns suggests congenital infection
More severe in 3rd trimester of pregnancy

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - IgM Ab in newborns suggests congenital infection:

  • Clinical conditions and sickle-shaped tachyzoites point towards Toxoplasmosis.
  • The presence of IgM antibodies suggests recent infection.
  • IgM antibodies are specific markers of acute or recent toxoplasmosis.
  • The detection of IgM antibodies in a newborn's blood indicates exposure to Toxoplasma gondii during pregnancy, either through a primary maternal infection or reactivation of a latent infection.
  • This finding is a concerning sign, as it suggests that the newborn may be at risk of developing symptomatic toxoplasmosis and related complications, such as neurological and ocular issues.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Subclinical in the least cases among adults:

  • Toxoplasmosis is mostly asymptomatic in adults.
  • It can cause seizures and encephalitis in immunocompromised patients.
  • Untreated Toxoplasmosis can cause blindness.

Option B - Extratracerebral calcification in children:

  • This statement is not accurate for toxoplasmosis. In congenital toxoplasmosis, calcifications are more likely to occur in the brain (intracerebral calcifications) rather than extracerebral areas.
  • These calcifications can lead to neurological and developmental problems in affected infants.

Option D - More severe in 3rd trimester of pregnancy:

  • Congenital infection occurring in 1st trimester of pregnancy, may cause abortion and stillbirth.
  • When acquired late in pregnancy, it may produce retinitis and mental defects. (less severe)

questions.text: Mark the correct statement regarding Ovarian cancer among given options

choices.text: Separate FIGO staging systems exist for epithelial and sex-cord/stromal ovarian tumors
Granulosa cell tumor has an excellent prognosis because most patients present with early-stage disease
Meigs' syndrome consists of ascites, hydrothorax, and a malignant epithelial ovarian tumor
Krukenberg tumors are metastatic ovarian neoplasms originating exclusively in the stomach

questions.solution:
Option B: As granulosa cell tumor is slowly growing, thus considered to be a low-grade malignancy. Has an excellent prognosis because most patients present with early-stage disease.

Granulosa cell tumors

  • Are associated with ↑ Estrogens
  • Present therefore with
    • Precocious puberty
    • Menorrhagia
    • Endometrial hyperplasia and cancer
  • CARL EXNER BODIES ·
  • Tumor Marker → Inhibin
  • Give contralateral ovarian secondaries prior to systemic secondaries

Option A:

  • The same FIGO staging system is used for both epithelial and non-epithelial ovarian tumors.

Option C:

  • Meigs’ syndrome consists of ascites; hydrothorax and ovarian fibroma

Option D:

  • Krukenberg tumor is secondaries to the ovary, it is most commonly from the CA Stomach although not exclusively, as secondaries may be from other GI tumors as well.
  • The features are
    • signet ring cells are pathognomonic for adenocarcinoma of the stomach
    • Bilateral ovarian tumor in 90% of cases
    • A solid-to-firm tumor
    • the ovary although may be enlarged more than 10 fold still maintains its shape.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with type 2 diabetes presents to the emergency department with altered mental status. His blood glucose level is measured at 48 mg/dL. On examination, he appears lethargic and confused. He is unable to answer questions appropriately and has difficulty following commands. Which level of hypoglycemia does this presentation correspond to?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Level 2:

  • The patient's presentation aligns with Level 2 hypoglycemia, which involves blood glucose levels below 54 mg/dL.
  • At this stage, individuals may exhibit lethargy, sleepiness, and significant impairment in their ability to perform tasks.
  • Neuroglycopenia, or brain glucose deprivation, begins to manifest.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Level 1: This level of hypoglycemia is characterized by blood glucose levels between 55-70 mg/dL. Patients may experience symptoms such as sweating, tremor, and palpitations, but they can usually perform tasks without significant impairment.

Option C - Level 3: Level 3 hypoglycemia involves severe symptoms requiring assistance, such as hypoglycemic seizures and coma.

Option D - Level 4: There is no Level 4 hypoglycemia.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female presents with recurrent headaches and lower extremity claudication. Physical examination reveals diminished femoral pulses, and blood pressure measurement shows a significantly higher pressure in the upper extremities compared to the lower extremities. A barium swallow is performed to evaluate for associated anomalies. Which of the following findings is most likely to be seen on the barium swallow?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Reverse 3 sign

  • In coarctation of the aorta, the most likely finding on a barium swallow is the "Reverse '3' sign," outlining the constricted or narrowed segment of the aorta, creating a shape reminiscent of the number 3, with the constriction representing the curved part of the 3.
  • Coarctation of the aorta is a congenital heart defect characterized by narrowing of the aortic lumen, typically occurring just distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery. This narrowing results in increased resistance to blood flow and decreased blood supply to the lower extremities. Clinical manifestations include hypertension in the upper extremities and weak or absent femoral pulses.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - String sign: It refers to the appearance of a thin, elongated narrowing in the barium column, typically seen in cases of diffuse esophageal spasm.

Option C - Corkscrew appearance: It is observed in conditions such as esophageal motility disorders, where the esophagus demonstrates abnormal peristalsis, resulting in a twisting or coiled appearance. 

Option D - Bird's beak sign: It is seen in the barium swallow of patients with achalasia, a condition characterized by impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter. It refers to the tapered narrowing of the distal esophagus, resembling a bird's beak.

questions.text: Which of the following is the leading cause of child mortality in developing countries?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pneumonia:

  • Pneumonia is the leading cause of death among children under five years of age in developing countries.
  • It is a significant public health concern due to factors such as limited access to healthcare, inadequate immunization coverage, malnutrition, and poor living conditions, which all contribute to higher rates of severe respiratory infections in children.

Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following states is characterized by the presence of Delta waves?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Deep sleep:

  • Delta waves are characteristic of deep sleep, also known as slow-wave sleep.
  • They are measured on an electroencephalogram (EEG) at frequencies of 0.5 to 4 Hz.
  • Deep sleep occurs predominantly in Stage III of non-rapid eye movement (NREM) sleep.
  • During deep sleep, individuals are less responsive to external stimuli and show slow, synchronized brain activity.
  • Delta waves are associated with restorative processes, memory consolidation, and overall physical and mental recovery during sleep.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - REM sleep:

  • REM sleep comprises beta waves.
  • It's the last stage of the sleep cycle.

Option C - Awake state:

  • The awake state comprises beta waves.
  • Beta waves are high-frequency waves.

Option D - Stage II NREM sleep:

  • This stage of sleep has theta waves, sleep spindles, and k-complexes.

questions.text: Which of the following layers form the buccopharyngeal membrane?
questions.solution:
Option B: Ectoderm + Endoderm

  • The buccopharyngeal membrane derived from ectoderm + endoderm represents the future opening of the oral cavity.
  • Cells from epiblast invaginate to form primitive streaks, giving rise to ectoderm and endoderm.
  • The primitive streak has 3 parts
    • Primitive groove
    • Primitive Knot
    • Primitive Pit
  • As epiblast cells proliferate to form primitive streaks, some epiblast cells jump into the primitive pit and go ventrally to replace hypoblast cells with endoderm.
  • Ectoderm and endoderm fuse at some level towards the cephalic end, forming the buccopharyngeal membrane and the caudal end, forming the cloacal membrane

Options A , C, D

  • Ectoderm and endoderm fuse towards the cephalic end, forming the buccopharyngeal membrane, and the caudal end, forming the cloacal membrane.
  • Both membranes do not have mesoderm because of the fusion of the dorsal ectoderm with the ventral endoderm.

questions.text: All the following are true about the functional divisions of the liver, except?

choices.text: Based upon portal vein and hepatic vein
Three major and three minor fissures

questions.solution:
Option C: Three major and three minor fissures

  • Only three major fissures are present in the liver's functional division.

Couinaud's division:

  • The functional anatomy of the liver is based on Couinaud's division of the liver into eight functional segments based on the distribution of portal venous branches in the parenchyma.
  • The liver is divided into four portal sectors by the four main branches of the portal vein. These are right lateral, right medial, left medial and left lateral.
  • The three main hepatic veins lie between these sectors as intersectoral veins. These intersectoral planes are also called portal fissures, namely: Main left and right portal fissures.
  • Each functional segment receives its primary branch of the hepatic artery and portal vein and is drained by the bile duct.

Option A: Based upon portal vein and hepatic vein

  • The functional anatomy of the liver is based on Couinaud's division of the liver into eight functional segments based on portal vein and hepatic vein

Option B: Divided into 8 segments

  • The functional anatomy of the liver is based on Couinaud's division of the liver into eight functional segments based on the distribution of portal venous branches in the parenchyma.

Option D: Four portal sectors

  • The liver is divided into four portal sectors by the four main branches of the portal vein. These are right lateral, right medial, left medial and left lateral.

questions.text: Which of the following events occurs immediately following the completion of meiosis II?

choices.text: Sperm penetration of the corona radiata

questions.solution:
Option C: Formation of a female pronucleus

  • The secondary oocytes stop in the metaphase of meiosis II and remain in this meiotic stage until fertilization.
  • After fertilization, the secondary egg cell completes meiosis II and forms a mature ovum and a polar body.
  • The nucleus of the mature egg cell is called the female pronucleus, which fuses with the male pronucleus to form a zygote.

Incorrect otpions

Option A: Degeneration of the zona pellucida

  • Oocytes are protected by granulosa cells, and those not protected undergo atresia.
  • Degeneration of the zona pellucida happens on day 5 after fertilization

Option B: Sperm penetration of the corona radiata

  • After ejaculation, Sperms reach the posterior fornix of the vagina, and it takes 2 minutes to reach the ampulla of the fallopian tube.
  • Acrosome breaks down and releases acrosin to fertilize oocyte (to disperse the corona radiata of zona pellucida of oocyte).
  • Acrosin (Hyaluronidase) will soften the zona pellucida (Acrosome reaction).
  • Sperm penetration of the corona radiata is a process leading to fertilization

Option D: Appearance of the blastocyst

  • Advanced morula enters the uterine cavity on Day 4 and changes to "Blastocyst."

  • It contains Blast cells & cyst-like cavities. Contains: Outer cell mass-Trophoblast [helps in placental formation] and inner cell mass – Embryoblast

  • The appearance of the blastocyst occurs on day 4 after fertilization

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to the outpatient department with abdominal pain for the past 2 hours. Examination reveals right upper quadrant tenderness. Abdominal ultrasound shows highly reflective echo from the gall bladder and stones. An elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy is planned under general anaesthesia. Central venous cannulation is planned under ultrasound guidance. The most preferred site for central venous cannulation to prevent catheter-related infections in this patient is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Subclavian vein:

  • The patient with right upper quadrant pain after heavy meals and ultrasound findings of gallstones has gallstone ileus.
  • Gall stones are common in females, and there are certain risk factors for the development of gall stones:
    • Female gender
    • Obesity
    • Age 40 or older
    • Sedentary lifestyle
    • High-fat diet
    • Pregnancy
  • Due to obesity, when it is difficult to secure peripheral venous cannulation, a central venous cannula is used.
  • The most preferred site for central venous cannulation is the subclavian vein.
  • It is the site with the least infection and better patient tolerance.
  • However, the demerit is a torturous course and high risk for pneumothorax and neurovascular injuries

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Femoral vein:

  • Femoral vein is the least desirable site because of the following:
    • Increased risk of thromboembolic complications
    • Infection
    • Vascular injury.

Option C - Right Internal jugular vein:

  • Right internal jugular vein is the most preferred for:
    • Transvenous pacemaker wires
    • Hemodialysis catheters
    • Pulmonary artery catheters

Option D - Left internal jugular vein:

  • Left internal jugular vein has a greater risk of pleural effusion and chylothorax. Hence, it is not preferred.

questions.text: A 29-year-old patient presented in a surgical emergency with an acute abdomen and was posted for emergency surgery.An anaesthetist decided to give him general anaesthesia. Which among these Mapleson circuits cannot be used in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Mapleson F

  • Type F is the modification of Type E.
  • There is no Adjustable pressure limiting valve.
  • It is also known as the Jackson Rees circuit.
  • It is the circuit of choice in pediatric patients.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Mapleson A

  • Mapleson A is also called the Magill circuit, the circuit of choice in adults for spontaneous ventilation.

Option B: Mapleson D

  • Mapleson D (Bains circuit) is a circuit of choice for adults on controlled ventilation.

Option D: Mapleson C

  • This circuit is also known as Water's circuit.
  • It is similar in construction to Mapleson B, but the main tube is shorter. An FGF equal to twice the minute ventilation is required to prevent rebreathing.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct about the lumbar hernia given in the picture below?

choices.text: Hernia through Grynfeltt triangle is less common
Petit’s triangle is bounded by the iliac crest, latissimus dorsi, and external oblique muscle
Grynfeltt triangle is bounded by the 11th rib, paraspinal, and external oblique muscle

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Petit’s triangle is bounded by the iliac crest, latissimus dorsi, and external oblique muscle:

  • Boundaries of the Inferior triangle of Petit
    • Posteriorly: Latissmus dorsi
    • Anteriorly: External oblique muscle
    • Inferiorly: Iliac crest

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Is always congenital:

  • Lumbar hernia can be acquired as well as congenital.

Option B - Hernia through superior Grynfeltt triangle is less common:

  • Most lumbar hernias occur through the superior triangle of Grynfeltt.

Option D - Grynfeltt triangle is bounded by the 11th rib, paraspinal, and external oblique muscle:

  • Boundaries of the Superior triangle of Grynfeltt are as mentioned in Option C.

questions.text: A college-going student comes to the OPD with severe pain in the right knee. He describes pain that is more intense at night and is relieved by pain medications. He had a history of TB in the past and has completed the treatment as prescribed by his primary care provider. A knee X-ray shows a nidus in the diaphysis of the upper end of the tibia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Osteoid osteoma:

  • The image shows nidus in the diaphysis of the upper end of tibia.
  • Patients often present with night cries and localized pain that are relieved by pain medications.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Skeletal TB:

  • This patient's past medical history includes TB infection completely treated by appropriate therapy. He is also not experiencing any symptoms of active TB infection such as fever, chills, night sweats, and weight loss. Therefore, the nidus seen in the X-ray is unlikely to be due to skeletal TB.

Option B - Chronic periostitis:

  • It is an inflammatory condition frequently occurring in athletes.
  • Pain is present throughout the day and can cause stress fractures.

Option D - Brodie's abscess:

  • It is a form of subacute osteomyelitis.
  • A well-defined cavity is seen in the cancellous bone.
  • The causal organism is staphylococcus aureus.
  • The most common sites are the upper tibia and lower femur.
  • X-ray shows an osteolytic lesion with sclerotic rim.
  • In children, Brodie's abscess is most common in the metaphyseal area.
  • Occurs before epiphyseal closure in a child.
  • In adults, it is more common in the epiphyseal-metaphyseal junction.
  • Occurs after epiphyseal closure in adults.

Option E - Ewing's sarcoma:

  • Commonly arises from the endothelial cells of the bone marrow of diaphysis.
  • Second most common primary malignant tumor overall.
  • Most common primary malignant tumor in a child below 10 years.
  • Common sites involved:
    • 1st - Upper tibia
    • 2nd - Lower femur
  • Onion-peel appearance (periosteum is layered to different layers) is also seen radiologically.

questions.text: A researcher is analyzing a dataset containing observations 4, 1, 2, 3, and 10 regarding the prevalence of a particular disease in a community. What is the mean of this dataset?
questions.solution:
Correct option a – 4:

  • The mean is calculated as the sum of the observations / total no. of observations.
  • Mean = 4 + 1 + 2 + 3 + 10 = 20/5 = 4.
  • The mean is most affected by outliers (extreme values).

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, D:

  • These are not the mean values of the given data.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female, a known patient of congenital heart disease and anxiety disorder, presented to the physician's office complaining of allergic rhinitis. She was prescribed fexofenadine. Which of the following is correct by fexofenadine?

choices.text: Fexofenadine is a beta-blocker that helps reduce heart palpitations caused by anxiety.
Fexofenadine is an antihistamine that helps relieve allergy symptoms such as runny nose and sneezing.
Fexofenadine is a corticosteroid that reduces inflammation in the nasal passages.
Fexofenadine is an antibiotic that treats bacterial infections related to allergies.

questions.solution:
Explanation:

  1. Option 1: This option is incorrect. Fexofenadine is not a beta-blocker. It is an antihistamine used to relieve allergy symptoms. It does not have any direct effect on anxiety or heart palpitations.

  2. Option 2: This option is correct. Fexofenadine is an antihistamine that is commonly used to treat allergic rhinitis. It works by blocking the effects of histamine, a chemical released by the body in response to allergens. This helps relieve symptoms like runny nose, sneezing, itching, and watery eyes.

  3. Option 3: This option is incorrect. Fexofenadine is not a corticosteroid. Corticosteroids are a different class of medications used to reduce inflammation, but they work through a different mechanism than antihistamines like fexofenadine.

  4. Option 4: This option is incorrect. Fexofenadine is not an antibiotic. Antibiotics are used to treat bacterial infections, while fexofenadine is specifically used to treat allergic reactions by targeting histamine receptors.

In summary, the correct option is: Fexofenadine is an antihistamine that helps relieve allergy symptoms such as runny nose and sneezing.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman came to the clinic for a consultation regarding contraception. She expressed interest in starting oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) and requests information about the contents of a particular brand she saw advertised. The physician provided her with a package inserted in the image below. Based on the information provided, what is the composition of the oral contraceptive?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg and ethinylestradiol 0.03 mg:

  • The composition of the oral contraceptive depicted in the image is Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg and Ethinylestradiol 0.03 mg.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D provide compositions that do not match the package insert shown in the image.

questions.text: Which muscle would not be affected in a 15-year-old boy who suffered an arrow injury in the suboccipital triangle?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Splenius capitis

  • The splenius capitis is innervated by the dorsal primary rami of the middle and lower cervical nerves.
  • So, injuring the suboccipital nerve between the vertebral artery and the posterior arch of the atlas won't affect the splenius capitis.
  • Splenius capitis and splenius cervicis together form the spinotransversales muscles.
  • The two spinotransversales muscles run from the spinous processes and ligamentum nuchae upward and laterally.
  • It is attached to the mastoid process of the temporal bone.
  • It is also attached to the transverse process of the upper cervical vertebrae.
  • Together, both of these muscles draw the head backward, extending the neck. Individually, each muscle rotates its head to one side- the same side as the contracting muscle.

Incorrect Option A, B, D:

  • These muscles will be affected due to the injury to the suboccipital nerve.
  • The suboccipital nerve (primary dorsal ramus of the C1) supplies muscles of the suboccipital area, including
    • The rectus capitis posterior major
    • Obliquus capitis superior
    • The semispinalis capitis

questions.text: A 25-year-old tall male presented to the emergency department with complaints of sudden stabbing left-sided chest pain and shortness of breath. On examination, there was reduced breath sound, hyper-resonant percussion, and decreased fremitus in the left lung. The chest x-ray of the patient is given below. Based on the above history and clinical findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Primary spontaneous pneumothorax:

  • In this case, a young male with a smoking history of three pack year presented with signs and symptoms of primary spontaneous pneumothorax.
  • Chest x-ray shows a large left pneumothorax with the whole lung collapsed towards the hilum.
  • Primary spontaneous pneumothorax- spontaneous pneumothorax without underlying lung disease 
  • The rupture of subpleural apical blebs causes it.
  • Risk factors include family history, male sex, young age, slim and tall stature, smoking, and homocystinuria
  • C/F: sudden onset and mild dyspnea
  • Investigation:  NCCT, CXR
  • Treatment for low-risk patients is conservative, while for high-risk patients is chest tube placement.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Tension Pneumothorax:

  • The one-way valve mechanism is when air enters the pleural space but cannot exit on expiration.
  • Immediate chest decompression is needed.

Option C - Secondary spontaneous pneumothorax:

  • It occurs as a complication of underlying lung disease.
  • COPD, pulmonary TB, and cystic fibrosis are the risk factors.

Option D - Traumatic pneumothorax:

  • It is caused by blunt trauma, penetrating injury, or ventilator-associated.
  • Most patients require immediate chest tube placement.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can cause both ototoxicity and nephrotoxicity?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Vancomycin:

  • Vancomycin is the drug out of all the 4 options that can cause ototoxicity and nephrotoxicity
  • Vancomycin is a commonly used antibiotic with potent activity against Gram-positive organisms, but prolonged use or high doses can lead to toxicity. While vancomycin-associated nephrotoxicity is widely reported, few cases of ototoxicity have been described.
  • The side effects of vancomycin are
    • Red man syndrome(red rash on face and body)
    • Ototoxicity
    • Nephrotoxicity
    • Eosinophilia
    • Low blood pressure

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Azithromycin:

  • Azithromycin can cause ototoxicity, but no nephrotoxicity is reported.

Option C - Clindamycin:

  • Clindamycin does not cause ototoxicity or Nephrotoxicity

Option D - Penicillin:

  • Penicillin side effects are rash, urticaria, and serious adverse reactions are anaphylaxis

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman delivers a female baby by normal vaginal delivery. A pediatric resident examines the baby and notes an exaggerated Moro's reflex. Which of the following is responsible for this finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Stage 1 (early/mild) Hypoxic Ischemic Encephalopathy:

  • It causes an exaggerated Moro’s reflex

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Stage -3 (severe) Hypoxic Ischemic Encephalopathy

Option B - Down syndrome

Option C - Acute Bilirubin Encephalopathy

  • These conditions cause absent Moro’s reflex

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to a vision center complaining of difficulty seeing at night. Upon further inquiry, she mentioned living in a poorly lit area without proper street lighting. The healthcare provider suspects her vision impairment might be due to inadequate lighting conditions. What is the unit of illuminance?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B- Lux:

  • What is perceived as light is a narrow wavelength band of electromagnetic radiation from about 380 to 780 nm. Light containing all visible waves is perceived as white.
  • There are four measures of importance in the context of measuring light.
  • The four measures are:
    • Illumination or illuminance: It is the amount of light reaching a surface measured in lux per unit area.
    • Brightness or luminance: It is the amount of light reflected from a surface measured in lamberts.
    • Luminous intensity: It is the power of a light source considered as a point radiating in all directions. This is measured as candela or candle power.
    • Luminous flux: It is the flow of light related to a unit of solid angle measured in lumen.

Incorrect Options

Options A, C, and D- (Lambert, Lumen & Candela):

  • These units are already described in the correct answer explanation and are not the units of measurement for illuminance.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a 25-year-long history of alcohol consumption presents to the hospital. On clinical examination, he is jaundiced and has peripheral oedema and ascites. After performing liver function tests, he is diagnosed with liver cirrhosis. Which plasma enzyme would be of no help in interpreting his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct option A: Lipase

  • Serum lipase and amylase are used in the diagnosis of acute pancreatitis, not liver cirrhosis.
  • The inflammation of the pancreas leads to cellular damage, and, as a consequence, amylase and lipase are released.

Incorrect options

Option B: ALP

  • ALP (Alkaline Phosphatase) is used in the diagnosis of liver cirrhosis as this enzyme is released as a result of damage to bile canaliculi
  • This enzyme is specific to the liver and is present in bile canaliculi.

Option C: AST

  • AST (Aspartate Transaminase) is used to diagnose liver cirrhosis as this enzyme is specific to the liver and is released as a result of damage to hepatocytes
  • Moderate level increase (5-fold) of AST occurs in cirrhosis and obstructive liver disease.
  • AST is also increased in hepatitis.

Option D: ALT

  • ALT (Alanine Transaminase) is used to diagnose liver cirrhosis as this enzyme is specific to the liver and is released as a result of hepatocyte damage
  • ALT is an early and specific marker for hepatocellular damage.
  • ALT is also increased in alcohol-related liver disease and fatty liver.

questions.text: What region of the brain is responsible for saccades and receives innervation from Y fibers in the retina in a topographic manner?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Superior colliculus:

  • The superior colliculus, located in the midbrain, is responsible for coordinating saccadic eye movements and receives innervation from Y fibers in the retina. This region processes visual information and helps direct the eyes toward relevant stimuli.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Frontal eye field:

  • The frontal eye field, located in the frontal lobe of the cerebral cortex, is involved in the initiation of voluntary eye movements, including saccades, but it does not receive direct innervation from Y fibers in the retina.

Option C - Pretectal nucleus:

  • The pretectal nucleus is involved in controlling the pupillary light reflex, not saccadic eye movements.

Option D - Brodmann area 17:

  • Brodmann area 17, also known as the primary visual cortex, is responsible for processing visual information but is not directly involved in the coordination of eye movements.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is not associated with walking pneumonia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D- Pneumococcal pneumonia:

  • Walking pneumonia is also called atypical pneumonia and pneumococcus is not a causative organism of atypical pneumonia.

Incorrect Options A, B, C (Mycoplasma pneumoniae, Legionella pneumophila & Chlamydia pneumoniae): All these organisms cause walking pneumonia.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient with a history of autoimmune hepatitis experiences a sudden exacerbation of symptoms and a rise in liver enzyme levels. The patient denies any changes in medications or exposure to infectious agents. Upon further inquiry, the patient reveals the recent initiation of a drug for acne management. Which of the following medications is most likely responsible for triggering the exacerbation of autoimmune hepatitis in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Minocycline:

  • Minocycline, which is commonly used in the management of acne, has been associated with drug-induced autoimmune hepatitis. It can trigger an immune response against the liver, leading to an exacerbation of autoimmune hepatitis in susceptible individuals. This emphasizes the importance of monitoring liver function in patients receiving minocycline and considering alternative treatments in those with a history of autoimmune hepatitis.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Penicillin: Penicillin is not typically associated with autoimmune hepatitis.

Option B - Prednisone: Prednisone is a corticosteroid and is often used in the treatment of autoimmune hepatitis to suppress the immune response and reduce inflammation.

Option D - Propranolol: Propranolol is a beta-blocker used primarily for cardiovascular conditions and is not known to cause autoimmune hepatitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is a histological feature seen in patients with Grave’s disease?

choices.text: Sheets of Polygonal cells in an amyloid stroma
Empty appearing nuclei with central clearing
A pale colloid in the follicular lumen with scalloped margins

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Pale colloid in the follicular lumen with scalloped margins:

  • In Graves' disease, the histological feature commonly observed is the presence of a pale colloid in the follicular lumen with scalloped margins. This occurs due to the increased activity of thyroid hormone production, leading to the depletion of colloid material within the thyroid follicles.
  • Due to continuous stimulation by autoantibody, the thyroid gland is usually symmetrically enlarged due to diffuse hypertrophy and hyperplasia of follicular epithelial cells. Follicular epithelial cells in untreated cases are tall and more crowded than usual on histology. This crowding may result in the formation of small papillae, which project into the follicular lumen and encroach on the colloid, sometimes filling the follicles. The colloid within the follicular lumen is pale, with scalloped margins.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Sheets of Polygonal cells in an amyloid stroma:

  • Sheets of Polygonal cells in an amyloid stroma are usually seen in medullary thyroid carcinoma, the tumour of Parafollicular 'C-cells' of the thyroid gland.
  • They produce calcitonin, which can lead to hypocalcemia.
  • It is associated with MEN2A and MEN2B (RET mutation).

Option B - Lymphocytic infiltration with germinal centers:

  • Lymphocytic infiltration with germinal centers is usually seen in Hashimoto's Thyroiditis.
  • It is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient countries.
  • Other important features are present anti-Thyroid peroxidase antibodies on serology and Hurthle’s cells on histology.

Option C - Empty appearing nuclei with central clearing:

  • Empty appearing nuclei with central clearing (Orphan Annie eyes) are seen in papillary carcinoma of the thyroid
  • The other important features on histology are Psammoma bodies and nuclear grooves.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient with a known history of chronic alcohol abuse presents to the emergency department complaining of increasing abdominal distention. On examination, there are massive ascites and peripheral edema. serum sodium: 125 mEq/L and serum potassium: 4.0 mEq/L The patient also reports increased salt intake for the past few weeks. Which of the following mechanisms most likely contributes to the development of hypervolemic hyponatremia in this patient?

choices.text: Decreased reabsorption of water in the distal nephron

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system:

  • In this patient with cirrhosis, hyponatremia is likely due to the activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS).
  • Cirrhosis leads to portal hypertension and decreased effective arterial blood volume, triggering the release of renin from the kidneys.
  • Renin then initiates the cascade of RAAS activation, leading to increased aldosterone secretion. Aldosterone promotes sodium and water retention in the kidneys, expanding extracellular fluid volume and dilutional hyponatremia.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Excessive intake of dietary sodium: Although excessive intake of dietary sodium may contribute to fluid retention in some cases, it is not the primary mechanism in cirrhotic patients with hypervolemic hyponatremia.

Option C - Impaired secretion of antidiuretic hormone (ADH): Impaired secretion of ADH can lead to hypervolemic hyponatremia in certain conditions such as diabetes insipidus, it is not typically seen in cirrhosis.

Option D - Decreased water reabsorption in the distal nephron: Decreased water reabsorption in the distal nephron would lead to a hypovolemic, rather than hypervolemic, state.

questions.text: Which of the following is the risk factor for direct inguinal hernia among the options given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Cigarette smoking:

  • Cigarette smoking t can cause chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and chronic cough), leading to increased intra-abdominal pressure, thus being the culprit for direct inguinal hernia.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Chronic Diarrhea:

  • Chronic diarrhea is not a risk factor for developing an inguinal hernia.

Option B - Underweight:

  • Obesity is a risk factor for developing a hernia.

Option D - None of the above:

  • Only Smoking is the mentioned risk factor for developing an inguinal hernia.

questions.text:
Match the following options under 1. Massive pulmonary embolism and 2. Sub-massive pulmonary embolism

a. BP is reduced

b. Normal chest x-ray

c. ECG: S1 Q3 T3

d. BP is normal

e. Right ventricle hypokinesia

f. Hampton hump on chest x-ray

g. ECG shows sinus tachycardia

h. Right ventricular dilatation

choices.text: 1 - b, d, g and h; 2 - a, c, e and f
1 - a, d, e and h; 2 - b, c, f and g
1 - b, c, f and g; 2 - a, d, e and h
1 - a, c, e and f; 2 - b, d, g and h

questions.solution:
Correct Option: D - 1 - a, c, e and f; 2 - b, d, g and h

1. Massive pulmonary embolism

2. Sub-massive pulmonary embolism

a. BP is reduced

c. ECG: S1 Q3 T3

e. Right ventricle hypokinesia

f. Hampton hump on chest x-ray

b. Normal chest x-ray

d. BP is normal

g. ECG shows sinus tachycardia

h. Right ventricular dilatation

Incorrect options: A, B and C - Refer to the above explanation and learning outcome

questions.text: A 55-year-old male undergoes a routine abdominal X-ray for health screening. The X-ray reveals the presence of calcifications in the kidney. Which of the following types of calcifications is commonly seen in the kidney?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Eggshell calcifications

  • Eggshell calcifications are thin, curvilinear calcifications seen along the periphery of a structure. In the kidney, they are commonly seen along the renal pelvis or the walls of renal cysts. They are typically associated with benign lesions, such as renal cysts but may also be found in cases of RCC.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Stippled calcifications: Stippled calcifications are small, punctate, and finely distributed. They are commonly seen in the thyroid gland, prostate, and testes but not typically in the kidney.

  • Seen in Enchondroma.

Option B - Ring-like calcifications: Ring-like calcifications are seen in lesions with central necrosis, such as some tumors. They appear as a circular calcification surrounding a central low-density area. While this type of calcification can be seen in the kidneys, it is less common compared to other organs.

Option D - Diffuse calcifications: Diffuse calcifications refer to widespread and uniform calcification throughout a structure. While diffuse calcifications can be seen in the kidneys in conditions like nephrocalcinosis, they are not specific to the kidney and can also occur in other organs.

  • Toxoplasma causes diffuse calcification throughout the brain.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the emergency department. He was diagnosed with hypertension 7 months ago, and his condition has been deteriorating since then, even on regular medications. On examination, his blood pressure is 200/120 mmHg. Fundoscopic examination reveals retinal hemorrhages. A CT scan of the brain shows a hemorrhage in the putamen. Laboratory investigations show evidence of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA). What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Malignant hypertension:

  • Malignant hypertension is characterized by severely elevated blood pressure along with end-organ damage. The presence of retinal hemorrhages, intracranial hemorrhage (putamen), and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA) are all consistent with malignant hypertension.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A -  Essential hypertension: Essential hypertension is incorrect because essential hypertension typically does not present with acute end-organ damage such as intracranial hemorrhage, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and renal impairment.

Option C - Hypertensive urgency: Hypertensive urgency refers to severely elevated blood pressure without acute end-organ damage. This patient has evidence of end-organ damage, making hypertensive urgency less likely.

Option D - Hypertensive emergency: Hypertensive emergency is characterized by severely elevated blood pressure with acute end-organ damage. However, the term "malignant hypertension" specifically refers to a hypertensive emergency with the characteristic features described in the patient's presentation

questions.text: What is the transmission route of Polio?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Feco-oral:

  • Polio is transmitted by the Feco-oral route.
  • Poliovirus belongs to the Family Picornaviridae.
  • Characteristics of the Family Picornaviridae:
    • Very small (pico: measuring small; RNA: RNA virus) RNA viruses.
    • The genome consists of a single linear molecule of single-stranded RNA.
    • Natural infection occurs only in humans.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with progressive dysphagia to both solids and liquids. A barium swallow study is performed, revealing dilatation of the oesophagus with a narrowed distal oesophageal segment as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Achalasia cardia

  • Achalasia is a motility disorder characterized by impaired lower esophageal sphincter relaxation and absent peristalsis in the esophagus. The classic radiographic finding in achalasia is the "bird's beak" appearance, which represents the narrowed and tapered distal esophagus on a barium swallow study.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD): GERD refers to the backward flow of gastric contents into the esophagus, leading to symptoms such as heartburn and regurgitation. It does not typically present with the "bird's beak" appearance seen in achalasia.It can lead to feline esophagus

Option C - Esophageal carcinoma: Apple core appearance is seen on a barium swallow study. Most common in the middle third.

Option D - Esophageal stricture: Eesophageal stricture refers to the narrowing of the oesophageal lumen, usually due to chronic inflammation or scarring.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male, a watchman by occupation, comes to the OPD complaining of swelling and bulging of veins in the lower limbs. He also describes feeling restlessness, occasional cramping bilaterally, and tiredness at the end of the day. Examination reveals dilated, tortuous veins in the patient's right lower limb, extending from the middle thigh to the leg in a standing position. Doppler test results show venous stasis. On the basis of the patient's condition, which of the following is true?

choices.text: Most common symptom: Dull aching pain in the veins after prolonged standing the whole day
Clinical investigation is the choice for the diagnosis of varicose veins
Bisgard's Regime is not used for venous ulcers
Trendelenberg operation is a gold standard treatment for varicose veins

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Most common symptom: Dull aching pain in the veins after prolonged standing the whole day:

  • In this case, as the patient's occupation is watchman, he has to stand for a prolonged period.
  • If a person has to sit or stand for a long time, the blood in the leg veins can pool, leading to increased blood pressure. 
  • Prolonged standing can result in the stretching of veins. This stretching can result in the weakening of the walls of veins and damage vein valves and resulting in an enlarged and swollen vein called varicose vein formation.
  • It is caused by blood reflux and stagnation due to the dysfunction of the superficial veins in the lower extremities. Most people show no obvious discomfort, but some patients can face pain, soreness, swelling and even bleeding.

​​​​​​

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Clinical investigation is the choice for the diagnosis of varicose veins:

  • Duplex ultrasound is considered the ideal investigation of choice for the diagnosis of varicose veins.

Option C - Bisgaard's Regime is not used for venous ulcers:

  • Bisgaard's Regime is Limb elevation.

Option D - Trendelenberg operation is a gold standard treatment for varicose vein:

  • Endothermal Ablation (EVLA and RFA) is a gold standard treatment for varicose veins.

questions.text: Which of the following treatment options is commonly used for the symptomatic relief of allergic rhinitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Nasal decongestants 

  • Nasal decongestants are medications that help alleviate symptoms of nasal congestion, stuffiness, and sinus pressure.
  • They work by constricting the blood vessels in the nasal passages, which reduces swelling and opens up the airways.
  • Nasal decongestants are available in various forms, including nasal sprays, drops, and oral tablets.
  • However, it's important to use them for a short duration as prolonged use can lead to a condition called rebound congestion.
  • Nasal decongestants provide symptomatic relief but do not address the underlying allergic response in allergic rhinitis.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Subcutaneous immunotherapy (SCIT):

  • Subcutaneous immunotherapy, commonly known as allergy shots, is a long-term treatment option for allergic rhinitis.
  • It involves injecting gradually increasing doses of allergen extracts under the skin.
  • The purpose of SCIT is to desensitize the immune system to specific allergens, including pollen, dust mites, or pet dander.
  • Over time, this can reduce the severity of allergic reactions and provide lasting relief.
  • SCIT requires regular visits to a healthcare professional for administration and monitoring.

Option C -Antifungal medications:

  • Antifungal medications are drugs used to treat fungal infections.
  • They are not typically used for the treatment of allergic rhinitis.
  • Allergic rhinitis is primarily triggered by allergens such as pollen, dust mites, or pet dander, rather than fungal infections.
  • Antifungal medications are more appropriate for conditions such as fungal skin infections, oral thrush, or systemic fungal infections.

Option D - Antibiotics:

  • Antibiotics are medications used to treat bacterial infections.
  • Allergic rhinitis is not caused by bacteria, so antibiotics are not effective in treating the underlying allergic response.
  • Antibiotics are only necessary if a bacterial infection, such as sinusitis or a secondary bacterial infection, occurs as a result of allergic rhinitis.
  • In such cases, antibiotics may be prescribed to treat the bacterial infection, but they do not directly address the allergic symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following has a large number of serous demilunes?
questions.solution:
Option B: Submandibular

  • Serous demilunes are cellular formations in the shape of a half-moon on some salivary glands.
  • It is one of the major salivary glands.
  • It is a feature of mixed (seromucous) glands, like submandibular salivary glands.
  • It is 95% serous and 5% mucous.
  • Stroma:
    • Capsule: It encapsulates the gland.
    • Lobule: Connective leads to the division of glands into lobules.
  • Parenchyma:
    • Serous cells: These cells are polarized and present in acinus and have endoplasmic reticulum in the base with granular secretion in the apex.
    • Mucous cells: These cells have a flattened nucleus at the bottom of the cells.

 

Option A: Parotid

  • Serous glands are present in the,
    • Parotid salivary glands.
    • Serous glands have dark staining cells.
  • Serous demilunes: Serous glands are sitting on the mucous gland, which is a feature of the mixed gland, not the serous gland

Option C: Sublingual

  • Sublingual glands are chiefly mucinous glands that are present in
    • Sublingual gland.
    • It has an empty look and light staining cells.
  • Serous demilunes are cellular formations in the shape of a half-moon that are present in mixed glands, not mucinous or serous glands alone.

Option D: Pituitary

  • The pituitary gland is an endocrine gland.
  • In the endocrine type of secretion, the hormones are secreted directly to the bloodstream without any duct.

questions.text: Which among the following is false/incorrect in the treatment of Acute hepatitis B infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Bed rest/ monitoring not required:

Treatment

Acute hepatitis B

  • Bed rest
  • Advice to stop smoking
  • Management
    • Itopride or Mosapride for nausea
    • Domperidone and Metoclopramide for vomiting
  • I.V. fluids (10% dextrose or NS) for dehydration
  • Monitoring

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B and C

  • These are true regarding the treatment of acute hepatitis B.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with a history of open-angle glaucoma is prescribed various antiglaucoma medications to manage intraocular pressure. Which of the following antiglaucoma drugs are wrongly matched with their mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Alpha agonists - Increase trabecular outflow:

  • Alpha agonists primarily work by reducing aqueous humor production and increasing uveoscleral outflow, rather than specifically increasing trabecular outflow.
  • NOTE: Normally, 90% of aqueous drains through trabecular outflow and 10% through Uveoscleral drainage.

Incorrect Options:

Option A -  Prostaglandin analogues – Increases uveoscleral outflow:

  • This is correct. Prostaglandin analogs are known to increase the uveoscleral outflow of aqueous humor, reducing intraocular pressure.

Option B - Miotic agents – Increases trabecular outflow:

  • This is correct. Miotic agents primarily work by constricting the pupil (miosis) and tightening the trabecular meshwork, which facilitates increased outflow of aqueous humor through the trabecular pathway.

Option C - Beta blockers – Decrease aqueous formation:

  • This is correct. Beta-blockers work by reducing the production of aqueous humor in the ciliary body, thereby lowering intraocular pressure.

questions.text: In a 14-year-old boy with left eye swelling, erythema, and proptosis, which clinical finding is most indicative of potential cavernous sinus thrombosis?

choices.text: Failed abduction in the left eye
Failed abduction in the right eye
Failed adduction in the left eye

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Failed abduction in the right eye:

  • Cavernous sinus thrombosis can result in failed abduction due to the involvement of cranial nerves, particularly cranial nerve VI (the first nerve to be involved in cavernous sinus thrombosis). The abducens nerve controls the lateral rectus muscle, responsible for the abduction of the eye. In this case, thrombosis affecting the cavernous sinus on the right side, would result in failed abduction in the right eye.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Failed abduction in the left eye: This would suggest a sixth cranial nerve (abducens nerve) palsy, which can be caused by cavernous sinus thrombosis. However, in the scenario described, where there is swelling and pain in the left eye, failed abduction in the left eye might also be attributed to localized inflammation or orbital cellulitis.

Option C - Ptosis in the left eye: Ptosis, or drooping of the upper eyelid, can occur in various neurological and muscular conditions, but it is not a specific sign of cavernous sinus thrombosis.

Option D - Failed adduction in the left eye: This would suggest a problem with the medial rectus muscle and the third cranial nerve (oculomotor nerve). While third nerve palsy can be associated with cavernous sinus pathology, failed adduction alone may not specifically point to cavernous sinus thrombosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient came to the outpatient department with a complaint of gradual diminished vision from the past two days. He admitted that he lately experiences some hallucinations and memory loss. His personal history shows he is a chronic alcoholic with a history of hooch consumption. The patient also and had a seizure episode during a recent episode of binge drinking. The ophthalmologist checked the eyes and the findings are shown below. Suggest an antidote to this condition and the appropriate treatment recommended for this condition.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Fomepizole-Ringer  lactate:

  • The fundal images show a damaged retina.
  • The question describes diminished vision(due to a damaged retina), and encephalopathy(signs of seizure activity, loss of memory, and hallucinations). The patient is a chronic alcoholic with a history of consuming hooch (illicit whiskey -likely methyl alcohol) and the likely diagnosis is methyl alcohol toxicity.
  • Methyl alcohol- Metabolized by the same enzyme that metabolizes ethyl alcohol (Alcohol dehydrogenase)
  • Metabolizes Methyl alcohol → Formaldehyde → Formic acid.
  • Formic acid has Low pH leading to metabolic acidosis.
  • Causes BBB damage - Encephalopathy and damage to retina
  • Antidote - Fomepizole - Inhibits Alcohol dehydrogenase.
  • Fluid of choice – Ringer Lactate

​​​​Incorrect Options:

Option A - Diazepam - 5%Dextrose:

  • Diazepam is used for convulsions but the question asked about the overall antidote for metabolic acidosis due to excess methyl alcohol(formic acid)

Option B - Activated charcoal - Normal saline:

  • Activated Charcoal is used as an antidote in most poisonings.

Option D - Mannitol-Ringer lactate:

  • Mannitol is used in the treatment of cerebral edema and fluid retention.

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes massive transfusion protocol?

choices.text: Replacement of the entire blood volume with more than 10 Units of whole blood within 24 hours
Replacement of the entire blood volume with more than 3 units of whole blood given within 4 hours period
Replacement of the entire blood volume with by more than 10 Units of whole blood within 12 hours
Replacement of the entire blood volume more than 2.5 L of whole blood given within 2 hours period

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Replacement of the entire blood volume with more than 10 Units of whole blood within 24 hours:

Definition of massive transfusion protocol

  • Replacement of the entire blood volume of the patient by more than 10 Units of whole blood within 24 hours or more than 2.5 L (5 units) of whole blood given within 4 hours period.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, D- Refer to the above explanation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man from Jharkhand presents with a single hypopigmented macule on his forearm. The lesion is well-demarcated, oval-shaped, and exhibits a smooth and slightly scaly texture. There are no signs of itching or inflammation. Upon examination, no nerve thickening or sensory loss is detected. Based on the clinical presentation, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for the observed lesion?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Indeterminate leprosy:

  • The clinical features described in the scenario, including a single hypopigmented macule that is well-demarcated, oval-shaped, and smooth without scaling, are indicative of an indeterminate leprosy lesion. Indeterminate leprosy is an early and mild form of leprosy, often presenting as a single hypopigmented macule or patch with no signs of nerve involvement or sensory loss.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Pityriasis alba: Pityriasis alba is a common skin condition that typically affects children and adolescents. It is characterized by multiple, poorly defined hypopigmented macules with fine scaling, often seen on the face. Unlike indeterminate leprosy, which presents as a single well-demarcated macule, pityriasis alba usually involves multiple macules and has a different distribution pattern.

Option C - Tinea versicolor: Tinea versicolor is a superficial fungal infection caused by Malassezia species. It results in multiple, slightly scaly macules that may coalesce and exhibit hypo or hyperpigmentation. The lesions are commonly found on the trunk and proximal extremities. In contrast, the scenario describes a single macule on the forearm, which is not consistent with the typical presentation of tinea versicolor.

Option D - Vitiligo: Vitiligo is an autoimmune condition characterized by depigmented macules or patches due to the destruction of melanocytes. The lesions of vitiligo are usually well-defined, chalky white, and can occur on any part of the body. However, vitiligo typically presents as multiple lesions rather than a single macule as described in the scenario.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to your clinic for consultation. The main concern is bleeding gums. The mother states several episodes of excessive bleeding previously from minor injuries. You find out that the maternal grandfather has a clotting disorder. Physical examination of the child reveals slight tenderness over the knee with fluid accumulation in the knee joint. Which of the following coagulation factors is likely deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Factor VIII:

  • Hemophilia A, characterized by a deficiency in Factor VIII, explains the bleeding gums and excessive bleeding from minor injuries seen in the 2-year-old child. The maternal grandfather's history of a clotting disorder further supports this diagnosis. Hemophilia A is an X-linked recessive disorder, and affected males typically inherit the defective gene from their carrier mothers.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Prothrombin activator:

  • Deficiency in prothrombin activator is not a specific coagulation factor deficiency and is not typically associated with bleeding disorders.

Option B - Factor VII:

  • Factor VII deficiency results in impaired initiation of the coagulation process, but it is not associated with an X-linked recessive inheritance pattern.

Option D - Factor X:

  • Factor X deficiency leads to impaired thrombin formation and blood clotting, but it is not commonly associated with an X-linked recessive inheritance pattern.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presents with recurrent UTIs, left flank pain, fatigue, and occasional low-grade fever. Physical exam reveals left flank tenderness. Lab tests show elevated inflammatory markers, hematuria, and pyuria. Imaging confirms horseshoe kidney-fusion of lower poles across the midline. Which structure prevents these kidneys from ascending?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Inferior mesenteric artery:

  • The ascent of the horseshoe kidney remains incomplete due to inferior mesenteric artery preventing further migration of the kidney.
  • The normal ascent of the kidneys makes the organs take their place in the abdomen below the adrenal glands.
  • However, with horseshoe kidney, the ascent into the abdomen is prevented by the inferior mesenteric artery, which hooks over the isthmus.
  • Isthmus is usually located adjacent to L3-L4 vertebrae, just below the origin of IMA from the abdominal aorta.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Superior mesenteric artery:

  • In the middle of the digestive tract is the superior mesenteric artery (midgut). It comes from the aorta, which is situated between the renal and celiac arteries.
  • It has no relationship with the ascent of the kidney.

Option B - Superior mesenteric vein:

  • The Superior mesenteric vein (SMV), a significant venous tributary of the abdominal cavity, is the superior mesenteric vein.
  • It has no relationship with the ascent of the kidney.

Option D - Inferior mesenteric vein:

  • It's the inferior mesenteric artery, not the vein, which prevents the ascent of the horseshoe kidney in the abdomen.

questions.text: A newborn develops yellowish discolouration of skin which is more towards the limbs compared to the face. On evaluation, the bilirubin level on soles is 14 mg/dl while on the face, it is 6 mg/dl. Which part of the brain is commonly involved in neonatal jaundice?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Basal Ganglia

  • Most Commonly involved part of the brain in neonatal jaundice: Basal ganglia.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Thalamus

Option B - Hypothalamus

Option C -  Lateral ventricle

  • These are not commonly involved in neonatal jaundice

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy comes to the clinic accompanied by his father and complains of rashes over genitalia. After evaluation, the doctor diagnosed it as a fungal infection and prescribed an antifungal drug. He also has reddened scrotal skin. Which stage of puberty is associated with the finding mentioned?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Stage 2:

  • Stage 2 comprises of Enlargement of testes & scrotum, Scrotal skin reddens, and Slight or no enlargement of penis

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Stage 5:

  • Adult genitalia (>20 ml)

Option B - Stage 4:

  • Tests & scrotum longer
  • Scrotal skin darker
  • Penis increases in length & breadth, glans becomes more prominent.

Option C - Stage 3:

  •  Further growth of testis
  •  Penis increases in length.

questions.text: An eight-year-old child living in an endemic area for leprosy presents to the community health center for prophylactic treatment. As part of the standard protocol, the healthcare provider decides to administer Rifampicin. Which of the following is the appropriate dose of Rifampicin that can be given for prophylaxis of leprosy in this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 300 mg:

  • This is the correct dosage of Rifampicin for prophylaxis of leprosy in children aged 6-9 years.
  • This is in accordance with the Sparsh Programme.
  • Side effects of Rifampin include reddish discoloration or tears, sweat, and/or urine.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 350 mg:

  • This dose exceeds the recommended dosage for prophylaxis of leprosy in children 6-9 years and may increase the risk of adverse effects without providing additional benefit.

Option C - 400 mg:

  • This dose exceeds the recommended dosage for children 6-9 years and is not appropriate for prophylactic treatment of leprosy in this age group.
  • For children 10-14 years old, a single dose of 450 mg of Rifampin is recommended.

Option D - 600 mg:

  • This dose is higher than the recommended dosage for children 6-9 years for leprosy prophylaxis.
  • Administering such a high dose can lead to an increased risk of adverse effects without additional therapeutic benefit.
  • 600 mg is recommended for use in those ≥ 15 years of age.

questions.text: The given structure is:

choices.text: D-Enantiomer of glucose at C-2 and C-3

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Epimer of glucose at C-2:

This structure shown is Mannose.

  • Epimerism is different H and OH orientation at one chiral center.
  • Mannose is an epimer of glucose at C-2.

Incorrect Options

Option A - Epimer of glucose at C-4:

  • Galactose is an epimer of glucose at C-4.

Option B - Enantiomer of glucose at C-4 :

  • Enantiomers are mirror images, meaning they have different configurations at all the chiral centers.

Option D - Enantiomer of glucose at C-2 and C-3:

  • For enantiomer, we compare penultimate carbon for D and L notation. The penultimate carbon, in this case, is C5. So, option D is false.

questions.text: All of the following are used to manage a case of snake bite except?

choices.text: Check for clot features in the test tube after 20 min

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Apply a tourniquet

  • Do not apply a tourniquet: To avoid pressure necrosis. ·
  • If a tourniquet is already applied then, don't cut the tourniquet, as it may cause the extensive spread of poison resulting in
    • Diaphragm paralysis
    • Sudden onset hypotension due to histamine release

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Immobilize the patient: Which prevents faster spread of venom.

Option B - Reassure: Because 70% snake bites belong to nonvenomous species.

Option D - Check for clot features in test tube after 20 min: To assess coagulopathy

  • Normal: a solid clot is retained on the inversion of the tube at 20 or 30 minutes (Grade 0, no coagulopathy)
  • Abnormal: clot degrades rapidly (Grade 1, friable clot) or fails to coagulate whatsoever (Grade-2)
  • 20 minutes Whole Blood Clotting Test - Repeat every 30 min for the first 3 hours of the admission ( after giving ASV it can be done on a 1- hour basis).
