questions.text: A 23-year-old woman was rescued from near the highway in the early hours of the morning. She was nearly unconscious but was able to record her statement while being treated by the doctors. She was allegedly abducted and raped by 2 unidentified men. The doctor was able to demonstrate presence of Spermine. Which of the following test was done by the doctor?
questions.solution:
Option A: Barberios test

  • Detects - Spermine crystals (yellow needle-shaped crystals)
  • Reagent - Picric acid.
  • Type of crystals: Spermine Picrate.

Incorrect options

Option B:Florence Test

  • Detects - Choline crystals (Dark brown rhombic crystals)
  • Reagent – KI is used.
  • Type of crystals: Choline iodide.

 

Option C:CPK (Creatinine Phospho Kinase)

  • Mnemonic: CPK - Old (Pakahua - means old in Hindi).
  • Detects: Old seminal stains (6 months old as well)
  • Normal range: 660 IU/ml.

 

Option D:Ammonium molybdate test -

  • Detects Phosphorus content of Semen.

questions.text:
Arrange the enzymes used to convert propionyl CoA to glucose in the correct sequence

A. Methyl malonyl CoA racemase

B. Succinate thiokinase

C. Methyl malonyl CoA mutase

D. Propionyl CoA carboxylase
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - D→ A→ C→B:

  • Beta oxidation of odd chain fatty acid ends with propionyl Co-A
  • Propionyl Co-A is converted into D-methyl malonyl Co-A, and this reaction is catalyzed by propionyl Co-A carboxylase; biotin is also required for this reaction.
  • D-methyl malonyl Co-A is converted into L-methyl malonyl Co-A, and the reaction is catalyzed by racemase.
  • L-methyl malonyl Co-A is finally converted into succinyl-Co-A
  • Succinate thiokinase is an enzyme used in TCA, which will be used after succinyl CoA enters TCA.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, C, and D: Refer to the explanation of Option B

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the OPD for an antenatal checkup. She denies any complaints other than early morning nausea and vomiting. She is taking her multivitamin supplements as recommended. On screening tests, serum AFP and estriol levels are lower than expected. Meanwhile, serum beta HCG and inhibin are high.  A USG shows increased nuchal translucency in the fetus. Appropriate counseling is offered and she is referred for further testing. What is the risk of having a newborn with this particular condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 1 in 30:

  • This 40-year-old pregnant woman with significant screening test abnormalities is likely having a fetus with Down syndrome. 
  • Increased nuchal translucency in the fetus is the most common ultrasound finding in fetuses with Down syndrome.
  • Women >35 years of age are at higher risk.
  • The risk of having a newborn with Down syndrome in this woman is 1 in 30.
  • Risk of having a child with Downs syndrome in a 40-year-old lady is 1 in 30

Incorrect Options:

Option B - 1 in 40

Option C - 1 in 50

Option D - 1 in 20

  • These values are incorrect

questions.text: Which statement about the Nipah virus is false?

choices.text: NiV is transmitted through bats urine

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - It causes hemorrhagic fever:

  • Hemorrhagic fevers are caused by viruses belonging to Flaviviridae, Arenaviridae, Bunyaviridae and filoviridae.
  • Nipah virus does not cause hemorrhagic fever.
  • The Nipah virus can cause:
    • Encephalitis
    • Fever

Incorrect Options:
Option A - It is transmitted through bat's urine:

  • The Nipah virus is transmitted through contamination of food and water by urinating.

Option C - It is an emerging infection:

  • The Nipah virus is an emerging infectious agent belonging to paramyxoviridae.

Option D - It is present in India:

  • There have been Nipah virus infection outbreaks in Kerala (2018).

questions.text: A 2-month-old baby presents to the pediatric outpatient department with concerns about inadequate weight gain. Upon history taking, it is revealed that the baby is exclusively breastfed. The mother reports feeding the baby on demand. On further inquiry, it is found that the baby consumes around 100 mL of breast milk per feed, with a frequency of 8 feeds per day. How many calories does the baby get from 100 mL of breast milk?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 65 kcal:

  • The amount of energy that a baby gets from 100 mL of breast milk is 65 cal.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D: These are not the correct amounts of calories in 100 mL of breast milk.

questions.text: A 14-year-old child is diagnosed with Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma. He was advised for surgery for the removal of the tumour. Which of the following clinical features is NOT associated with Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma?

choices.text: Unilateral serous otitis media and conductive hearing loss

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Neck swelling and lymphadenopathy:

  • This clinical feature is NOT typically associated with Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma. The tumor primarily grows within the nasopharynx and does not involve the lymph nodes in the neck region.
  • Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA) is a benign but locally aggressive vascular tumor that primarily affects adolescent males. It commonly presents with certain clinical features.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Recurrent unprovoked profuse epistaxis:

  • This is a hallmark feature of JNA. Due to the tumor's location in the nasopharynx, it can cause recurrent episodes of profuse nosebleeds.

Option B - Unilateral serous otitis media and conductive hearing loss:

  • JNA can cause obstruction of the Eustachian tube, leading to the accumulation of fluid in the middle ear. This can result in unilateral serous otitis media and conductive hearing loss.

Option C - Cranial involvement causing nerve palsies:

  • JNA has a tendency to extend into adjacent structures, including the cranial cavity.
  • This extension can result in involvement of cranial nerves, such as the second (optic nerve), third (oculomotor nerve), fourth (trochlear nerve), fifth (trigeminal nerve), and sixth (abducens nerve). The involvement of these cranial nerves can cause various neurological deficits.

questions.text: A primigravida presents in labour. Vaginal examination shows 4 cm dilatation and a fetal head at -1 station with a bordeline pelvis. The nurse is plotting the partograph to assess the progress so that necessary action can be taken immediately, she should mark this first point in cervical dilatation at?

choices.text: Left side of the action line
Right side of the alert line

questions.solution:
Option C : The first point on the partograph for plotting cervical dilatation is marked at 4 cm and it starts at the alert line

Partograph

In partogram, first time of the initial markings are marked on the alert line. The subsequent plotting is done from this point.

Till the graph stays on the left if the alert line, the progress can be considered satisfactory. If the graph moves towards the right of the alert line, caution is required and when the graph crosses to the right of action line, it warrants intervention.

NOTE: There are new recommendations regarding the dilatation at which start of active labour should be plotted on the partograph, which is suggested to be commenced from 6 cm. However due to lack of consensus, it is still in consideration and till any confirmed guideline on this is available to us we shall go by the old norm of 4 cm.

 

 

Options A, B, D : plotting is started from alert line at 4 cm dilatation.

questions.text: Describe the appearance of the organism using the negative staining technique.

choices.text: The yeast cells will appear stained, and the background will appear colorless.
The yeast cells and the background will both appear stained.
The yeast cells will appear colourless, and the background will appear stained.
Both the yeast cells and the background will appear colorless.

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - The yeast cells will appear colorless, and the background will appear stained:

  • When negative staining is performed on a sample, the background will be stained.
  • However, the capsule itself, being a non-ionic polysaccharide, does not take up the stain and will appear as a clear halo or zone surrounding the unstained yeast cells.

Incorrect Options:
Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option C for an explanation.

questions.text: The HR of a company sent a notice to a 28 year old man who was absent quite frequently over the past month. He used to be a confident and alert employee until recently, when he started complaining of insects crawling beneath his skin. One of his friends also noticed that his pupils were constantly dilated. Which of the following conditions could this employee have?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Chronic cocaine poisoning:

  • Magnan's sign or cocaine bugs is characteristic of Chronic cocaine poisoning, in which there is a feeling as if grains of sand are lying under the skin or some small insects are creeping on the skin giving rise to an itching sensation (formication, tactile hallucination).
  • The individual exhibits a heightened pulse rate, rapid and deep respirations, dilated pupils, a headache, pale skin, cyanosis, increased sweating, and an elevated body temperature

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Parkinsonism:

  • Parkinson’s disease can cause varying and progressive symptoms throughout its course. Some of the most common symptoms associated with the disease include:
    • Difficulty showing facial expressions
    • Muscle stiffness
    • Slowed, affected movements
    • Speech changes
    • Tremor, especially of one hand

Option B - Chronic depression:

  • Dysthymia (Chronic Depression): A mood disorder consisting of the same cognitive and physical problems as in depression, with less severe but longer-lasting symptoms.
  • patients feel like a gloomy black cloud is hanging overhead and do not remember what it felt like to not be depressed.

Option D - Acute barbiturate poisoning:

  • Barbiturate poisoning: The affected person demonstrates shallow breathing, a profound state of unconsciousness, lack of response to painful stimuli, diminished reflexes, below-normal body temperature, low blood pressure, a weak and faint pulse, and dialted pupils

questions.text: A 50-year-old female is admitted to the surgical ward for a total thyroidectomy under anaesthesia. Her medical history is consistent with diabetes mellitus, hypertension and coronary artery disease. Her medications include aspirin, metformin, amlodipine and valsartan. Transthoracic echocardiography shows an ejection fraction of 40% and no regional wall motion abnormalities. Which of the following inhalational anaesthetic agent to be avoided in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Halothane:

  • Halothane is a direct myocardial depressant.
  • Halothane, Isoflurane, Desflurane, and Sevoflurane produce similar and dose-dependent decreases in mean arterial pressure.
  • But Halothane decreases blood pressure due to the decrease in myocardial contractility and cardiac output, whereas others decrease by lowering systemic vascular resistance.
  • Isoflurane, desflurane, and sevoflurane increase heart rate.
  • Halothane causes an unchanged heart rate despite a decrease in blood pressure due to depression of the carotid sinus (baroreceptor reflex response) and drug-induced decreases in the rate of sinus node depolarization.
  • Junctional rhythm with the decrease in blood pressure reflects suppression of sinus node activity by Halothane.
  • It also decreases the speed of conduction of impulses through the AV node and His-Purkinje system.
  • Also sensitizes the heart to the arrhythmogenic effects of epinephrine and is contraindicated in pheochromocytoma.
  • Isoflurane, desflurane, and sevoflurane do not have much effect on the cardiac output as increased heart rate tends to offset the drug-induced decrease in cardiac output but not with Halothane is no change in heart rate.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Isoflurane:

  • Isoflurane does not affect cardiac output as much as Halothane does.

Option C - Sevoflurane:

  • Sevoflurane's cardio-depressant effect is very little.
  • Halothane has the maximum and direct cardio-depressant effect.

Option D - Desflurane:

  • Desflurane increases heart rate.
  • It does not cause cardiac depression

questions.text: A 49-year-old female was scheduled for herniorrhaphy. During the surgery, the surgeon observed that the shape of the hernia was in a “W” shape, as shown in the image below. What is the name of the hernia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Maydl's hernia :

  • The picture shown above is that of a Maydl hernia.
  • The hernial sac has two loops of the bowel, one of which is intra-abdominal. The hernial sac contains a loop of the bowel in the shape of a 'W', and the center section of the 'W' loop may become strangulated, either alone or in conjunction with the bowel in the hernial sac.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Richter’s hernia:

  • A Richter's hernia arises when the intestine's antimesenteric wall protrudes through a hole in the abdominal wall.

Option B - Littre's hernia:

  • The protrusion of a Meckel diverticulum through a possible abdominal orifice is referred to as a Littre hernia.

Option C - Pantaloon hernia:

  • A pantaloon hernia, also known as a "Saddlebag" hernia, is defined as any combination of two contiguous femoral or inguinal hernia sacs on the same side .

questions.text: The first-line drug of choice in acute pulmonary edema secondary to heart failure
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Furosemide:

  • Initial drug for acute heart failure due to potent diuretic effect.
  • Rapidly reduces fluid retention by inhibiting sodium and chloride reabsorption in the ascending loop of Henle.
  • Relieves symptoms of dyspnea and edema, improves hemodynamics and cardiac function.
  • Acts as a venodilator, reducing preload.
  • Fast onset of action and intravenous administration make it suitable for acute management.

 Incorrect Options:

Option A - Dobutamine:

  • Direct sympathomimetic drug, increases cardiac output.
  • Used in heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF), but furosemide remains important for fluid management.

Option C - Metoprolol:

  • Beta-receptor antagonist, not typically used during acute heart failure due to potential reduction in contractility.

Option D - Digoxin:

  • Positive inotrope, not routinely used in acute heart failure.
  • Furosemide remains primary for managing pulmonary edema and heart failu

questions.text: Which of the following indices can be used to differentiate between microcytic, normocytic, and macrocytic anemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Mean corpuscular volume:

  • MCV can be used to determine if anemia is microcytic, normocytic or macrocytic.

Anemia is divided into three types based on MCV:

  • Microcytic anemia, normocytic anemia and macrocytic anemia.
  • If MCV is less than 80 fL, it is called microcytic anemia.
  • If MCV is between 80 and 100 fL, it is called Normocytic anemia.
  • If the MCV is more than 100 fL, it is a macrocytic anemic.
  • Normocytic is further classified into hemolytic and non-hemolytic anemias, while hemolytic anemia is further divided into extravascular hemolysis or intravascular hemolysis.
  • Macrocytic anemia is divided into megaloblastic and non-megaloblastic anemia.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B and C are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: A 28-year-old girl presented with acute left facial palsy, tear secretion disturbance in the ipsilateral eye, and left-sided conductive hypoacusia. Imaging revealed an extradural mass in the left middle fossa. A subtemporal approach was performed, and the lesion, originating from the proximal portion of the first branch of the facial nerve, was excised. Post-operative xerophthalmia was treated with artificial teardrops. Which nerve was operated upon?
questions.solution:
Correct Option  B - Greater petrosal nerve :

  • Greater petrosal nerve is the first branch of the facial nerve which arises from the geniculate ganglion. It innervates the lacrimal glands and mucosal glands of the nasal cavity. Any pathological lesions in the GSPN may result in facial nerve palsy, hearing disturbances, dry eyes (Xerophthalmia), headaches, and diplopia.
  • Also called superficial petrosal nerve
  • Branch of nervus intermedius

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Auriculo-temporal nerve:

  • The auriculo-temporal nerve carries parasympathetic secretomotor fibers to the parotid gland.

Option C - Lingual nerve:

  • Lingual nerve supplies sensation to the floor of the mouth and forward two-thirds of the tongue
  • The lingual nerve is not involved in lacrimation.

Option D - Chorda tympani:

  • Chorda tympani nerve carries secretomotor fibres to sublingual and submandibular glands

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents to the eye clinic complaining of redness, discharge, and a foreign body sensation in her left eye. On examination, the presence of a membrane adherent to the conjunctival surface is noted which bleeds on peeling. Which of the following organisms is most commonly associated with this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Corynebacterium diphtheriae:

  • The clinical picture of redness, discharge, and membrane which bleeds on peeling is suggestive of membranous conjunctivitis. 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Moraxella Axenfeld: Moraxella is a bacterium that can cause conjunctivitis, but it is not commonly associated with the formation of membranes on the conjunctival surface. It typically presents as conjunctivitis with excoriation of the skin (Angluar Conjunctivitis).

Option B - Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus can cause bacterial conjunctivitis, but it is not commonly associated with membranous conjunctivitis. 

Option D - Streptococcus pneumoniae: Streptococcus pneumoniae can cause conjunctivitis, but it is not commonly associated with the formation of membranes on the conjunctival surface. It typically presents with acute bacterial conjunctivitis usually associated with petechial subconjunctival hemorrhages i.e., hemorrhagic conjunctivitis.

questions.text:
Match the following:


	
		
			
			Causative pathogen Vector
			
			
			Incubation period
			
		
		
			
			1. Plasmodium falciparum
			
			
			a.16 to 18 days
			
		
		
			
			2. Plasmodium ovale
			
			
			b. 8 to 17 days
			
		
		
			
			3. Plasmodium malariae
			
			
			c.9 to 14 days
			
		
		
			
			4. Plasmodium vivax
			
			
			d.18-40 days
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 1-c, 2-a, 3-d, 4-b:

  • The incubation period of P. falciparum is 9 to 14 days
  • The incubation period of P. ovale is 16 to 18 days
  • The Incubation period of P. malariae is 18-40 days
  • The incubation period of P. vivax is 8 to 17 days

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, D:

  • These options reflect incorrect matching between the pathogen and incubation period.

questions.text: A 55-yar-old male known case of hepatitis C and chronic liver disease came to the emergency department with complaints of 3 episodes of hematemesis and an altered level of consciousness. Upon arriving, the patient was given terlipressin and managed for oesophagal bleeding. Which of the following vasculitis is associated with hepatitis C infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Cryoglobulinemia:

  • Cryoglobulins are proteins that precipitate  when temperatures fall below 37°C.
  • They can be just immunoglobulins (Ig) or a combination of immunoglobulin (Ig) and complement elements.
  • Cryoglobulinemia, which is caused by the accumulation of these cryoglobulins in the body's medium- and large-sized blood arteries, damages endothelial cells and internal organs.
  • Patients who present with skin ulcers, arthralgia, glomerulonephritis, neuropathy, and purpura should have this entity suspected as a diagnosis.
  • Small amounts of cryoglobulin are typically found in healthy persons.
  • As 90% of occurrences of cryoglobulinemic vasculitis are linked to Hepatitis C infections, drug use is the main risk factor for the condition.
  • Blood vessel inflammation is brought on by the immune complex formation and complement activation by producing hepatitis C IgG and IgM rheumatoid factor.
  • Hepatitis C most frequently causes mixed cryoglobulinemia.
  • During the management of cryoglobulinemia, hepatitis C should be evaluated.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Takayasu’s arteritis:

  • Takayasu arteritis, also known as pulseless disease, is a chronic inflammatory illness that damages the medium and large arteries and their branches.
  • It primarily affects girls and women younger than 40.
  • It is not associated with hepatitis.

Option B - Churg-Strauss syndrome:

  • Churg-Strauss syndrome is a small vessel vasculitis characterised by granulomatous inflammation.
  • It is associated with asthma.

Option D - Microscopic polyangiitis:

  • Microscopic polyangiitis is an idiopathic autoimmune illness characterised by systemic vasculitis affecting primarily small-calibre blood vessels and is related to developing anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic autoantibodies (ANCA).
  • The disease is said to be associated with pulmonary fibrosis.

questions.text: In a newborn, a condition is observed where the bladder protrudes through the abdominal wall, causing the mucosa to be exposed. A downward displacement of the umbilicus separated pubic rami in the midline and separation of the rectus muscles is also observed. Which of the following is a consequence of this condition?
questions.solution:
Çorrect Option A - Total urinary incontinence:

  • The given scenario described the presentation of bladder exstrophy.

Clinical features

  • Urinary Bladder protrudes from the Anterior abdominal wall and its mucosa is exposed
  • Umbilicus displaced downwards
  • Pubic rami widely separated
  • Rectus Muscles separated
  • In males -Complete Epispadias, undescended testes, and inguinal hernia common
  • Anus displaced anteriorly and/or Rectal prolapse (both males and females)

Consequence

  • Total urinary incontinence
  • Increased Risk for bladder adenocarcinoma

Treatment

  • Cover the defect with plastic wrap to keep the Mucosa moist
  • Surgery

Incorrect Options

Option B - Hematuria

Option C - Infections

Option D - Oliguria

  • These are not the consequences of Bladder exstrophy

questions.text: A student was asked to prepare a seminar on the characteristics of different mosquitoes. During the seminar presentation, the professor asked the students about the flight range of different mosquitoes. Which among the following mosquitoes have a flight range of 11-13 km?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Culex:

  • The flight range of mosquitoes can vary depending on factors such as species, environmental conditions, and availability of hosts.  
  • The Culex mosquito, which transmits  Japanese encephalitis virus and West Nile virus, has a flight range of 11-13 km.
  • Some species, like Aedes aegypti, which is known for transmitting diseases such as dengue fever, Zika virus, and chikungunya, have been observed to have shorter flight ranges, usually staying within a few hundred meters of their breeding sites.
  • It is important to note that while mosquitoes may have a certain flight range, they are also opportunistic and will seek out hosts (such as humans or animals) for blood meals within their flight range. 
  • Additionally, factors such as wind speed and direction can affect the dispersal of mosquitoes over longer distances.

Incorrect Options:

Options B - Aedes: These mosquitoes have a short flight range of 100-200 meters.

Option C - Anopheles These mosquitoes have a long flight range of 2-3 km.

Option D - Mansonia: These mosquitoes have a long flight range of 2-3 km.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man presents to the physician with complaints of worsening hypogastric discomfort 32 hours after undergoing a hernioplasty under spinal anaesthesia. He complains that he has not urinated since the operation. He gives no history of any other abnormalities. He is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. On the abdominal examination of the patient, there is a palpable bladder 4 cm above the symphysis pubis. He is treated with bethanechol, which directly increases detrusor muscle tone. The patient is at increased risk for which of the following adverse effects of the drug involved in this case?
questions.solution:
Option C: Bradycardia

  • This is a case of urinary retention
  • In the above-mentioned adverse effects, parasympathomimetic drugs can cause bradycardia.
  • Outcomes that are seen with cholinergic muscarinic receptor stimulation are:

Heart

Bradycardia or even cardiac arrest

Blood vessels

Fall in B.P. and flushing occurs

Bronchus

Bronchospasm

GIT

Diarrhoea

Bladder

↑ urine outflow

Glands

↑ secretions

Eye

Miosis

Option A: Constipation

  • Cholinergic muscarinic receptor agonist drugs do not result in constipation.
  • It usually causes diarrhoea.
  • The stimulation of muscarinic receptors can cause diarrhoea.

Option B: Rise in blood pressure

  • Parasympathomimetic drugs do not result in a rise in blood pressure.
  • It usually causes hypotension and flushing.
  • It also causes bradycardia and even cardiac arrest.

Option D: Oliguria

  • Oliguria means meagre urine output.
  • Cholinergic muscarinic receptor stimulation causes increased urine output.
  • Parasympathomimetic drugs increase the secretions of all the glands of the body

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with a brownish-black, non-scaly macule on the palm of his hand. The lesion has been gradually increasing in size over the past few months. On microscopic examination, fungal elements are observed. What is the most likely causative organism responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D- Exophiala werneckii/ Hortaea wernickii:

  • The clinical presentation described is characteristic of Tinea nigra, a superficial fungal infection of the skin. The most common causative organism associated with Tinea nigra is Exophiala werneckii, a pigmented fungus. It typically presents as a well-defined brownish-black or dark brown macule, often on the palms or soles. The lesion is non-scaly and slowly enlarges over time. KOH and microscopic examination: Brown hyphae with light brown septa, confirming the diagnosis of Tinea nigra.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Microsporum canis: Microsporum canis is a dermatophyte fungus that commonly causes Tinea capitis (scalp infection) and occasionally Tinea corporis. It does not cause Tinea nigra.

Option B - Epidermophyton floccosum: Epidermophyton floccosum is another dermatophyte fungus that causes various types of dermatophyte infections. However, it is not associated with Tinea nigra. It commonly causes infections like Tinea cruris (jock itch) and Tinea corporis (ringworm).

Option C - Malassezia furfur: Malassezia furfur is the causative organism of Pityriasis versicolor, which presents as scaly patches with variable pigmentation. It is not associated with Tinea nigra.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the clinic for a regular checkup. Over the past year, he has been having migraine headaches affecting his work schedule. Family history is positive for familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP). His father suffered from myocardial infarction (MI) at age 45 and now has the peripheral arterial disease (PAD). The patient's BMI is 29.5 kg/m2. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), his pulse is 83/min, his respirations are 20/min, and his blood pressure is 125/80 mmHg. An examination does not reveal any abnormality. The physician decides to prescribe celecoxib to the patient. Which of the following set of pathologies will be addressed by adding this medication?
questions.solution:
Option B: Migraine and FAP

  • Celecoxib reversibly and selectively inhibits the cyclooxygenase (COX) isoform 2.
  • It is used to treat migraines with and without aura acutely.
  • Selective COX-2 inhibitors have also been used to prevent the risk of colon cancer in patients with familial adenomatous polyposis coli (FAP).
  • It does not have any role in managing myocardial infarction (MI) or peripheral artery disease (PAD) because they lack the cardioprotective properties of aspirin. In fact use of celecoxib is limited due to increased of cardiovascular disease
  • Side effects include:
    • An increased risk of thrombosis
    • Sulfa allergy.

Option A: Migraine and PAD

  • Aspirin can be used for managing both migraine and PAD.
  • However Celecoxib is not used for treating PAD.

Option C: MI and FAP

  • Celecoxib does not have any role in treating MI.
  • Aspirin has a role in treating both MI and FAP.

Option D: MI and PAD

  • Aspirin is an option for managing both MI and PAD.
  • Celecoxib does not play any role in treating both of these conditions

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with a history of ischemic heart disease presents to the emergency with left-sided chest pain, low blood pressure, and dyspnea for the last 1 hour. His O2 concentrations of mixed venous and arterial blood are 16 and 20 ml/min, respectively. The O2 consumption is 300 ml/min. According to Fick’s principle, what is cardiac output in liters/min?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 7.5:

  • The formula for cardiac output is :

CO = cardiac output 

VO2 = oxygen consumption in ml of pure gaseous oxygen per minute 

Ca = oxygen content of arterial blood

Cv = oxygen content of mixed venous blood

  • Given values are:
    • Oxygen consumption → 300 ml/min.
    • Arterial O2 → 20 ml.
    • Venous O2 → 16 ml.
  • Cardiac output, in this case, after putting the values in the formula, is 7.5 liters/min.
  • The patient is a known case of ischemic heart disease. Based on the symptoms of left-sided chest pain, low blood pressure, and dyspnea, he is most likely suffering from myocardial infarction.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and C: Refers to option D explanation.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman, G2P1, presents at 40 weeks gestation with active labor pain for 4 hours. Vaginal examination reveals the cervix is dilated 6 cm and 70% effaced. The fetal head is felt at -1 station. There is a presence of anterior fontanelle and a supra-orbital ridge over the fetal head. What is the most likely diameter of the fetal skull that would have engaged in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A:

  • Palpation of the anterior fontanelle and supra-orbital ridge on the fetal head vaginally is suggestive of brow presentation.
  • The engaging diameter of the Brow presentation is mentovertical - 14 cm

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Submento-vertical is seen in incomplete extension, face presentation.

Option C: Suboccipito-frontal is engaged in deflexed head

Option D: Suboccipito-bregmatic is engaged in complete flexion.

questions.text: The fingerprint pattern showing two or more delta is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Whorls:

  • The fingerprint pattern showing two or more delta is Whorls.
  • Whorl: 25-35% of fingerprint patterns are whorls. Whorls have at least two deltas and a core. Any fingerprint pattern that contains equal or more than 2 deltas will be a whorl pattern.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Loop:

  • Loop: 60-70% of fingerprint patterns are loops. These are the most common fingerprint pattern.
  • Loops pattern must have one delta and one core.

Option B - Plain arch:

  • A fingerprint pattern in which the ridges enter on one side of the impression and flow or tend to flow out the other side with arise or wave in the center.

Option C - Tented arch:

  • The tented arch and the arch comprise about 5% of fingerprint patterns found on the human fingertips and thumbs. The tented arch has a ‘tent pole’ thrusting up from the mound at the base in the middle of the print.

questions.text: What method is most appropriate for detecting antigens related to the infection in a throat swab sample from a patient with persistent sore throat, fever, and malaise?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C- ELISA: ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay) is a highly sensitive and specific technique used to detect the presence of antigens or antibodies in a patient's sample. In this case, the patient's symptoms of sore throat, fever, and malaise could be either viral or bacterial. ELISA can reliably detect multiple types of pathogens quickly.

Incorrect Options:

Option A-Cell culture on Hela cells: Cell culture on Hela cells is not the best option for detecting antigens; it is more commonly used to culture and isolate viruses. Cell culture can be time-consuming and may not be as sensitive as other methods.

Option B-Complement fixation test: Complement fixation test measures the ability of patient serum to fix complement in the presence of a specific antigen. Complement fixation tests are less commonly used today due to their lower sensitivity and specificity compared to modern techniques like ELISA.  

Option D- Staining with Wright's stain: Staining with Wright's stain is a microscopy-based method, which may help visualize cells and bacteria (Klebsiella granulomatis and Histoplasma capsulatam) but is not specific to detecting antigens.

questions.text: All of the following developmental events depend on the production of maternal or fetal glucocorticoids EXCEPT?

choices.text: Production of surfactant by type II alveolar cells

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Induction of thymic involution:

  • Thymic involution is not dependent on maternal or fetal glucocorticoids. It occurs after birth during childhood and involves processes unrelated to glucocorticoid production.

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C and D:

  • Production of surfactant by type II alveolar cells, functional thyroid development, and the functional hypothalamic-pituitary axis are all dependent on maternal or fetal glucocorticoids. Glucocorticoids play crucial roles in the synthesis and maturation of surfactants, the development of the fetal thyroid, and the functional regulation of the hypothalamic-pituitary axis in the fetus.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases shows a cyclical trend?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Influenza:

  • Influenza shows a cyclical trend repeating every 7-20 years.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Malaria: Malaria shows a seasonal trend.

Option C - Hay fever: Hay fever shows a seasonal trend.

Option D - Pneumonia: It shows a seasonal trend.

questions.text: A primigravida at 41 weeks presents with premature rupture of membranes. Per vaginal examination revealed that the cervix is dilated 3 cm, and the foot of the fetus can be felt. The fetus's estimated weight is about 2.7 kg, and the fetal heart rate tracing is reactive. Which of the following is the most appropriate method to complete this delivery?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Perform an emergency cesarean section

  • This is a Footling breech presentation. There is a high risk of cord prolapse and hence footling breech presentations should undergo delivery by cesarean section.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Vaginally by breech extraction

Frank and complete breech are delivered vaginally. Breech Extraction implies a part or the entire body of the fetus is extracted by the obstetrician. 

Option B: Vaginally after external cephalic version

ECV is not done in labor. It is done electively at around 36 weeks to convert breech to cephalic.

Option D: Internal podalic version

Internal podalic version is done for the second twin in a transverse lie to convert to breech.

questions.text: A primigravida presents at 37 weeks in labor. Her antenatal ultrasound suggests accessory placental tissue seen separate from the main placental mass. Which complication of third-stage labor is more common with such a presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D

  • The given history is suggestive of the succenturiate lobe of the placenta, a condition in which one or more accessory lobes present apart from the main placental body.

  • The succenturiate lobe of the placenta is a risk factor for retained placenta, as the additional lobe may not be delivered along with the main placenta.
  • Retained placenta can result in postpartum hemorrhage and other complications, making it important to be aware of risk factors such as the presence of a succenturiate lobe.

Incorrect Options:

Option A :

  • Cord avulsion, also known as cord traction, refers to the accidental tearing of the umbilical cord during the delivery of the placenta. While it can occur in various situations, accessory placental tissue is not directly associated with an increased risk of cord avulsion.

Option B : 

  • Uterine inversion is a rare but serious complication where the uterus turns inside out after delivery. The presence of accessory placental tissue is not a recognized risk factor for uterine inversion.

Option C:

  • Chorioamnionitis is an infection of the fetal membranes and amniotic fluid. It is not directly related to accessory placental tissue but can occur due to prolonged labor, prolonged rupture of membranes, or other factors that increase the risk of ascending infection.

questions.text: In a primary health center, a female health worker is tasked with various responsibilities to improve the health outcomes of the community. She diligently performs her duties, but certain tasks are outside the scope of her duties. Which among the following is not a job responsibility of a female health worker?

choices.text: Maintains a special register called the eligible couples register

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Collect sputum samples:

  • Collecting sputum samples is typically not within the scope of responsibilities of a Health Worker Female.
  • Under the Revised National TB Control program, it is the duty of a Health Worker Male to identify persons 15 years and above, with prolonged cough or spitting of blood, and take sputum smears from these individuals.
  • The duties of health worker female are:
    • Conducts deliveries.
    • Maintains special register - Eligible couples register.
    • Identifies high-risk pregnancies and referrals
    • Performs hemoglobin and urine testing.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Maintains a special register called the eligible couples register:

  • Female health workers often maintain registers related to family planning and reproductive health services, including the eligible couples register.
  • This register helps monitor and provide necessary interventions for family planning services.
  • Thus, it is indeed a job responsibility of a female health worker.

Option B - Identifies high-risk pregnancies and referrals:

  • Identifying high-risk pregnancies is crucial for ensuring timely interventions and reducing maternal and neonatal mortality rates.
  • Female health workers, being the frontline healthcare providers in many settings, are trained to recognize signs of high-risk pregnancies and refer them to higher-level healthcare facilities for specialized care.
  • Therefore, this is a legitimate job responsibility of a female health worker.

Option C - Performs hemoglobin and urine testing:

  • Female health workers often conduct basic diagnostic tests such as hemoglobin and urine testing as part of their routine health assessments.
  • These tests help identify conditions such as anemia and urinary tract infections, which are prevalent in many communities.
  • Performing these tests allows for early detection and management of health issues, making it an integral part of a female health worker's responsibilities.

questions.text: Which of the following studies is used for determining the prevalence of a disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Cross-sectional study:

  • A cross-sectional study is used to determine the prevalence of a disease or condition within a population at a specific point in time.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ecological study: Ecological studies compare exposure and frequency of disease across populations but do not directly measure disease prevalence.

Option B - Cohort study: Cohort studies are better suited for assessing incidence over time.

Option C - Case-control studies: Case-control studies examine associations between exposure and outcome but do not estimate disease prevalence in a population.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the activity of naturally occurring human estrogens. He studies the relative blood levels, activity, and strength of binding to estrogen receptors for estrone, estradiol, and estriol by injecting each subcutaneously in mice. Which of the following is expected to cause maximum estrogenic effects and side effects in mice when equal amounts of each type are used?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B: Estradiol (E2)

  • The question asked is about the potency of estrogens. The 3 naturally occurring estrogens in women are estriol (E3), estrone (E1), and estradiol (E2).
  • Estradiol is the dominant estrogen during reproductive years both in terms of absolute serum levels as well as in terms of estrogenic activity.
  • After menopause, estrone is the predominant circulating estrogen.
  • Estriol is the dominant circulating estrogen in terms of serum levels during pregnancy.
  • Although estriol is the most abundant of the 3 estrogens, it is also the weakest, whereas estradiol is the most potent, with a potency of approximately 75 to 80 times that of estriol.
  • Thus, estradiol is the most important estrogen in non-pregnant females between the menarche and menopause stages of life.
  • However, during pregnancy, this role shifts to estriol, and in postmenopausal women, estrone becomes the primary form of estrogen in the body.

Incorrect Option:

Option A: Estrone (E1).

  • Estrone is the 2nd most potent estrogen.
  • Estradiol (E2) is the most potent, followed by estrone (E1), and estriol (E3) is the least potent.

Option C: Estriol (E3)

  • Estriol is the least potent estrogen.

Option D: Equal for all

  • The potency is not equal for all.

questions.text: What's the recommended treatment for a 38-year-old woman with a recurrent, painful mass under her left breast's areola, occasional discharge, a history of 15 years of chewing tobacco, examination revealing well-defined, erythematous nodules with draining sinuses and the given biopsy findings?

choices.text: Antibiotics like cephalexin, clindamycin, or co-trimoxazole

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - En Bloc surgical removal:

  • The images show the histology of a lactiferous duct: This lactiferous duct has been almost completely replaced by squamous epithelium. There is only a small area with glandular epithelial cells. Closer view of a duct space with normal ductal epithelium and the lumen filled with keratin from SMOLD involving this duct upstream (magnification 10x).
  • Given the clinical presentation and histological findings described, the recommended mode of treatment would be consistent with managing a condition known as squamous metaplasia of lactiferous ducts (SMOLD).
  • In most cases of squamous metaplasia of the lactiferous duct, En Bloc surgical removal of the involved duct and contagious fistula tract is curative.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A -  Easily treated with antibiotics like cephalexin, clindamycin, or co-trimoxazole:

  • This would be an appropriate treatment if the diagnosis was Acute mastitis caused by Staphylococcus. In the case of SMOLD antibiotics only have a therapeutic role if there is evidence of secondary bacterial infection.

Option B - Simple incision and drainage:

  • In a SMOLD, a simple incision drains the abscess cavity, but the offending keratinizing epithelium remains and recurrences tend to become common.

Option D - Antibiotic and steroid therapy is required:

  • Steroid therapy would be an appropriate mode of treatment for granulomatous mastitis in a person with an underlying autoimmune condition such as sarcoidosis. Otherwise, antibiotic+steroid therapy would not be a treatment of choice in SMOLD.

questions.text: In a patient presenting with Horner's syndrome, which substance is commonly utilized to differentiate between preganglionic and postganglionic lesions causing constriction of the pupil on clinical examination during a diagnostic workup?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – 10% Hydroxyapmhetamine:

  • 10% Hydroxyamphetamine is used to differentiate between preganglionic and postganglionic lesions in Horner's syndrome. If the lesion is preganglionic, there will be dilation of the affected pupil in response to 10% hydroxyamphetamine. If the lesion is postganglionic, the pupil will not dilate.
  • For diagnosing Horner's, 4% cocaine is given to the pupil
    • If the pupil dilates, it is normal.
    • If no dilation is seen, it is Horner's.
    • This is because cocaine blocks the reuptake of noradrenaline (NA).
  • Now use 10% Hydroxy amphetamine.
    • If the pupil dilates, it is preganglionic.
    • If not, it is postganglionic.
      • To check again, a very low concentration of adrenaline is used. If it responds to that, it is a postganglionic lesion

Incorrect Options:
Option A – 0.125% pilocarpine:

  • 0.125% pilocarpine is used to diagnose Adie’s pupil. If the pupil constricts on the instillation of the 0.125% pilocarpine it is Adie’s pupil.

Option B – 4% Cocaine:

  • 4% Cocaine is used in the cocaine test to diagnose Horner's syndrome. If the pupil dilates on application of the 4% cocaine, then he is diagnosed with Horner’s syndrome, which works by blocking the reuptake of norepinephrine. But it does not tell the location of the lesion.

Option D – None of the above: Incorrect Option

questions.text: Which gene is most likely mutated in a 35-year-old man with diffuse gastric thickening, signet-ring cell infiltration on microscopic examination, and a family history of early-onset gastric carcinoma in his father?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - CDH1:

  • This patient with familial gastric cancer most likely has a mutation in CDH1, the gene encoding the cellular adhesion protein E-cadherin.
  • E-cadherin mutations account for a significant proportion of familial gastric cancers and Lobular carcinoma of the breast.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - APC:

  • APC is mutated in the majority of colorectal adenocarcinomas and intestinal types of gastric cancer.

Option C -PMS2:

  • MSH2 and PMS2 are both mismatch repair genes that are mutated in Lynch syndrome.

Option D - p53:

  • p53 is mutated in Li Fraumeni syndrome.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female patient with a history of Grave's disease presents with symptoms of hyperthyroidism, including palpitations and weight loss. She is started on saturated solution of potassium iodide (SSKI) for 10 days as part of her treatment plan. Which of the following effects is likely to be observed during this treatment?

choices.text: Surge of T3 and T4 levels

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Decrease in thyroid gland size:

  • SSKI (saturated solution of potassium iodide) administration for 10 days causes a decrease in thyroid gland size.
  • This is because SSKI leads to the Wolff-Chaikoff effect, which occurs due to a temporary decrease in iodine trapping by the thyroid gland.
  • The Wolff-Chaikoff effect essentially prevents further formation of thyroid hormone by inhibiting the organification of iodine and hence decreases T4 and T3 levels.
  • So, in this case, the patient's symptoms of hyperthyroidism, such as palpitations and weight loss, should improve as the thyroid gland shrinks and the excess production of T3 and T4 decreases.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Surge of T3 and T4 levels: This is incorrect. SSKI actually leads to a decrease in T3 and T4 levels due to the Wolff-Chaikoff effect.

Option B - Increased iodine trapping: This is incorrect. SSKI causes a decrease in iodine trapping, which is part of the Wolff-Chaikoff effect.

Option D - deactivation of the Wolff-Chaikoff effect: SSKI activates the Wolff-Chaikoff effect, which decreases thyroid hormone production.

questions.text: A 36-year old female patient is evaluated for gram negative septicemia. The patient’s medical records reveals that she has earlier experienced an episode of anaphylaxis leading to shock after the administration of penicillin V. Which of the following drugs can be used in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Aztreonam:

  • In patients allergic to Penicillin, most beta-lactams are risky, except for monobactams and certain 3rd/4th generation cephalosporins. Monobactams lack the thiazole ring of beta-lactams, making them safe alternatives.
  • Aztreonam and imipenem are effective for gram-negative infections. However, as the patient is allergic to beta-lactams, carbapenems show cross allergy and are contraindicated in people with beta-lactam allergy. So Aztreonam is preferred in such a patient.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ampicillin plus sulbactam:

  • Ampicillin is a beta-lactam which can cause life-threatening anaphylaxis again in this patient, so it is contraindicated

Option C - Cefazolin:

  • Cefazolin is a first generation cephalosporin and is a beta-lactam, so it cannot be administered to this patient with evidence of beta-lactam allergic reaction

Option D - Imipenem plus cilastatin:

  • Imipenem is a carbapenem, and carbapenems have shown cross-allergy in patients with a beta-lactam allergy, so it is also contraindicated in this case

questions.text: Below are images showing various clinical tests. Identify them and mark the correct option having the names of the tests for assessing ACL injury.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 1, 2, 3:

  • 1 - Lachman test

    • Lachman Test

      • Patient in the supine position.
      • Knee flexed to 30°
      • The examiner places one hand behind the tibia with the thumb on the tibial tuberosity.
      • More than 2mm of anterior translation associated with a 'soft end feel' is considered positive.
      • Lachman test - More reliable, More sensitive than Anterior Drawers Test. 

    • Superior to Anterior Drawers Test

      • Less hurtful to the patient.
      • No doorstep phenomenon.
      • Gold standard physical test.
  • 2 - Anterior drawer test

    • Anterior Drawer Test

      • Patient in the supine position.
      • Hip flexed to 45°, Knee flexed to 90°
      • Examiner sits on the patient's feet.
      • Thumb of both hands on the tibial tuberosity.
      • This test is considered positive if there is a 'soft end feel.'
      • Less accurate than Lachman Test
      • Associated medial meniscus injury.
      • The doorstep phenomenon is present in ACL injury associated with the posterior horn of medial meniscal tear injury.
  • 3 - Pivot shift test

    • Pivot Shift Test-

      • Pivot Shift Test is a special test used to diagnose the rotatory instability related to injury of the ACL of the knee.
      • The patient is supine.
      • The examiner grasps and immobilizes the lateral femoral condyle with one hand and palpates the proximal tibia or fibula with the thumb.
      • Conversely, the examiner holds the patient's lower leg in internal rotation and abduction (valgus stress).
      • From this starting position, the knee is then moved from extension into flexion.
      • In the presence of a torn anterior cruciate ligament, the valgus stress will cause the tibia to subluxate anteriorly while the knee is still in extension.

Incorrect Options: Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

  • 4 - Godfrey sign in posterior drawer test is done is PCL injury

    • Godfrey sign

      • This is otherwise called the Gravity Sign or Sag Sign.
      • When viewed from the side, there is an abnormal posterior translation of the Tibia, accentuated by the hamstrings' contraction.
  • 5 - Apley’s grinding test done in meniscus injury

    • Apley's Grinding Test

      • Step I - Patient in a prone position with knee flexed to 90°.
      • Step II - The patient's thigh is fixed to the examination table with the examiner's knee.
      • Step III - The examiner medially & laterally rotates the Tibia combined with distraction. If there is
      • pain associated with excessive rotations; it is a ligamentous injury.
      • Step IV - The examiner medially & laterally rotates the Tibia combined with compression. If there is
      • pain associated with the restriction of rotations; it is a meniscal injury.
      • Apley's Grinding Test has 87% specificity & 97% sensitivity.
  • 6 - Mcmurray’s test in meniscus injury

    • McMurray Test

      • Step-I: The patient is in the supine position. The examiner holds the knee and palpates the joint line. The other hand holds the sole.
      • Step II: He is kept in full flexion.
      • Step III: The examiner applies valgus stress to the knee. With the other hand, the foot & leg are externally rotated.
      • Step IV: The knee is gradually extended.
      • Step-V: Audible click & pain denotes medial meniscal tear.

questions.text: Which hormones counteract the nitric oxide effect and make the penis flaccid after orgasm?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Endothelin and Norepinephrine:

  • Endothelin and norepinephrine counteract the effects of nitric oxide and contribute to penile detumescence after orgasm.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Estrogen and Progesterone: Estrogen and progesterone are female sex hormones and do not play a role in penile erection or detumescence.

Option C - LH and FSH: LH and FSH are involved in spermatogenesis but do not directly affect penile erection or detumescence.

Option D - Progesterone and LH: Progesterone and LH do not play a role in penile erection or detumescence. LH acts on the ovaries to stimulate ovulation and progesterone production.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct about Methotrexate?

choices.text: It is a cell cycle non-specific and kills cells in all phase
Its toxicity primarily affects the bone marrow and epithelial structures
Folic acid reverses its toxic effects
It is the drug of choice for dermoid cysts

questions.solution:
Option B: Its toxicity primarily affects the bone marrow and epithelial structures

  • Methotrexate is an antimetabolite that inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, an enzyme essential for synthesizing purines and pyrimidines.
  • Methotrexate (MTX) toxicity predominantly impacts the bone marrow and epithelial structures, leading to significant adverse effects.
  • As an antimetabolite chemotherapy agent, MTX disrupts DNA and RNA synthesis, particularly affecting rapidly dividing cells.
  • In the bone marrow, it can cause myelosuppression, resulting in decreased production of blood cells and increasing the risk of anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia.
  • Additionally, MTX toxicity affects epithelial tissues, leading to mucositis, dermatologic reactions, and gastrointestinal disturbances.
  • Monitoring for these toxicities and managing them promptly are crucial aspects of MTX therapy to optimize treatment outcomes and minimize patient morbidity.

Option A: It is a cell cycle non-specific and kills cells in all phase

  • Methotrexate is an antimetabolite that inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, an enzyme essential for synthesizing purines and pyrimidines.
  • Methotrexate is a cell cycle-specific drug that kills the cells only in the S phase.

Option C: Folic acid reverses its toxic effects

  • Folinic acid (leucovorin) is used to reverse the adverse effect of Methotrexate.
  • Folic acid is ineffective.

Option D: It is the drug of choice for dermoid cyst

  • Dermoid cyst is a benign tumor. Due to high risk of torsion, cystectomy is used as a management strategy
  • Methotrexate is a drug of choice for choriocarcinoma.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to a rural health center complaining of fever, chills, and sweating for the past 3 days. On examination, he has a temperature of 39.5°C, with no other significant findings. A rapid diagnostic test for malaria is performed. When were the rapid diagnostic kits for malaria introduced?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 2005: 

  • The introduction of rapid diagnostic kits for malaria in 2005 improved the diagnosis and management of malaria cases, especially in resource-limited settings where access to laboratory facilities and skilled personnel for microscopy may be limited.
  • These kits provide quick results, facilitating prompt initiation of appropriate treatment and reducing the burden of malaria-related morbidity and mortality.
  • However, when a patient in or from a malarious area presents with fever, thick and thin blood smears should be prepared and examined immediately to confirm the diagnosis and identify the species of the infecting parasite.
  • If reliable microscopy is unavailable, a rapid test should be performed.
  • Molecular diagnosis with PCR amplification of parasite nucleic acid is more sensitive than microscopy or rapid diagnostic tests but is impractical in standard clinical settings.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 2002: Rapid diagnostic kits for malaria were not introduced in 2002. During this time, diagnosis of malaria primarily relied on microscopic examination of blood smears for malaria parasites.

Option B - 2004: Rapid diagnostic kits for malaria were not introduced in 2004.

Option D - 2006: By 2006, rapid diagnostic kits for malaria were already in use. Waiting until 2006 for their introduction would have meant delaying the adoption of this important diagnostic tool, which was available earlier.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with COPD presents to the ED with a week of worsening dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, and productive cough with yellowish sputum. Examination reveals decreased breath sounds on the right side and dullness on percussion over the lower lung fields. What is the most sensitive X-ray view for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Lateral Decubitus:

  • In this case, the patient's symptoms and examination findings suggest a potential pleural effusion, which is an abnormal accumulation of fluid in the pleural space. The lateral decubitus view is the most sensitive X-ray for detecting pleural effusion.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - PA view:

  • The PA (Posteroanterior) view is a standard chest X-ray, but it is not as sensitive for detecting pleural effusions as the lateral decubitus view.

Option B - Lateral view:

  • The lateral view provides a side perspective of the chest and is valuable for assessing structures within the mediastinum. However, it is not as sensitive as the lateral decubitus view for detecting pleural effusions.

Option C - AP view:

  • The AP (Anteroposterior) view is taken with the patient facing the X-ray tube. While it is commonly used, especially when a PA view is not feasible, it may not be as sensitive as the lateral decubitus view for detecting pleural effusions.

questions.text: An 55-year-old man with a history of diabetes mellitus presents with right shoulder pain and limited range of motion. Physical examination indicates adhesive capsulitis. Which muscle is responsible for the abduction of the arm from 0° to 15°?
questions.solution:
Option D: Supraspinatus

  • Abduction of the arm is the movement of the arm away from the body within the plane of the torso.
  • The supraspinatus, deltoid, trapezius and serratus anterior are involved in the action of arm abduction.
  • Supraspinatus originates from the supraspinous fossa of the scapula and inserts at the greater tubercle of the humerus.
  • It is innervated by the suprascapular nerve.
  • It is responsible for 0°–15° abduction of the arm.

Option A: Trapezius

  • The trapezius is supplied by the accessory nerve.
  • It is responsible for > 90° abduction of the arm.

Option B: Deltoid

  • The deltoid is supplied by the axillary nerve.
  • It is responsible for 15°–90° abduction of the arm.

Option C: Serratus anterior

  • Serratus anterior is supplied by the long thoracic nerve.
  • It is responsible for > 90° abduction of the arm.

questions.text: A G3P2L2, 29-year-old woman presents with a history of positive pregnancy test. Her Last period was 6 weeks ago. ultrasound scan shows severe fetal anomalies. what is the maximum gestational age limit within which a medical termination of pregnancy can be legally performed?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option 2: 24 weeks

  • The Medical Termination of Pregnancy (Amendment) Bill, 2021, passed by the Rajya Sabha, increases the upper gestation limit for special categories of women from 20 to 24 weeks.
  • This means that for women like the one described in the scenario, who do not desire the pregnancy and are within 24 weeks of gestation, a medical termination of pregnancy can be legally performed under the Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act in India.

Incorrect Options:

Option 1: 20 weeks

  • This option was correct before the amendment. However, with the passing of the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (Amendment) Bill, 2021, the upper gestational limit has been extended to 24 weeks for special categories of women.

Option 3: 12 weeks

  • This option represents an earlier gestational limit that was in place before the amendment. However, it's no longer accurate following the amendment that extends the limit to 24 weeks for certain categories of women.

Option 4: 14 weeks

  • This option is way below the limit imposed on abortion. it's no longer accurate following the amendment that extends the limit to 24 weeks for certain categories of women.

questions.text: A 47-year-old male patient is brought to the clinic complaining of a large erythematous skin pocket on his sacrum and left hip. He has a history of systemic lupus erythematosus, paraplegia, and steroid-induced diabetes, diagnosed two years ago. Examination reveals large 3-4 cm pressure sores, as shown in the image below. Which would be the most appropriate treatment for this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Surgery is the only modality of the treatment
A fasciocutaneous flap should be used
Herbal remedies with or without insulin are mostly useful than other remedies.
Stage 2 and 3 ulcers may be left to heal secondarily after debridement.

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Stage 2 and 3 ulcers may be left to heal secondarily after debridement:

  • Stage 2 and 3 pressure ulcers, as seen in the image, typically involve partial thickness skin loss or full thickness tissue loss, respectively.
  • Treatment often involves debridement to remove necrotic tissue and promote healing.
  • Leaving the ulcers to heal secondarily after debridement allows for natural wound healing processes to occur without the need for surgical intervention.
  • This approach is suitable, particularly considering the patient's comorbidities such as systemic lupus erythematosus, paraplegia, and steroid-induced diabetes, which may increase surgical risks.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Surgery is the only modality of treatment:

  • While surgery may be necessary in some cases of pressure ulcers, it is not the only treatment modality, especially for stage 2 and 3 ulcers.
  • Non-surgical interventions such as debridement and wound care are often utilized.

Option B - A fasciocutaneous flap should be used:

  • While flap surgery may be considered in severe cases of pressure ulcers, it is not always the most appropriate initial treatment, especially for stage 2 and 3 ulcers.
  • Flap surgery is typically reserved for more advanced or non-responsive cases.

Option C - Herbal remedies with or without insulin are mostly useful than other remedies:

  • Herbal remedies and insulin are not the primary treatments for pressure ulcers.
  • Wound care, debridement, and addressing underlying factors such as pressure relief are essential in managing pressure ulcers.

questions.text: A newborn was delivered by vacuum-assisted delivery. On examination, the baby is comatose, with severe hypotonia, absent Moro’s reflex, variable heart rate, and mildly dilated pupils. Which among the following is the correct stage of hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy referred to here?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Stage 3 HIE

  • The baby is comatose
  • Severe hypotonia
  • Absent Moro’s reflex
  • Both sympathetic and parasympathetic systems are depressed
  • Pupils mildly dilated
  • Variable HR
  • Prognosis:
    • 50% die
    • 50% severe neurological sequelae

Incorrect Options:

Option A & B - Stage 1 HIE & Stage 2 HIE: The features mentioned above are of Stage 3 HIE

Option D - Stage 4 HIE: There is no stage 4 under staging of Hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy

questions.text: Which of the following statements about pseudobulbar palsy is accurate?

choices.text: It typically presents with a monotone voice and reduced emotional expression
Patients often have a diminished gag reflex
Anarthria is a feature of pseudobulbar palsy
Exaggeration of emotions, such as involuntary crying or laughing, is a characteristic feature

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Exaggeration of emotions, such as involuntary crying or laughing, is a characteristic feature:

  • This feature is known as pseudobilbar affect.
  • Pseudobulbar affect (PBA) results from degeneration of the corticobulbar projections innervating the brainstem.
  • Features of Pseudobulbar palsy include:
    • Donald Duck voice - Dysarthria
    • Exaggeration of emotions (Involuntary crying/ laughing)
    • Brisk gag reflex

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, B and C are incorrect as mentioned above.

questions.text: At rest, myosin heads are bound with adenosine diphosphate (said to be in a "cocked" position) to the thin filament that does not have Calcium (Ca2+) bound to the troponin-tropomyosin complex. Ca2+ bound to the troponin-tropomyosin complex induces a conformational change in the thin filament, allowing myosin heads to cross-bridge with thin filament actin. Which of the following triggers the detachment of the myosin head from the actin filament?

choices.text: Entry of Ca++ into the sarcoplasmic reticulum
Hydrolysis of ATP to ADP and Pi

questions.solution:
Option C: Binding of ATP to head

  • ATP binding causes myosin to release actin, allowing actin and myosin to detach from each other.
  • Hence, the Myosin head separates from actin when ATP is attached to the myosin head.
  • So, the correct answer is When the Binding of ATP to the head.

Option A: Change in troponin C configuration

  • The binding of Ca2+ and troponin C produces a sequence of conformational changes in the troponin-tropomyosin complex that exposes the specific myosin-binding site on actin.

Option B: Entry of Ca2+ into the sarcoplasmic reticulum

  • The sarcoplasmic reticulum releases calcium ions that various enzymes require during muscle contraction.
  • The myosin heads perform the task of attachment and detachment, extending from the heads on the myosin filaments to the sites on actin filaments.

Option D: Hydrolysis of ATP to ADP and Pi

  • Myosin has another binding site for ATP at which enzymatic activity hydrolyzes ATP to ADP, releasing an inorganic phosphate molecule and energy.
  • ATP binding causes myosin to release actin, allowing actin and myosin to detach from each other.
  • After this happens, the newly bound ATP is converted to ADP and inorganic phosphate, Pi.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the dermatology clinic with a painful rash on his beard area. He reports that the rash started as small red bumps and has progressively worsened over the past week. On examination, you observe multiple pustules and papules with surrounding erythema and crusting. Based on the clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Sycosis barbae:

  • It is also known as barber's itch. Sycosis barbae is a bacterial infection of the hair follicles in the beard area, commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus. The clinical presentation of painful rash, small red bumps progressing to pustules and papules with surrounding erythema and crusting, is consistent with Sycosis barbae.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Bockhart's impetigo: Bockhart's impetigo is a superﬁcial folliculitis that specifically affects the hair follicles, leading to the formation of pustules and crusts. However, it is characterized by deeper, more discrete lesions compared to the widespread pustules and papules seen in the presented case.

Option C - Tinea barbae: Tinea barbae, also known as ringworm of the beard, is a fungal infection caused by dermatophyte fungi. It typically presents with circular, scaly patches with hair loss. The presence of pustules and papules with surrounding erythema and crusting, as seen in the case, is more suggestive of a bacterial infection rather than a fungal one.

Option D - Impetigo: Impetigo is a common bacterial skin infection that can occur in various areas of the body, including the beard area. It typically presents with honey-colored crusts and superficial blisters. While the pustules and papules observed in the case may resemble impetigo, the absence of honey-colored crusts and the involvement of the hair follicles make Sycosis barbae a more likely diagnosis.

questions.text: In a community medicine study, researchers are analyzing the trends of an infectious disease outbreak over time. They want to select the most appropriate graphical representation to depict the incidence of cases accurately. Which among the following graphical representations is the best to represent the trends of an event or incidence of cases with time?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Line charts:

  • Line charts are ideal for displaying trends over time.
  • They show the relationship between two variables, with one variable typically plotted on the x-axis (time) and the other on the y-axis (incidence of cases).
  • Each point on the chart represents a specific time period, allowing for a clear visualization of the trend in cases over time.
  • Therefore, line charts are the most suitable option for representing the trends of an event or incidence of cases with time.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Pie charts:

  • Pie charts are suitable for showing the distribution of parts of a whole but are not ideal for representing trends over time.

  • They are more static and do not convey changes in data over continuous intervals.

  • Therefore, they are not the best choice for representing the trends of an event or the incidence of cases with time.

Option C - Bar charts:

  • Bar charts are useful for comparing categories of data, but they are not specifically designed to show trends over time.

  • While bar charts can represent discrete data points, they are less effective than line charts for displaying continuous trends over time.

Option D - Histogram:

  • Histograms are similar to bar charts but are used specifically to represent the distribution of continuous data over intervals or bins.

  • While histograms can show the frequency distribution of events, they do not display the chronological sequence of data points over time, making them less suitable for representing trends of an event or incidence of cases with time.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with progressive neck pain, stiffness, and inability to move her neck laterally or medially. Which structures are involved in the patient's pathology?
questions.solution:
Option B: Atlanto-axial joint

  • This is a case of atlantoaxial joint dysfunction, which is most likely caused due to degenerative changes.
  • Side-to-side movement is due to the C1 – C2 joint called an atlantoaxial joint.
  • Atlas is C1 bone; Axis is C2 bone; the dens of C2 will fit into the atlas bone-forming atlantoaxial joint.

Option A: Atlanto-occipital joint

  • Atlantooccipital joint (Ellipsoidal synovial joint) causes yes movement/nodding movement.
  • Atlanto - occipital joint
    • For head nodding
    • Ellipsoid synovial/condylar joint
  • The vertebral artery comes from the foramen transversarium & arches over the superior surface of the atlas vertebra (Posterior arch) & enters the cranial cavity by passing through the foramen magnum upwards.​​​​​​​

Option C: C2-C3 articulation

  • C2-C3 articulation allows the flexion and extension of the movement
  • For example touching of the chin towards the chest and movement of the head backwards

Option D: C6-C7 articulation

  • This helps in giving flexibility to the neck and supports the cervical spine and head.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with dysphagia and regurgitation of undigested food. Barium swallow reveals a Zenker's diverticulum measuring 4 cm in size. The patient is fit for surgery. What is the most appropriate treatment option for this patient?

choices.text: Endoscopic balloon dilation of the cricopharyngeal muscle.
Excision of pouch and cricopharyngeal myotomy through a cervical approach.

questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Excision of pouch and cricopharyngeal myotomy through a cervical approach.

  • This option involves surgically removing the Zenker's diverticulum and performing cricopharyngeal myotomy through a cervical approach.
  • It is considered the standard treatment for fit patients with symptomatic Zenker's diverticulum, particularly when the diverticulum is large or causing significant symptoms.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Endoscopic balloon dilation of the cricopharyngeal muscle:

  • Endoscopic balloon dilation is a non-surgical treatment option for Zenker's diverticulum.
  • It involves using an endoscope and a balloon catheter to stretch and disrupt the cricopharyngeal muscle, allowing improved food passage.
  • However, in this case, the diverticulum size (4 cm) is relatively large, making endoscopic dilation less effective and surgical intervention more appropriate.

Option C - Observation and conservative management:

  • Observation and conservative management may be considered for patients with small Zenker's diverticula and minimal symptoms.
  • However, in this case, the patient's symptoms and the size of the diverticulum indicate the need for intervention rather than observation alone.

Option D - Gastrostomy tube placement:

  • Gastrostomy tube placement is not a primary treatment option for Zenker's diverticulum. It is typically used for enteral nutrition in patients who cannot tolerate oral feeding due to other reasons

questions.text: In a community with a prevalence of trachoma follicles greater than 10%, which of the following interventions would be the most appropriate according to the SAFE strategy?

choices.text: Follow facial hygiene and environmental cleanliness

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Trichiasis surgery:

  • The SAFE strategy, implemented by the WHO, aims to control trachoma in communities.
  • The criteria for implementing the SAFE strategy depend on the prevalence of trachoma follicles in the community.
  • If the prevalence of trachoma follicles is greater than 10%, follow the SAFE strategy. If it is between 5-10 %, follow only the FE strategy.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female complaints of headache, palpitations, and increased sweating. Her blood pressure was 180/100 mm Hg. On examination, urinary catecholamines and their metabolites were found to be elevated. Which of the following statements is incorrect about this condition?

choices.text: They may arise from sympathetic ganglions

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 90% are malignant:

  • The given condition is pheochromocytoma. They arise from sympathetic ganglia and secrete catecholamines.
  • According to the rule of 10, pheochromocytomas are:
    • 10%- bilateral
    • 10% - malignant
    • 10% - occur in pediatric patients
    • 10% - extra-adrenal
    • 10% - familial
  • Extra adrenal tumors, also called functional paragangliomas, may be found at sites of sympathetic ganglia in the
    • Organ of Zuckerkandl
    • Neck
    • Mediastinum
    • Abdomen and pelvis

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C & D - are correct, as explained above.

questions.text: A 36-year-old married female with two kids presents to the community health center for a routine check-up. She stated she desires to limit her family size due to financial constraints.  In this context, which among the following countries is credited as the first to launch a national family planning welfare program?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - India:

  • India initiated its National Family Planning Program in 1951-52, making it one of the earliest countries to implement such a program.
  • The program aimed to promote contraceptive methods, reproductive health awareness, and maternal and child health services across the country.
  • Therefore, India was the first country to launch such a program.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, D:

  • None of these countries was the first to launch a national family planning welfare program.

questions.text: Four patients visiting the antenatal clinic have profiles as listed below. They are all screened at 24 weeks for gestational diabetes. Which of the following has the highest risk of having gestational diabetes?

choices.text: G2P1L0 with previous unexplained perinatal loss
Current amniotic fluid index (AFI) of 7 cms
G2P1L1 with previous low birth weight baby

questions.solution:
Option B: G2P1L0 with previous unexplained perinatal loss

High-risk factors for gestational diabetes

  • History of stillbirth
  • History of neonatal death
  • History of fetal macrosomia
  • Concomitant obesity or hypertension
  • Diabetes in a first-degree relative
  • Overweight before pregnancy
  • Strong family history of type II DM
  • Previous history of GDM

 

Option A: 23-year-old primigravida

  • 23-year-old primigravida is not a risk factor for gestational diabetes mellitus.
  • Therefore, this option is not correct.

 

Option C: Current amniotic fluid index (AFI) of 7 cms

  • Normal amniotic fluid index is 5cm to 25cm. This patient has a normal amniotic fluid index. This patient is not at risk for gestational diabetes. 
  • GDM is more commonly associated with polyhydramnios
  • Therefore, this option is not correct.

 

Option D: G2P1L1 with previous low birth weight baby

  • Gestational diabetes is associated with increased birth weight/ macrosomia
  • Previous low birth weight baby is not a risk of gestational diabetes in the current pregnancy.
  • Therefore, this option is not correct.

questions.text:
Please match each tumor with its corresponding slide:


	
		
			
			A.  Pleomorphic adenoma
			
			
			1. 
			
		
		
			
			B.  Papillary cystadenoma Lymphomatosum
			
			
			2. 
			
		
		
			
			C.  Mucoepidermoid Carcinoma
			
			
			3. 
			
		
		
			
			D.  Adenoid Cystic Carcinoma
			
			
			4.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – A-4, B-3, C-2, D-1:

The given microscopic features are correctly matched in option B

Pleomorphic Adenoma (Benign Mixed Tumor):

  • Components: Epithelial and Mesenchymal.
    • Epithelial Component: Comprising epithelial cells and myoepithelial cells.
    • Mesenchymal Component: Characterized by chondromyxoid stroma
  • Papillary Cystadenoma Lymphomatosum:
    • Microscopic Features:
      • Papillary projections are seen.
      • Papillae are lined by two rows of oncocytic cells.
      • High lymphocyte count.
      • Tumor exists as a cyst filled with fluid.
  • Mucoepidermoid Carcinoma:
    • Microscopic Features:
      • Mucin-containing cells.
      • Squamous cells with a pink appearance.
      • Higher grade tumors have more epidermoid/squamous cells.
