  • Adenoid Cystic Carcinoma (ACC):
    • Microscopic Features:
      • Cribriform pattern: Sieve-like pattern with basement membrane-like material.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, C, and D do not correctly match the tumors with their microscopic features.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male came to the Outpatient department with history of fever for 3 days.He admitted that he had multiple episodes of vomiting and restlessness. Lab investigations revealed elevated HCT ,platelet count of 70,000/mcL ,a positive IgM for dengue virus..He was admitted to the inpatient department for further treatment.The HCT seemed to be elevated despite maximum fluid resuscitation. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Albumin:

  • Albumin (colloids) is the next step in management:
  • The question clearly indicates the HCT remains same despite maximum fluid resuscitation- group c (severe dengue)

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B: Refer to the above explanation

Option D - Vaccination:

  • It can be given but ineffective during acute phase of dengue.

questions.text: Which among the following is the correct statement about short trunk dwarfism?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - US:LS ratio is decreased:

  • Short trunk dwarfism is a subtype of Disproportionate dwarfism
  • US:LS ratio is decreased 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - US:LS ratio is increased: In Short limb dwarfism, US:LS ratio is increased

Option C - US:LS ratio is normal: In Proportionate short stature, US:LS ratio is normal

Option D - US = LS: This is not seen in Short trunk dwarfism

questions.text: Which drug, not inducing mydriasis, might the physician prescribe for a 50-year-old female experiencing severe right eye pain, blurred vision, nausea, and conjunctival injection with corneal edema, along with a fixed and dilated right pupil, without any other remarkable findings on examination?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Pilocarpine:

  • All these symptoms of the patient suggest angle closure glaucoma.
  • Pilocarpine is a drug which can be used for this condition.
  • Pilocarpine cause miosis, not mydriasis. It activates cholinergic receptors by stimulating a specific subtype of muscarinic receptor (M3) located on the iris sphincter muscle, resulting in muscle contraction and the induction of miosis.
  • Applied to the eye, it penetrates the cornea and promptly causes miosis, ciliary muscle contraction and fall in intraocular pressure lasting 4-8 hours.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Atropine:

  • Parasympatholytic drugs like atropine stop the action of Ach on sphincter pupillae resulting in passive mydriasis.

Option B - Phenylephrine:

  • Phenylephrine is an alpha-adrenergic agonist.
  • It can be used for:
    • Nasal decongestion
    • Dilation of the pupils

Option C - Tropicamide:

  • Tropicamide is an anticholinergic drug.
  • It is also used for the dilation of the pupils.
  • It is usually used during the examination of the eyes.

questions.text: What is the causative organism in a 55-year-old man with painful multiple crops of a rash on the right side of his face involving his nose and eyes, and a history of lupus and long-term steroid use, along with blurry vision in his right eye?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Herpes virus type 3:

  • The patient's clinical presentation of multiple crops of rash, i.e., macules, papules, vesicles, and pustules on the right side of the face, is suggestive of Herpes zoster ophthalmicus caused by herpes virus type 3 (Varicella zoster virus).
  • The lesion is on one side of the face, supplied by the trigeminal nerve with eye involvement.

Herpes Zoster ophthalmicus:

  • This is due to the reactivation of the latent Varicella-zoster virus in the trigeminal ganglia due to lowered immunity (usage of steroids)
  • Single-sided lesion.
  • The ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve is involved.
  • Preceded by a prodrome of itchiness or tingling.
  • Painful unilateral macules, papules, vesicular, pustular, and scab eruption along a single dermatome that does not cross the midline is present.
  • The virus is often latent in the dorsal root ganglia or trigeminal ganglia.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Herpes virus type 1:

  • Herpes virus type 1 is herpes simplex virus type 1 causing herpes labialis (painful vesicular lesions over the lip).
  • HSV-1 primarily causes mouth, throat, face, eye, and CNS infections. The rash caused by herpes simplex virus is vesicular, and reactivation is due to fever, axonal injury, physical or emotional stress, or exposure to UV light.

Option B - Herpes virus type 2:

  • Herpes virus type 2, also known as herpes simplex virus type 2, causes genital lesions or lesions below the waist along with fever and malaise.

Option D - Herpes virus type 4:

  • Herpes virus type 4, also known as Epstein-Barr virus is known for causing infectious mononucleosis, a condition characterized by symptoms such as fever, sore throat, and swollen lymph nodes.

questions.text:
Assertion: Urea synthesis is an energy requiring process. It consumes total 4 high energy phosphates

Reason: 2 ATPs are needed at carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I step and 2 ATPs at argininosuccinate synthetase step.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are independently true / correct statements and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are independently true / correct statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion
Assertion is independently a true / correct statement, but the Reason is independently a false / incorrect statement
Assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reason is independently a true/correct statement.

questions.solution:
Correct option A:  Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion

  • In the urea cycle, A total of 3 ATPs but four high energy phosphates are consumed as shown in the diagram below.

  • 2 ATP are consumed in the conversion of CO2 and ammonia into carbamoyl phosphate via the enzyme carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I (CPS I).
  • ATP to AMP conversion is counted as 2 ATPs in the argininosuccinate synthetase step.

Incorrect options

Option B, C, and D: refer to option A explanation

questions.text: A 30-year old presents with bleeding nasal obstruction, bleeding from the nose and difficulty in breathing. On examination, strawberry-like mass appears in the nasal cavity and he is diagnosed to have rhinosporidiosis. What is the recommended treatment for rhinosporidiosis?

choices.text: Surgical excision followed by dapsone therapy

questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Surgical excision followed by dapsone therapy 

  • This option aligns with the recommended treatment.
  • Complete excision of the mass with a diathermy knife and cauterization of its base is performed, followed by medical treatment with dapsone.
  • This combination approach aims to remove the mass surgically and reduce the chances of recurrence.

 

Incorrect options

Option A: Antibiotic therapy with dapsone

  • This option suggests using dapsone as the primary treatment for rhinosporidiosis.
  • However, medical treatment with dapsone is only partially effective and can be used to reduce recurrence. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option B: Surgical excision only

  • This option suggests that surgical excision without any follow-up medication is the recommended treatment.
  • However, surgery followed by medicines is the treatment for rhinosporidiosis. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option D: Medical treatment with dapsone only

  • This option suggests using dapsone as the sole treatment without surgical intervention.
  • However, surgery followed by medicines is the recommended treatment for rhinosporidiosis. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: Body fluids include the interstitial fluids, saliva, tears, and gastric juices. They moisten the tissues, muscles, organs, and skin. Which of the following is a correct physiological statement about body fluids?

choices.text: The total body fluid per unit of body weight is less in infants as compared to adults
The ECF volume of a 70 kg adult man would be approximately 14 L
Intracellular fluid is 66% of total body weight
Synovial fluid is not a transcellular fluid

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - The ECF volume of a 70 kg adult man would be approximately 14 L:

  • Total body water is 60% of body weight. Therefore, 42 L in a 70 kg man
  • Extracellular fluid (ECF) is 1/3rd or 33.3% of total body water (TBW), i.e., 14L, which is 20% of body weight.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

  • Infants actually have a higher percentage of total body water compared to adults due to their higher proportion of water-containing tissues and organs. Intracellular fluid typically accounts for about 2/3rd of total body water, not 66% of body weight. Synovial fluid is indeed a type of transcellular fluid, along with other fluids like cerebrospinal fluid and peritoneal fluid.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man presenting with multiple falls and episodes of dizziness over the past 6 weeks, examination reveals a wide-based gait, impaired rapid alternating movements of the hands, and a coarse tremor when grabbing a pen. Muscle power and sensation are normal. What is the blood supply of the structure involved in the patient's pathology?


	Vertebral artery
	Basilar artery
	Middle cerebral artery
	Posterior cerebral artery
questions.solution:
Correct Options A - Only 1 and 2 are correct: 

  • Neurological deficits suggest cerebellar dysfunction, responsible for coordination and balance.
  • Symptoms include frequent falls, dizziness, coarse intentional tremors, impaired coordination, and inability to walk straight.
  • Lesions in the cerebellum can result from causes like ischemic stroke or hemorrhage.
  • Blood supply: Primarily provided by vertebral arteries and basilar artery, forming vertebrobasilar system.
  • Likely blood supply territory for observed symptoms: Territory supplied by vertebral artery and basilar artery.

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option B, C & D are incorrect because it consist of the following

 Statement 3: Middle cerebral artery

  • The middle cerebral artery does not supply the cerebellum
  • The lateral surface of the cerebrum receives supply from the middle cerebral artery.
  • The medial surface of the cerebrum is majorly supplied by the anterior cerebral artery.

 Statement 4: Posterior cerebral artery

  • The posterior cerebral artery does not supply the cerebellum
  • It supplies the midbrain and the thalamus

questions.text: Which of the following features is true about feigned insanity?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Exaggerated facial appearance: 

  • In cases of feigned insanity, the person voluntarily exaggerates the facial appearance.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Gradual onset: In feigned insanity, its Sudden onset.

Option B - Presence of predisposing factor: Predisposing factors are absent in feigned insanity.

Option D - Motive is usually absent: In feigned insanity, Motive is always present.

questions.text: A woman presents in a subsequent pregnancy at 38 weeks at the onset of labor pains. She is admitted for safe delivery. On examination, the cervix is 2 cm dilated and membranes are intact, fetal heart is good. With which of the following findings can the patient be allowed to progress with labor?
questions.solution:
Option A : Occipito-posterior can deliver normally

80% of occipito-posterior deliver normally by becoming occipito-anterior by forward rotation in favorable pelvis in advancing labour.

Out of total Occipito posterior position,

-80% becomes OccipitoAnterior-

  • Mode of delivery - Normal (hence it is preferable to wait and watch for spontaneous rotation to occur)

-15-16% becomes persistent OccipitoPosterior

  • occurs in anthropoid pelvis
  • Mode of delivery - Face to pubis delivery

-2-4% undergoes Deep transverse arrest

  • occurs in android pelvis
  • Mode of delivery - Manual rotation and forceps extraction(sagittal suture of baby should be in AP plane of pelvis) or cesarean section

Indications for LSCS

  • Cephalopelvic disproportion or contracted pelvis
  • Placenta previa
  • Fetal hypoxia
  • Previous cesarean : >=2, previous classical cesarean, previous hysterotomy
  • Pelvic tumors
  • Active genital herpes
  • Transverse lie, complicated breech, non cephalic presenting twin
  • Uterine rupture
  • Scarred uterus such as previous myomectomy, unification surgery
  • Other medical or surgical complications necessitating surgery

Option B : Transverse lie is an absolute contraindication for vaginal delivery

Option C :Absolute indications for cesarean in breech presentation are:

  • Footling breech
  • Breech with extended head
  • Complicated breech such as twin, previous cesarean etc
  • Any of the above mentioned obstetric indications

Option D : contracted pelvis is an indication for LSCS

questions.text: A 20-year-old female presents with vaginal itching, discharge, and painful intercourse. With a history of three sexual partners in two years, a wet mount reveals flagellated organisms with "twitching motility." Which statement accurately reflects the patient's current pathology?

choices.text: Men are always symptomatic and efficient transmitters of this organism
Metronidazole is contraindicated in this disease
In women, the incubation period is 1-2 days
In severe cases, the regional mucosa may be red with petechial lesions, and the cervix has been described as a "strawberry cervix."

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - In severe cases, the regional mucosa may be red with petechial lesions, and the cervix has been described as a strawberry cervix:

  • This statement pertains to a clinical finding in severe cases of trichomoniasis, an infection caused by the parasite Trichomonas vaginalis. When the infection is severe, it can cause inflammation and irritation of the vaginal and cervical tissues. This results in characteristic changes in the appearance of the cervix, which may be described as a "strawberry cervix."

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Men are always symptomatic and efficient transmitters of this organism:

  • Men infected with T. vaginalis: are usually asymptomatic but can transmit infection sexually.

Option B - Metronidazole is contraindicated in this disease:

  • All sexual partners must be treated concurrently (Metronidazole) to prevent reinfection, especially from asymptomatic males.

Option C - In women, the incubation period is 1-2 days:

  • It is an incorrect option because the incubation of Trichomonas vaginalis is not 1-2 days.
  • The incubation period is 5–28 days.

questions.text: In a village with a high prevalence of chronic diseases, a small group of public health researchers is assessing the effectiveness of various interventions in improving the quality of life. They decide to utilize Sullivan's index for their study. Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of Sullivan’s index?

choices.text: Sullivan's index = LE - Duration of stability
It is a disability-free life expectancy
It is a measure of the burden of disease and the effectiveness of intervention

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - It is a measure of the burden of disease and the effectiveness of intervention:

  • Sullivan's index represents disability-free life expectancy, not a measure of disease burden or intervention effectiveness. It quantifies the average number of years individuals are expected to live without disability, providing insight into overall health status.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Advanced disability indicator:

  • Sullivan's index does indicate disability but is not necessarily considered an "advanced" indicator.

Option B - Sullivan's index = LE - Duration of stability:

  • This equation accurately represents Sullivan's index calculation.

Option C - It is a disability-free life expectancy:

  • This is a characteristic of Sullivan's index, indicating the number of years expected to be lived without disability.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the OPD with complains of discomfort in the right ear with watery discharge with a musty odour. He was diagnosed with Otomycosis. Which of the following statements is correct about Otomycosis?

choices.text: It is predominantly caused by Aspergillus species.
It is less frequently observed in immunosuppressed individuals.
Red granulation tissues are commonly found in the external auditory canal.
The treatment of choice is the use of systemic antifungal medications.

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - It is predominantly caused by Aspergillus species:

  • Otomycosis is commonly caused by fungal infections, with Aspergillus species being one of the main culprits.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - It is less frequently observed in immunosuppressed individuals:

  • While otomycosis can occur in both immunocompetent and immunosuppressed individuals, it is most often seen in immunosuppressed individuals.

Option C - Red granulation tissues are commonly found in the external auditory canal:

  • Red granulation tissues are not commonly associated with otomycosis. Instead, otomycosis is characterized by a whitish discharge and the presence of black spores.

Option D - The treatment of choice is the use of systemic antifungal medications:

  • The treatment of otomycosis typically involves local toileting, such as cleaning and removal of fungal debris, along with the use of antifungal ear drops. Systemic antifungal medications are not usually necessary unless the infection is severe or recurrent.

questions.text: A 38-year woman presents in the OPD with the complaint of menorrhagia and severe pelvic and lower abdominal pain for the last 2 days. Her USG reveals a large fibroid for which she needs a hysterectomy. She is admitted to the ward for surgery. A gynaecologist instructs his residents regarding the pre-operative preparation of patients planned for hysterectomy during ward rounds. Which of these is a relevant instruction?

choices.text: A prophylactic antibiotic is given at the time of skin incision
The dose of antibiotic should be repeated after 3 hours in case the surgery is prolonged, or there is excessive bleeding
Povidone-iodine preparations have a lower rate of SSI than chlorhexidine alcohol-based preparations
All patients must be screened for bacterial vaginosis and adequately treated

questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B: The dose of antibiotic should be repeated after 3 hours in case the surgery is prolonged or there is excessive bleeding.

  • Prophylactic antibiotic: single dose 30 to 60 minutes before skin incision (and not at the incision). Cefazolin 1 to 2 g and increased to 3 g for obese patients is recommended.
  • Re-dosing is recommended after 3 hours of surgery and with excessive bleeding.
  • Chlorhexidine-alcohol–based skin preparations have lower surgical site infection odds than povidone-iodine preparations. Concentrations of 4% or less can be used in the vagina.
  • Although treating all patients with bacterial vaginosis may decrease vaginal cuff cellulitis, universal screening preoperatively is not recommended as a routine.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Prophylactic antibiotic is given at the time of skin incision.

  • A single dose of antibiotic should be given at 30 to 60 minutes before skin incision (and not at the time of incision)as the effective amount of serum and tissue level of the drug, at the time of incision, is needed to ensure its function.

Option C: Povidone-iodine preparations have a lower rate of SSI than chlorhexidine alcohol-based preparations.

  • Chlorhexidine alcohol is more effective in SSI than povidone-iodine preparations.

Option D: All patients must be screened for bacterial vaginosis and adequately treated

  • It is better to treat the infection before surgery, but it is not a requirement.

questions.text: A 23-yr-old nulliparous woman complains of painful coitus and informs that pain is located at the vaginal introitus. This is also accompanied by painful involuntary contraction of the pelvic muscles. The pelvic examination is normal. No obvious local pathology could be seen. The patient was unable to allow a pervaginal examination. Of the following, what is the most common cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: Psychological causes

The patient, in this case, has vaginismus as she complains of painful coitus and involuntary contractions of pelvic muscles.

  • Genito-Pelvic Penetration Pain Disorder: GPPPD
  • It includes dyspareunia and vaginismus
  • Dyspareunia:
  • Persistent or recurrent pain with attempted or complete vaginal entry or penile-vaginal intercourse.
  • This is frequently associated with pelvic pathologies such as endometriosis, pelvic adhesions, or ovarian neoplasms.
  • Vaginismus:
  • Persistent or recurrent difficulty to allow vaginal entry of a penis , often with phobic avoidance, anticipation/fear/experience of pain, plus variable and involuntary pelvic muscle contraction.
  • Involuntary reflexive contraction of pelvic muscles and often thighs, abdomen, buttocks, jaw, fists, and other muscle groups.
  • Absence of local or pelvic pathology.
  • These 2 terms, Dyspareunia and Vaginismus, are combined as mentioned above and called GPPPD.
  • Treatment of vaginismus:
  • It is graded psychotherapy.
  • This involves gradual assistance in making the patient aware of her anatomy and encouragement to allow self-examination for a few days first and then examination by a gynaecologist.
  • Intercourse is not an option till the patient is comfortable with a pelvic examination.

Option A: Endometriosis

  • A chronic, benign condition in which endometrial tissue is found outside the uterus, commonly in the fallopian tubes, ovaries, bladder or rectouterine pouch.
  • Symptoms include chronic pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, pre- or postmenstrual bleeding and infertility.
  • The symptom here is usually deep dyspareunia and not involuntary contraction of vaginal muscles

Option C: Bartholin gland abscess

  • When the Bartholin cyst is infected, the Bartholin abscess is formed.
  • Its clinical features are
  1. Acute unilateral pain and tender swelling
  2. Dyspareunia
  3. Pain while walking and sitting
  4. Fever
  5. Prompt pain relief with discharge
  • This has been ruled out with a normal local examination

Option D: Vulvar atrophy

  • It is a condition of vulvovaginal epithelial atrophy that can cause vaginal dryness, irritation, and discomfort with the loss of liable fat pads and receding pubic hair.
  • It can occur in a woman after menopause or due to other functional ovarian impairments that result in decreased estrogen production.

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered a trigger for Posterior Reversible Encephalopathy Syndrome (PRES)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B- Pre-eclampsia:

  • Posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES), can arise from various causes such as head injury, seizures, migraines, and certain drug use.
  • It involves a hyperperfusion state where blood pressure surpasses the brain's ability to regulate it, leading to cerebral edema.
  • Conditions considered as a trigger to PRES include:
    • Eclampsia
    • A.K.I
    • Amphetamines
    • SLE, APS
  • Symptoms include headaches, fluctuating neurological signs, and visual disturbances..
  • MRI shows characteristic edema mainly in the occipital lobes but can be generalized.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • As explained above options A, C and D are triggers for Posterior Reversible Encephalopathy Syndrome (PRES).

questions.text: Which of the following enriched media is most suitable for the growth of a fastidious bacterium that requires both V and X factors?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Chocolate Agar:

  • Chocolate agar is an enriched medium used to grow fastidious bacteria, for example, species of Haemophilus and Neisseria. A fastidious organism refers to a microorganism, that has specific nutritional requirements for growth and is challenging to cultivate in laboratory settings. The term "chocolate agar" refers to the appearance of the medium, which becomes a dark chocolate color after blood is added and the agar is heated during the preparation process.
  • V factor (NAD - nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide) and X factor (hematin) are two essential growth factors required by some bacteria, particularly Haemophilus species. Chocolate agar is known for containing both V and X factors, which makes it an ideal medium for the growth of Hemophilus.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Blood Agar: Blood agar is an enriched medium made by adding sterile sheep red blood cells to nutrient agar. While it provides extra nutrition, it does not release factors like V and X factors. Organisms like species of staphylococcus and streptococcus are grown on blood agar.

Option C - Sabouraud Agar: Sabouraud Agar is a selective medium used for the growth of fungi, not for fastidious bacteria requiring V and X factors.

Option D - MacConkey Agar: MacConkey Agar is a selective and differential medium used for the isolation and differentiation of gram-negative bacteria based on their lactose fermentation ability. MacConkey agar promotes the growth of most gram-negative rod bacteria especially enterobacteriaceae group of organisms.

questions.text: Which amino acid is present at this point (indicated by arrow) of protein?
questions.solution:
Correct option A: Glycine

The loop shown is called a β-turn structure of the protein.

β turns:

  • They are non-regular secondary protein structures that cause a direction change in the polypeptide chain. It allows the polypeptide to turn and get folded.
  • In β turn, the change of direction occurs in the space of 4 residues
  • They are common protein and polypeptide motifs.
  • Common amino acids present at β-turns include glycine, proline, asparagine, and aspartic acid.
  • Glycine and proline are commonly found in β turn positions due to their unique side chains that favor conformational stability in certain β turn positions.
  • Glycine has the smallest side chain to fit in a small space, creating bends in protein structure. So, glycine is responsible for protein flexibility.

Incorrect options

Option B: Lysine

  • Lysin is not present at the β turn point of the protein.
  • It is generally present in the active site of proteins which are generally present in the inside part of globular proteins.
  • It is a basic amino acid and participates in acid-base catalysis 

Option C: Methionine

  • Methionine is not present at the β turn point of the protein due to its bulkier size.

Option D: Glutamate

  • Glutamate is present at the surface of proteins.
  • It is an acidic amino acid and generally provides hydrophilic properties to the protein.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with a painless, enlarging mass in his nasal cavity. On examination, a friable, pedunculated, reddish mass with a "strawberry" appearance is noted. Biopsy shows sporangia containing endospores. This organism, primarily found in aquatic environments, is associated with nasal, genital, and ocular infections. What is the likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Rhinosporidium seeberi:

  • The patient's presentation of a friable, pedunculated, reddish mass with a characteristic "strawberry" appearance in the nasal cavity is suggestive of rhinosporidiosis. The key microscopic finding of sporangia containing tiny endospores within them is highly characteristic of Rhinosporidium seeberi, the causative agent of rhinosporidiosis. This infectious agent is classified as an aquatic protozoan. While this condition most commonly affects the nasal cavity, it can also involve the genitals and eyes. Rhinosporidium seeberi cannot be cultured using conventional methods. The most appropriate treatment for rhinosporidiosis is surgical removal of the polyp (polypectomy).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Candida albicans: Candida albicans is a yeast that can cause fungal infections, including oral thrush and vaginal yeast infections. However, it does not typically present with the characteristic "strawberry" appearance of a nasal polyp, and it does not form sporangia with endospores.

Option B - Aspergillus fumigatus: Aspergillus fumigatus is a mold that can cause a range of respiratory infections, including allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis and invasive aspergillosis. While it can lead to nasal symptoms, it does not commonly cause the distinctive "strawberry" appearance described in the question. Additionally, Aspergillus does not form sporangia with endospores.

Option D - Mycobacterium tuberculosis: Mycobacterium tuberculosis is a bacterium responsible for causing tuberculosis (TB). It primarily affects the lungs and can lead to respiratory symptoms, but it does not typically form the described "strawberry" nasal polyp appearance. TB is characterized by granulomatous inflammation, which is different from the presentation seen in rhinosporidiosis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a history of recurrent miscarriages presents to your clinic. She was recently diagnosed with obstetric antiphospholipid antibody syndrome. Her previous pregnancies ended in miscarriages during the first trimester. What is the recommended initial treatment option?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Low-dose aspirin + low molecular weight heparin (LMWH):

  • This combination is the cornerstone of treatment for obstetric antiphospholipid antibody syndrome. Low-dose aspirin helps to prevent platelet aggregation, while LMWH acts as an anticoagulant, reducing the risk of thrombosis and improving pregnancy outcomes.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Immunomodulators: Immunomodulators such as corticosteroids or hydroxychloroquine may be considered if the combination of low-dose aspirin and LMWH fails to improve pregnancy outcomes.

Option C - Warfarin: Warfarin is typically used for the treatment of thrombotic events in antiphospholipid syndrome. However, it is not the primary treatment for obstetric antiphospholipid antibody syndrome, as it may not provide adequate protection against pregnancy complications and could pose risks to the developing fetus.

Option D - No treatment: This option is not recommended, as untreated obstetric antiphospholipid antibody syndrome can lead to recurrent miscarriages and other pregnancy complications.

questions.text: A 21-year-old white woman was referred to a hospital after exposure to CO from a faulty furnace. She developed acute weakness, dyspnea, nausea, and vomiting. An ECG revealed sinus tachycardia, non-specific ST-T wave abnormalities, and a prolonged QTc interval. The chest X-ray revealed pulmonary edema and the 2-D echo revealed decreased LV systolic function with an EF of 25%. The treatment for this woman, among the following, would be?
questions.solution:
Option C: 100% Oxygen

  • Maintain patent airway, fresh air, and orthobaric oxygen (high-flow or 100% oxygen at atmospheric pressure) Oxygen therapy is started if COHb > 10% and should be given for 4–6 hours.

Incorrect options

Option A: Ascorbic acid

  • It is given as an antidote for poisoning caused by a fatal dose of mercury

Option B: Intravenous methylene blue

  • It is given as a treatment for cyanide poisoning

questions.text: A young patient with chest pain and palpitations came to the emergency room. ECG was done which showed tall tented T wave with pointed tip. What is the drug of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Calcium gluconate:

  • IV calcium gluconate/ chloride is the drug of choice in the treatment of hyperkalemia
  • Antagonism of K
  • Calcium carbonate is given orally

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C & D:

  • Insulin drip: Send K+ inside cells: ↓ K+ 0.5-1 by mEq/hour.
    • Most effective drug
  • Salbutamol nebulization potentiates the action of insulin.
  • IV furosemide can cause kaliuria (urinary loss of K+)

questions.text: HCG should come to pre-pregnancy levels in approximately how many weeks after normal delivery?
questions.solution:
Option C : 2 weeks

  • 2 weeks is the correct answer as hCG disappears from circulation within 2 weeks following delivery.
  •  

Other options are incorrect

questions.text: A 10-week-old baby is brought to an immunization center. The parents informed the nurse that the baby has had a common cold for 3 days and expressed concerns about the current vaccination. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Ask to come after 2 days after giving medicines for cold
Ask to come after 1 week when the symptoms resolve

questions.solution:
Option A - Continue immunization as per schedule:

  • When a baby with cold comes for immunization, vaccines can be given as per schedule
  • Minor cough and cold are not contraindications for vaccination
  • A history of severe allergic reaction such as urticaria, wheezing or difficulty breathing, or circulatory collapse or shock (not fainting) following a previous dose of vaccine or to a vaccine component is a contraindication to further doses.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Ask to come after 2 days after giving medicines for cold

Option C - Ask to come after 1 week when the symptoms resolve

Option D - Ask to come after 3 days

  • These cannot be the answer because minor cold is not a contraindication for vaccination

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman who had two normal pregnancies 13 and 20 years ago presents with the complaint of amenorrhea for 9 months. She expresses the desire to become pregnant again. After exclusion of pregnancy, which of the following is the next best test indicated in the evaluation of this patient’s amenorrhea?
questions.solution:
LH and FSH levels

  • Patient has secondary amenorrhea, which rules out abnormalities associated with primary amenorrhea such as congenital Mullerian abnormalities and chromosomal abnormalities.
  • The most common cause for secondary amenorrhea in a woman of reproductive age is pregnancy, which should be evaluated first.
  • Other possibilities include chronic endometritis or scarring of the endometrium (Asherman syndrome), hypothyroidism, and ovarian failure.
  • The latter is the most likely diagnosis in a woman at this age.
  • Persistently elevated gonadotropin levels (especially when accompanied by low serum estradiol levels) are diagnostic of ovarian failure.
  • Thus the most relevant test here would be LH and FSH which are expected to be raised at this age suggesting ovarian failure or menopause

An endometrial biopsy would show proliferative changes as cycles are mostly anovulatory in perimenopausal age group but this would suggest anovulation but not the exact cause of anovulation, which is expected to be ovarian failure in this case.

Karyotyping is warranted in cases of primary amenorrhea to rule out chromosomal causes

HSG for amenorrhea can identify an obstructive pathology such as Ashermans syndrome which is not likely here

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with hypertension, eruptive xanthoma with hepatosplenomegaly. The patient is currently using atorvastatin and lisinopril. In labs, the patient is found to have high LDL and increased total Cholesterol but normal levels of LDL receptors. What is the most probable cause of his lab findings?
questions.solution:
Correct option A:  Apo B-100 mutation

  • This patient is showing classical features of familial defective Apo B100, also known as autosomal dominant hypercholesterolemia IIa.
  • Clinical features of Familial hypercholesterolemia/ Type II–A hyperlipoproteinemia
  • Defect either in LDL receptors or Apo B100 apoprotein.
  • Autosomal dominant
  • LDL levels & cholesterol - raised
  • TGs & HDL - Normal
  • High levels of LDL cholesterol and increased risk of coronary artery disease and atherosclerosis, and cholesterol deposits may be seen as:
    • Xanthomas of the Achilles tendon.
    • Subcutaneous tuberous xanthomas over the elbows.
    • Xanthelasma (lipid in the eyelid).

Incorrect options

Option B: Apo E defect

  • The Apo E gene is located at chromosome 19 and encoded by three allelic isoforms.
  • The broad beta disease is caused by the ApoE defect.
  • It increases cholesterol, chylomicron remnant, VLDL remnant, and triglycerides.

Option C: LCAT deficiency

  • The liver synthesizes LCAT and is found at the surface of HDL.
  • It converts Cholesterol into cholesteryl ester.
  • LCAT deficiency primarily affects the kidneys and eyes.
  • It causes corneal opacities, kidney failure, and hemolytic anemia.

Option D: Lipoprotein lipase Deficiency

  • Lipoprotein lipase deficiency is caused by LPL gene mutation.
  • LPL deficiency decrease chylomicron breakdown, which causes hyperchylomicronemia.
  • Clinical features include eruptive cutaneous xanthoma, epigastric pain of varying intensity, and lipemia retinalis.

questions.text: Among the given options, which of the following given structures does not cross the dorsal surface of the bony landmark highlighted below?
questions.solution:
Option C: Obturator nerve

  • The bony landmark highlighted in the above diagram is the ischial spine, and the nerve block performed in the above scenario is the pudendal nerve block. The obturator nerve doesn’t lie in the dorsal relation of this bony landmark.
  • The ischial spine provides attachment to the sacrospinous ligament and is a bony landmark that is crossed by certain neurovascular structures.
  • The Pudendal nerve, Internal pudendal vessels, Nerve to obturator internus comes out of greater sciatic foramen, cross the dorsal surface of ischial spine and enter into lesser sciatic foramen.
  • The obturator nerve arises from the L2, L3, and L4 nerve roots that pass along the medial border of the psoasmuscle and then exit the pelvis by passing through the obturator foramen and obturator canal. The obturator nerve does not cross the dorsal aspect of the ischial spine.
  • The following diagram illustrates the structures passing along the dorsal aspect of the ischial spine and adjacent sacrospinous ligament:

Option A and B:

  • The pudendal nerve runs along the dorsal aspect of the ischial spine along with the internal pudendal vessels and then passes through the pudendal canal to enter the perineum. The ischial spines are important bony landmarks to target the pudendal nerve for pudendal nerve block.

Option D: Nerve to Obturator internus

  • The nerve to obturator internus crosses the dorsal aspect of ischial spine, enters the lesser sciatic foramen, and pierces the obturator internus. This nerve supplies the obturator internus and gemellus superior muscle.

questions.text: A group of third-year medical students was studying the NACP topic in the textbook of Community Medicine. One of the students taught the other the objectives of the National Strategic Plan for HIV/AIDS, 2017-2024. Which of the following is not an objective of it?

choices.text: Facilitate sustainable NACP service delivery by 2024
Ensure 95% of PLHIV (people living with HIV) know their status by 2024
Eliminate mother-to-child transmission of HIV and Syphilis by 2024

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Eliminate mother-to-child transmission of HIV and Syphilis by 2024:

  • This statement is incorrect due to the inaccuracy of the year mentioned.

Objectives of the National Strategic Plan for HIV/AIDS, 2017-2024 are as follows:

Objectives of the National Strategic Plan for HIV/AIDS, 2017-2024 are as follows:

Objective 1: Reduce 80% of new infections by 2024 (Baseline 2010)

Objective 2: Ensure 95% of estimated PLHIV (people living with HIV) know their status by 2024

Objective 3: Ensure 95% of PLHIV have ART initiation and retention by 2024, for sustained viral suppression

Objective 4: Eliminate mother-to-child transmission of HIV and Syphilis by 2020 (it has been extended)

Objective 5: Eliminate HIV/AIDS-related stigma and discrimination by 2020

Objective 6: Facilitate sustainable NACP service delivery by 2024


 

  • This target aligns with global efforts to achieve zero new HIV infections among infants.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Reduce 80% of new infections by 2024 (Baseline 2010):

  • This objective aims to significantly decrease the incidence of new HIV infections by 80% by the year 2024, compared to the baseline data from 2010.
  • This is a key target of the National Strategic Plan for HIV/AIDS, focusing on prevention strategies to curb the spread of the virus.

Option B - Facilitate sustainable NACP service delivery by 2024:

  • This objective focuses on ensuring the sustainable delivery of services under the National AIDS Control Program (NACP).
  • It aims to maintain and improve the provision of services related to HIV prevention, treatment, care, and support.
  • Thus, facilitating sustainable NACP service delivery is an integral objective of the National Strategic Plan for HIV/AIDS, 2017-2024.

Option C - Ensure 95% of PLHIV (people living with HIV) know their status by 2024:

  • This objective highlights the importance of increasing awareness and access to HIV testing services to ensure that 95% of estimated people living with HIV know their status by 2024.
  • This is crucial for early diagnosis, linkage to care, and treatment initiation, thus reducing transmission rates.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with primary infertility and right-sided pain abdomen. A hysterosalpingogram shows a tobacco pouch appearance on the right-sided fallopian tube. Which of the following is the most common transmission mode of this condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Hematogenous

  • A key contributing factor to female infertility worldwide, particularly in underdeveloped nations, is genital tuberculosis (TB).
  • The fallopian tubes (92%–100%), endometrial cavity (50%), and ovaries (10%–30%) are typically involved in infertile patients.
  • Cervical and vulvovaginal TB is uncommon.
  • Depending on the disease stage (acute inflammatory or chronic fibrotic) and the involved organ, genital TB exhibits distinct radiological findings.
  • Ultrasonography (US) and hysterosalpingography (HSG) are the primary imaging modalities utilised to diagnose genital TB.
  • The primary method for assessing uterine, fallopian tube, and peritubular involvement is HSG, which also aids in assessing tubal patency. In contrast, the US permits both ovarian and extrapelvic involvement to be evaluated simultaneously.
  • Features suggestive of genital tuberculosis on HSG are:
  • The tobacco-pouch appearance of hydrosalpinx and pyosalpinx
  • Lead pipe appearance (A rigid nonperistaltic pipe-like tube)
  • Calcification of the tube
  • Beading and variation in the filling defect
  • A jagged fluffiness of the tubal outline
  • Cornual block
  • HSG should not be performed if active tuberculosis is suspected, as it may spread the infection.
  • The mode of spread is through the haematogenous route or via lymphatics and rarely from direct contiguity with an intra-abdominal organ or affected peritoneum.

Option B: Ascending infection

  • Genital tuberculosis is not an ascending infection.
  • Other pathogens, such as Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis, cause ascending infection through the urethra and cervix.

Option C: Direct invasion

  • Treponema pallidum, Haemophilus ducreyi, and herpes simplex virus spread via invading the skin and the mucous membranes.
  • Genital TB does not spread via direct invasion

Option D: Sexually transmitted

  • Genital TB is not a sexually transmitted disease (STD)
  • Syphilis, chancroid, chlamydia, gonorrhoea, and human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) are examples of STDs.

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida presents to the antenatal clinic at 33 weeks of gestation for a routine checkup. Her BP is 170/100 mmHg. Her lipid profile and cardiac evaluation are normal. She never had raised BP in the past and has no family history of hypertension. Her urinalysis shows WBC 0-1/ HPF, albumin 2+, no glucosuria, and no pus cells. Which of the following is an expected renal change in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: glomerular endotheliosis

  • This patient presenting with high BP and proteinuria at 33 weeks of gestation most likely suffers from preeclampsia.
  • The characteristic renal lesion in preeclampsia is glomeruloendotheliosis.
  • It leads to scarring of glomeruli, decreasing the glomerular filtration rate.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Increased Glomerular filtration rate

In preeclampsia, the glomerular filtration rate decreases instead of increasing, because of the scarring of the glomeruli.

Option C: Increased renal blood flow

  • Renal perfusion is decreased in preeclampsia due to glomerular endotheliosis.

Option D: Persistent proteinuria after delivery

  • Proteinuria due to preeclampsia resolves on the termination of pregnancy. It does not persist after delivery.

questions.text: An inpatient of the hospital suffers burns injury when hot bottles were used for the treatment. In this case, the hospital incharge was also charged with negligence under the doctrine of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Vicarious liability:

  • Vicarious Liability/Respondent Superior: A doctrine that holds an employer legally responsible for the wrongful acts of an employee, if such acts occur within the scope of the employment.
  • An employer is responsible not only for his own negligent act but also for the negligent act of his employees by the principle of ‘respondent superior’ or ‘Master-Servant Rule’.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Res ipsa loquitur:

  • Res ipsa loquitur (Latin for “the thing speaks for itself”).
  • The very nature of an accident or injury itself proves the negligent action of the physician.
  • Specialized knowledge or understanding of technical matters of the medical profession is not required.
  • The application of common knowledge is sufficient to understand negligence.
  • Eg: Forceps inside the abdomen postoperatively.

Option C - Novus actus interveniens:

  • Novus actus interveniens: "new act intervening" breaking the chain of causation such that even if the defendant has acted negligently, a subsequent intervening action breaks the chain of causation with the loss or damage sustained and so the defendant is not liable.

Option D - Contributory negligence:

  • Contributory negligence: The plaintiff failed to take reasonable care of his own safety and this factor contributed to the harm ultimately suffered by the plaintiff.
  • The burden of proof lies with the defendant (doctor in this case).

questions.text: A 17-years old male presents to the hospital with complaints of soreness and swelling of the penis. The primary complaint includes the inability to retract the penis foreskin, pain and burning sensation while urinating. He also says that he suffers from pain during erections. Physical examination shows that the patient is uncircumcised. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the diagnosis?

choices.text: The most common cause is STI.
Circumcision is done in all the cases

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Congenital and acquired:

  • In this case, as the patient has the inability to retract the penile foreskin and shows ballooning and swelling of the penis, it makes the diagnosis of phimosis.
  • Phimosis most commonly occurs in the uncircumcised penis.
  • Phimosis is the formation of adhesion between the glans penis and prepuce.
  • It is the inability to fully retract the penile foreskin.
  • There are two types of phimosis.

Congenital:

  • It is also called physiological or primary phimosis and is present at birth..

Acquired

  • It is also called pathological or secondary phimosis and occurs as a result of scarring, infection, or inflammation.
  • Adult men can have secondary phimosis caused by tears or recurring infections, or STIs.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Most common cause is STI:

  • The most common cause of phimosis is a chronic infection due to poor hygiene.
  • Not cleaning the penis can cause infection and result in phimosis.
  • It is occasionally associated with sexually transmitted infections (STIs).
  • STI is not a common cause.

Option C - Ballooning of prepuce during erection:

  • Bulging or ballooning of prepuce while urinating is one of the most common symptoms of phimosis.
  • This happens because, during micturition, urine accumulates in the foreskin before making its way out.

Option D - Circumcision is done in all the cases:

  • Circumcision for phimosis should be avoided in children requiring general anesthesia except in cases with recurrent infections.
  • The procedure should be postponed until the child reaches an age when local anesthesia can be used.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with sudden onset vertigo, hearing loss, and a feeling of fullness in the ear. The symptoms started a week after recovering from a viral respiratory infection. Upon examination, no signs of tinnitus or ear discharge are observed. The patient is otherwise healthy with no significant medical history. Based on the history and clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Labyrinthitis:

  • Labyrinthitis is a condition in which the entire labyrinth, including the cochlea and vestibular system, becomes inflamed. It is commonly associated with a viral infection and can result in symptoms such as vertigo, hearing loss, and a feeling of fullness in the ear. The duration of symptoms can vary from several days to a few months.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Vestibular Neuronitis:

  • Vestibular neuronitis is characterized by sudden onset vertigo, nausea, and vomiting without associated hearing loss or tinnitus.
  • It is an inflammatory process that affects the vestibular nerve. The symptoms can last for days to weeks and are often triggered by viral infections or occur idiopathically.

Option C - Meniere's Disease:

  • Meniere's disease is a chronic condition characterized by recurrent episodes of vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus (ringing in the ear), and a feeling of fullness or pressure in the affected ear.
  • It is thought to be caused by an abnormal accumulation of fluid in the inner ear. The episodes of vertigo can last for hours and are often accompanied by nausea and vomiting.

Option D - Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV):

  • BPPV is a common inner ear disorder characterized by brief episodes of vertigo triggered by certain head movements, such as rolling over in bed or looking up.
  • It is caused by the displacement of small calcium crystals (otoconia) within the inner ear. BPPV typically does not cause hearing loss or other symptoms like tinnitus.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the ER with severe epigastric pain. He has a history of epigastric pain following food intake. A detailed history reveals recurrent renal stones and inability see things on the outer sides of their vision. Which of the following syndromes is suspected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - MEN 1:

  • The patient has a characteristic history of MEN-1 syndrome, including recurrent stones (Primary hyperparathyroidism), bitemporal hemianopia (Prolactinoma), and a history of epigastric pain after food intake (Gastrinoma).

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B & D are not associated with this condition.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female named Sarah recently survived a severe car accident. She was trapped in the wreckage for several hours before being rescued. Since the accident, she has been experiencing recurrent distressing dreams about the event, avoiding driving or even being near cars, and constantly feeling on edge. Which of the following best describes Sarah's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C : Hypervigilance and avoidance behavior.

  • Based on the scenario, Sarah is experiencing several symptoms consistent with Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD). These symptoms include recurrent distressing dreams about the traumatic event (intrusion symptoms), avoiding driving or cars (avoidance), and constantly feeling on edge (hypervigilance). Therefore, option C is the most appropriate choice that reflects Sarah's symptoms.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Anterograde amnesia: Anterograde amnesia pertains to a specific type of memory impairment, rather than the set of symptoms she is experiencing.

Option B - Social withdrawal and isolation: While avoidance behavior is present in PTSD, it specifically refers to avoiding reminders of the traumatic event, not necessarily social withdrawal or isolation.

Option D - Excessive sleepiness and fatigue: While sleep disturbances can occur in PTSD, the scenario does not mention excessive sleepiness and fatigue as primary symptoms experienced by Sarah.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient is brought to the clinic by his family, expressing concerns about the patient’s behavior. The family reports that the patient has been laughing uncontrollably without any apparent reason and suddenly bursts into tears without any provocation. During the examination, the patients show sudden laughing and crying emotions without any reason. Which abnormality of affect is most likely present in the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Labile affect 

  • Labile affect refers to rapid and abrupt changes in emotional expression without any apparent stimuli. The patient's uncontrollable laughter and sudden crying without any provocation suggest labile affect, which is often associated with conditions such as mania and organic mental disorders.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Flat/Blunt affect

  • Flat affect refers to a lack of emotional expression even when discussing emotional events. However, in the given scenario, the patient's emotional expression is rapidly changing between uncontrollable laughter and sudden tears, indicating a different abnormality.

Option C - Elevation of mood

  • Elevation of mood refers to excessive happiness, ranging from euphoria to ecstasy. However, the scenario does not describe a consistently elevated mood, but rather rapid and unpredictable shifts between laughter and tears.

Option D - Depressed mood

  • Depressed mood refers to feelings of sadness or low mood. The scenario does not describe a consistent sad mood but rather extreme fluctuations between laughter and tears.

questions.text: A 1-year-old boy was brought to the emergency department after several episodes of vomiting and lethargy. He was also found to have hypoglycemia. His pediatrician was concerned about possible hepatic failure along with recurrent episodes of vomiting and lethargy. A detailed history of the parents revealed that these symptoms appear every time after the ingestion of fruits, honey, and juice. What substance accumulation is most likely to occur in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Fructose-1-phosphate:

  • Symptoms like vomiting and low energy post fruit juice ingestion point to potential Hereditary Fructose Intolerance (HFI), an autosomal recessive condition marked by aldolase B enzyme deficiency, leading to fructose-1-P accumulation.
  • This sequesters Pi, inhibiting glycogen phosphorylase and causing fasting hypoglycemia. Patients are typically asymptomatic until fructose intake, with prolonged exposure leading to jaundice, hepatomegaly, and hepatic failure

Incorrect Options:

Option B – Galactitol:

  • Galactitol accumulation occurs in Classical Galactosemia, a metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency in the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridylyltransferase (GALT).
  • Galactosemia presents with symptoms such as jaundice, hepatomegaly, infantile cataracts, and intellectual disability, especially after the ingestion of lactose-containing foods.

Option C - Galactose-1-phosphate:

  • Galactosemia, particularly when caused by a deficiency in galactose-1-phosphate uridylyltransferase (GALT), leads to the accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate. This buildup depletes the liver of inorganic phosphate, causing severe liver damage and potentially leading to liver failure. Mental deterioration can also occur due to the impact on brain function.

Option D – Lactose:

  • Lactose is a disaccharide sugar composed of glucose and galactose. While lactose intolerance can cause gastrointestinal symptoms such as vomiting and diarrhea after the ingestion of lactose-containing foods, it does not lead to hypoglycemia or hepatic failure.

questions.text: What are the chromosomes involved in early-onset Alzheimer's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 1, 14, 21:

  • The chromosomes involved with early onset Alzheimer’s disease are 1,14 and 21.
  • Young-onset (also called early-onset) Alzheimer's is an uncommon form of dementia that affects people younger than age 65.
  • About 5% to 6% of people with Alzheimer's disease develop symptoms before age 65.
  • Implicated genes in early-onset Alzheimer's disease include presenilin 1 and 2 (on chr 14 & 1) and APP gene (on chr 21)

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of Option A.

questions.text: Which of the following toxicities is not a contributing factor to secondary parkinsonism?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Magnesium:

  • Magnesium deficiency, while it can cause neurological symptoms such as tremors and muscle spasms, is not typically associated with secondary parkinsonism.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A,B and C are incorrect. Secondary parkinsonism has been linked to excessive levels of toxic substances such as carbon monoxide, methanol, and MPTP.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a known history of chronic heart failure presented to the cardiology outpatient department with shortness of breath for 2 weeks, which had gradually worsened. He complained that he was unable to perform his daily activities anymore. He gave a history of smoking for the last 30 years. On examination, he had bilateral pitting pedal oedema and elevated JVP. Auscultation of the chest revealed bilateral basal crepitations. His chest x-ray showed cardiomegaly and pleural effusion. The patient reported non compliance to medication in the preceding weeks. Which of the following drug is most useful in the patient’s current pathology?
questions.solution:
Option C: BNP analogue

  • In this case, the patient is a chronic smoker with a history of chronic heart failure and non compliance to medications, suffering from symptoms of cardiac decompensation. These include worsening dyspnea for the last 2 weeks, pedal oedema, basal crepitations, pleural effusion suggesting fluid overload from low cardiac output. Therefore, this is a case of acute-on-chronic cardiac failure. It includes sudden and severe worsening of symptoms in a patient with preexisting chronic heart failure.
  • Nesiritide is a recombinant BNP analogue used in acute cardiac failure.
  • It is indicated for patients with worsening dyspnea or dyspnea at rest.
  • It has a half-life of 18 minutes.
  • It is not used in chronic therapy.

Option A: Na+ K+ ATPase inhibitor

  • Digitalis is a Na+ K+ ATPase inhibitor that exhibits positive inotropic action.
  • It is not a chronotropic agent; therefore, it does not significantly affect the heart rate.
    Its property of increasing the force of contraction of the cardiac myocytes without significantly changing the heart rate makes it more useful in chronic conditions.

Option B: Aldosterone antagonists

  • They decrease morbidity and mortality associated with cardiac failure by preventing cardiac remodelling.
  • They are frequently used with ACE inhibitors and ARBs.

Option D: Beta receptor antagonists

  • These drugs can worsen the acute decompensation of heart function.
  • They are more helpful in treating chronic CHF as these reduce mortality by reversing left ventricular hypertrophy.

questions.text: A 13-month-old child is brought to a hospital for severe diarrhea and dermatitis. She is also underweight for her age. Physical examination shows a rash that is distributed beyond the genital area and is prevalent on knees and tissue around the mouth and anus. She has edema of hands and feet, and has alopecia. Which one of the following mineral supplements can most help relieve her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Zinc:

  • Acrodermatitis enteropathica is a rare autosomal recessive disorder affecting zinc absorption.
  • Characterized by skin inflammation (dermatitis) and diarrhea, particularly on the cheeks, elbows, knees, and around the mouth and anus.
  • Administration of zinc with new low osmolarity oral rehydration solutions can reduce the severity and duration of diarrheal episodes.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Lead:

  • Lead exposure leads to various symptoms including memory loss, abdominal pain, and reproductive issues.

Option B - Arsenic:

  • Arsenic toxicity affects endothelial cells and can cause various symptoms including tachycardia and cancers.

Option D - Antimony:

  • Toxicity from antimony therapy can cause respiratory irritation and skin discoloration, with potential carcinogenic effects.

questions.text: Which of the following viruses is involved in causing punched-out ulcers in a a 45-year-old chronic smoker, and a biopsy taken from the edge of the ulcer showed multinucleated squamous epithelial cells and eosinophilic Cowdry 'A' inclusions?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Herpes simplex virus (HSV):

  • The patient likely has viral oesophagitis caused by the herpes simplex virus.
  • It is characterized by the following:-
    • Punched-out ulcers on upper GI endoscopy
    • The biopsy shows cowdry A inclusions and multinucleated cells with nuclear molding and ground glass appearance.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cytomegalovirus (CMV):

  • Shallow ulcerations
  • Cytomegalic cells, typically 2-4 fold larger than normal, contain basophilic cytoplasmic & intranuclear inclusion bodies surrounded by a clear halo, giving the appearance of an owl's eye within capillary endothelium & stromal cells.

Option C - Adenovirus:

  • Adenovirus is unlikely to cause esophagitis. Therefore this option is incorrect

Option D - Coxsackie virus:

  • It rarely causes esophagitis; if it occurs, it is generally mild and does not cause ulcers.
  • Therefore this option is incorrect

questions.text: Which of the following is the mechanism of resistance in Methicillin Resistant Staphulococcus aureus(MRSA)??
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Altered penicillin-binding proteins:

  • MRSA is resistant to all β-lactams because of mecA, a gene that produces a penicillin-binding protein (PBP2a) with low affinity for β-lactam antibiotics.
  • β-lactams like penicillin bind to the Penicillin-binding proteins like transpeptidases through which they inhibit the formation of the cell wall
  • MRSA is mainly acquired through hospitals, but it can also be community-acquired and acquired after an open wound, like in this patient who had a wound in his tibia.
  • The treatment for MRSA is vancomycin
  • The treatment for Vancomycin-resistant Staph aureus is Daptomycin.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C and D are incorrect and do not refer to the correct mechanism of resistance seen in MRSA.

questions.text: Which of the following represents the physiological adaptation of a female breast at puberty?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C- Hypertrophy and hyperplasia:

  • Hormonal hyperplasia is well demonstrated by the proliferation of the glandular epithelium of the female breast at puberty and during pregnancy.
  • It is usually accompanied by the enlargement (hypertrophy) of the glandular epithelial cells.
  • Simultaneous Hypertrophy and Hyperplasia occur in the female breast at puberty.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A- Hypertrophy:

  • Hypertrophy is an increase in the size of the cell.
  • Hyperplasia and hypertrophy are both involved in breast development.

Option B- Hyperplasia:

  • Hyperplasia is an increase in the number of cells.
  • Hyperplasia and hypertrophy are both involved in breast development.

Option D- Atrophy:

  • Atrophy is a decrease in the size of the cell due to increased long-term stress.
  • For example, muscle atrophy due to disuse of the muscle

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common malignant tumor of the spleen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Lymphoma:

  • The most common malignant neoplasm of the spleen is lymphoma (non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma).
  • Lymphoid tumors of the spleen are mainly Hodgkin disease or non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Sarcoma:

  • The most common primary nonlymphoid malignant spleen tumor is angiosarcoma (Hemangiosarcoma).

Option C - Hemangioma:

  • The most common benign tumor of the spleen is the hemangioma.

Option D - Metastasis:

  • Secondary or metastatic tumors are most commonly from melanoma, lung, and breast cancers

questions.text: All are killed vaccines, except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Yellow fever:

  • Yellow Fever Vaccine is an attenuated, live-virus vaccine.
  • This vaccine is given as a single injection given subcutaneously.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, D - 

  • These are examples of killed vaccines.

questions.text: A 50-year-old unrestrained driver is brought to the emergency department following a dashboard injury. A physical examination shows absent pulsations of the femoral artery in the mid-inguinal point and apparent shortening and external rotation of the right limb. FADIR (Flexion, adduction, Internal rotation)  is the attitude of the limb. The patient screams when his right hip region is being examined. X-ray reveals dislocation and fracture of the acetabulum and femoral head. This patient's condition is best managed by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Open reduction:

  • X-ray findings of fracture of femur head and acetabulum leads to the diagnosis of Posterior Dislocation of Hip, Pipkin Type 4.
  • The treatment for dislocation along with a fracture is open reduction.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Allis technique

Option C - Stimson’s gravity method

Option D - Classical Watson Jones method

  • All the above techniques are closed reduction techniques done only in isolated hip dislocations without a fracture.

questions.text: A 30-year-old professional singer complains of hoarseness and a strained voice. She has been performing regularly for the past five years. On examination, there are nodules noted on both vocal cords. Which of the following best describes these nodules?

choices.text: Occurs at the junction of the anterior 1/3rd and posterior 2/3rd of the vocal cord.

questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Occurs at the junction of the anterior 1/3rd and posterior 2/3rd of the vocal cord.

  • Occurs at the junction of the anterior 1/3rd and posterior 2/3rd of the vocal cord: is correct as this describes the location of nodules.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Caused by sudden voice abuse:

  • This is incorrect as vocal nodules are caused by chronic voice abuse, not sudden shouting.

Option C - Unilateral lesions:

  • This is the incorrect answer because vocal polyps are unilateral lesions, meaning they occur on one side of the vocal cord.

Option D- Pedunculated masses:

  • This is incorrect as this describes polyps, not nodules.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the clinic with multiple asymptomatic, well-demarcated, scaly patches on his trunk. On examination, the patches are hypopigmented and do not show any inflammation. The Wood's lamp examination reveals yellowish fluorescence in the affected areas. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C- Pityriasis Versicolor:

  • Pityriasis versicolor, also known as tinea versicolor, is a superficial fungal infection caused by the Malassezia species. It commonly affects young adults and is characterized by multiple well-demarcated, scaly patches that can be hypopigmented, hyperpigmented, or erythematous. The absence of inflammation is a distinguishing feature of this condition. Under a Wood's lamp, the affected areas typically appear yellow-green or coppery-orange fluorescence, which helps confirm the diagnosis.
  • Tinea versicolor is usually a clinical diagnosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Psoriasis: Psoriasis is a chronic autoimmune condition characterized by well-defined, red, scaly plaques with silvery scales. Unlike pityriasis versicolor, psoriasis typically presents with inflammation and erythema. Additionally, Psoriasis is not associated with fluorescence under a Wood's lamp.

Option B - Pityriasis rosea: Pityriasis rosea is a common skin condition that usually begins with a single large pink or red patch called a herald patch, followed by the appearance of numerous smaller oval patches in a Christmas tree distribution. Unlike pityriasis versicolor, which is caused by a fungal infection, pityriasis rosea is believed to have a viral etiology. Pityriasis rosea patches are typically pink or red and do not show fluorescence under a Wood's lamp.

Herald Patch

Christmas Tree / Fir Tree Pattern

Option D - Tinea corporis: Tinea corporis, also known as ringworm, is a fungal infection of the skin characterized by annular erythematous patches with central clearing and an active raised border. It commonly affects the body, including the trunk. Unlike pityriasis versicolor, tinea corporis does not cause hypopigmentation and is associated with inflammation and itching. Wood's lamp examination may or may not reveal fluorescence, depending on the causative fungus.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with a history of liver disease presents with complaints of incoordination, slurred speech, and hand tremors. On examination, the ophthalmologist observes a characteristic brownish-golden ring at the periphery of the cornea. Which of the following statements is not true regarding the disease the patient is suffering from?

choices.text: The ring starts superiorly and inferiorly first.
Ring is formed due to deposition of the copper.
All cases with hepatic involvement will present with the ring.
Most cases with Neurological involvement will present with the ring.

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - All cases with hepatic involvement will present with the ring:

  • The patient is suffering from Wilson disease, and the brownish-golden ring is a Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring.
  • Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring is a characteristic sign of Wilson's disease, a genetic disorder that results in the accumulation of copper in various organs, including the liver, brain, and eye.
  • While KF rings are commonly associated with Wilson's disease, not all cases with hepatic involvement will necessarily present with these rings; only 65% of cases will show KF rings. The presence of KF rings is often seen in patients with neurological (95% cases) involvement rather than hepatic involvement.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - The ring starts superiorly and inferiorly first: This statement is true. In Wilson's disease, Kayser-Fleischer (KF) rings typically start to appear at the superior and inferior portions of the cornea due to the deposition of copper. Over time, the ring becomes more complete.

Option B - Ring is formed due to the deposition of copper: This statement is true. KF rings are indeed formed due to the deposition of copper in Descemet's cornea membrane.

Option D - Most cases with Neurological involvement will present with the ring: This statement is true. KF rings are often associated with neurological involvement in Wilson's disease. While not all patients with Wilson's disease will have neurological symptoms, when neurological symptoms are present, KF rings are more likely to be observed as well.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with the complaint of shortness of breath and cough. A diagnosis of COPD is made after a thorough assessment. During the ward round, the pulmonologist explains to the junior residents the physiology of pneumocytes. Which among the following statements regarding the alveolar epithelial cells is false?

choices.text: Gas exchange occurs via the type I pneumocytes
Lamellar inclusion bodies are seen in type II pneumocytes
Type III pneumocytes act as chemoreceptors
Type II and type I exist in a ratio of 1:2

questions.solution:
Option C. Type III pneumocytes act as chemoreceptors

This statement is false. There is no specific classification of alveolar epithelial cells known as Type III pneumocytes. The alveolar epithelium primarily consists of two main types:

Option A. Gas exchange occurs via the type I pneumocytes - This statement is true. Type I pneumocytes, also known as squamous or flat pneumocytes, are responsible for gas exchange in the alveoli. They are thin and flat, providing a large surface area for efficient diffusion of gases like oxygen and carbon dioxide across the alveolar membrane.

Option B. Lamellar inclusion bodies are seen in type II pneumocytes - This statement is true. Lamellar inclusion bodies, also known as lamellar bodies, are characteristic organelles found in Type II pneumocytes. These bodies contain surfactant, a substance that reduces surface tension in the alveoli and prevents their collapse.

Option D. Type II and type I exist in a ratio of 1:2 - This statement is true. Type II pneumocytes, also known as septal or great pneumocytes, are responsible for producing pulmonary surfactant, which is crucial for maintaining alveolar stability and preventing atelectasis (lung collapse). The ratio between Type I and Type II pneumocytes is approximately 1:2.

questions.text: A 20-year-old boy suffering from congenital deficiency of muscle phosphorylase is getting examined by an ischemic forearm exercise test by squeezing a rubber ball. This patient would exhibit which one of the following as compared to a normal person performing the same test?

choices.text: Increased blood glucose in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein
Increased lactate in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein
Relatively decreased blood lactate in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein

questions.solution:
Correct option D: Relatively decreased blood lactate in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein

  • Normal or low blood lactate and increased blood ammonia after an ischemic exercise test suggest a defect in the conversion of glycogen (glucose) to lactate.
  • This is observed in the case of McArdle's disease, which occurs due to a deficiency of muscle glycogen phosphorylase enzyme such that glycogen cannot be converted to glucose and further to lactate in exercising muscle.
  • Hence, relatively low levels of lactate will be formed from muscle glycogen after exercise compared to a normal individual.
  • Another thing that happens is that due to a lack of energy and ATP, muscle cells get damaged. Hence myoglobin will be released in urine, causing myoglobinuria.
  • Definitive diagnosis of this disease can be done by:
    • Enzymatic assay in muscle tissue
    • Mutation analysis of the myophosphorylase gene
  • Abnormal exercise response also occurs with
    • Deficiencies of muscle phosphofructokinase
    • Deficiencies of the debranching enzyme (when the test is done after fasting).

Incorrect options

Option A: Exercise endurance

  • Any type of glycogen storage disease in muscles causes exercise intolerance and muscle cramps due to a lack of stored muscle glycogen utilization.
  • So, in McArdle’s disease also, there is no chance of developing exercise endurance.

Option B: Increased  blood glucose in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein

  • Muscle cells can take glucose from the blood during exercise, but muscle glycogen cannot contribute to blood glucose due to a lack of a glucose-6-phosphatase enzyme.
  • So, there can’t be any increased blood glucose in the blood vein of exercising forearm; rather, it will show decreased blood glucose

Option C: Increased lactate in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein

  • In glycogen phosphorylase deficiency, free glucose is not generated
  • Hence no lactate is formed due to a lack of glucose
  • Therefore, the blood level of lactate falls.

questions.text: Which of the following methods is most appropriate to sterilize devices that come in contact with mucous membranes according to the Spaulding Classification?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - High-Level Disinfection (HLD):

  • The Spaulding classification stratifies the risk of infection transmission based on the patient tissue the device contacts during use. Devices that come in contact with mucous membranes are semi-critical devices.
  • Semi-critical devices require a high level of disinfection to ensure the elimination of all vegetative bacteria, mycobacteria, fungi, and most viruses, but not necessarily bacterial spores. High-level disinfection (HLD) is a reprocessing method sterilizing using heat if the device is heat stable or chemical (glutaraldehyde, formaldehyde, and chlorine) if heat sensitive that achieves this level of disinfection.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Intermediate-Level Disinfection (ILD): Intermediate-Level Disinfection is used for non-critical devices 

Option C - Low-Level Disinfection (LLD): Low-Level Disinfection is used for Non-Critical Devices that come in contact with the skin. LLD aims to reduce the number of viable microorganisms on these devices but does not achieve the same level of disinfection as HLD.

Option D - Dry Heat Sterilization: Dry Heat Sterilization is a method used for Critical Devices that can withstand high temperatures. It is not commonly used for Semi-Critical Devices, as it is generally reserved for devices that require complete sterilization.

questions.text: Which of the following is the root value of the superior gluteal nerve?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - L4, L5, S1:

  • The superior gluteal nerve root is L4, L5, and S1.
  • The superior gluteal nerve supplies Gluteus medius, Gluteus minimus, and Tensor fasciae latae.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: L2, 3, 4

  • The obturator nerve emerges from the anterior division of the L2, L3, and L4 ventral rami

Option C:T12, L1, L2

  • The ilioinguinal and iliohypogastric originate from the T12, and L1 nerve roots but not the obturator nerve
    • innervation common to both nerves- External oblique, internal oblique, transversus abdominis muscles of anterior abdominal wall

Option A:L1, 2, 3

  • The genitofemoral nerve originates from the L1 nerve root
    • Innervation- 

      Cremaster muscle in the scrotum in male; skin over anterior surface of the thigh; nervous pathway for cremasteric reflex

  • The lateral femoral cutaneous nerve originates from L2, L3
    • Innervation- Skin of anterior and lateral surfaces of the thigh

questions.text:
Mark the option with correct statements regarding Diabetes insipidus.

a) Urine output>3L/day

b) First line drug for central DI is Indomethacin

c) Reduced Plasma Osmolarity

d) Miller Moses test is used for evaluation
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - a,d:

  • a)Urine output>3L/day-Polyuria
  • d)Miller Moses test which is a Water deprivation test is used for the evaluation of diabetes insipidus.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - b,c:

  • b) First line drug for central diabetes insipidus is Desmopressin and not Indomethacin
