  • c) Diabetes insipidus leads to reduced Urine Osmolarity and increased Plasma Osmolarity

Option C & D - (a,c & b,d): Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient has been diagnosed with stage III locally advanced breast cancer. As part of her treatment plan, she undergoes neoadjuvant chemotherapy. She shows a partial response to chemotherapy, and a reduction in the size of the mass is noted. The patient is scheduled for a modified radical mastectomy (MRM). After the mastectomy, axillary dissection is started for axillary lymph node dissection (ALND). What is the superolateral boundary of axillary dissection?
questions.solution:
Option D: Axillary vein

  • Axillary Node Dissection is the standard initial approach for breast cancer patients who are clinically node-positive.
  • The boundaries of standard axillary lymph node dissection are
    • Laterally: Axillary pad of fat
    • Posteriorly: Latissimus dorsi, Teres major and subscapularis, thoracodorsal and long thoracic nerves
    • Superiorly: Lower border of the axillary vein
    • Anteriorly: Pectoralis muscle
    • Medially: Chest wall (serratus anterior muscle)
  • There are three levels of axillary lymph nodes related to the pectoralis minor muscle, as shown in the table.

Level I

Level II

Level III

Lateral to the edge of the pectoralis minor muscle

Includes

  • External mammary
  • Subscapular
  • Lateral axillary lymph nodes

Behind or posterior to the muscle

Central axillary lymph node

Medial or superior to the pectoralis minor muscle

Includes

  • Sub clavicular or apical lymph nodes

 

 

Option A: Clavipectoral fascia

  • Clavipectoral fascia (costocoracoid membrane; coracoclavicular fascia) is a strong fascia situated under the clavicular portion of the pectoralis major.
  • It occupies the interval between the pectoralis minor and subclavius and protects the axillary vessels and nerves.
  • It is related anteriorly to the axillary lymph nodes by relation to the pectoralis minor.

Option B: Brachial plexus

  • The brachial plexus passes from the neck to the axilla and supplies the upper limb.

Option C: Axillary artery

  • The axillary artery is divided into three parts related to the pectoralis minor muscle.
  • The first part is proximal to the pectoralis minor, the second is posterior to the pectoralis minor, and the third is distal to the pectoralis minor.
  • It is related anteriorly to the axillary lymph nodes.

questions.text: A patient wakes up in the middle of the night and claims to see a large spider crawling on the ceiling. Upon closer examination, it is discovered that it was actually a wall hanging. This is an example of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Illusion 

  • Illusion refers to a false perception or misinterpretation of a real object or stimulus. It occurs when the brain misinterprets sensory information, leading to a distorted perception of reality. In the given scenario, the patient's perception of seeing a spider on the ceiling, which is actually a misinterpretation of the real object (such as a rope or curtain), is an example of an illusion.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Delusion: Delusion refers to a false belief held by an individual despite evidence to the contrary. It is a fixed, irrational belief that is not influenced by logical reasoning. In the context of the given scenario, the patient's perception of seeing a spider on the ceiling is not a delusion because it is a perceptual experience rather than a belief.

Option B - Hallucination: Hallucination is a false perception that occurs without any external stimulus. It involves experiencing sensory perceptions that are not based on reality. In the given scenario, the patient's perception of seeing a spider on the ceiling is not a hallucination because there is a real object present (the wall hanging), although the perception of the spider is false.

Option D - Disorientation: Disorientation refers to a state of confusion or loss of awareness regarding one's surroundings, time, or identity. It is characterized by a difficulty in recognizing or comprehending the environment. Disorientation is not applicable to the given scenario as the patient's perception of the spider on the ceiling does not indicate a state of confusion or loss of awareness.

questions.text:
The base of the femoral triangle is formed by:


	1 - Inguinal ligament
	2 - Medial border of sartorius muscle
	3 - Medial border of adductor longus muscle
	4 - Iliacus muscle
questions.solution:
Option A: 1 Only

Statement 1: Inguinal Ligament.

The triangle mentioned here is a femoral triangle.

  • The inguinal ligament is a set of two bands connecting the abdomen's oblique muscles to the pelvis, deep in the groin 
  • They support soft tissues in the groin area and anchor the abdomen and pelvis.
  • The base of the femoral triangle is the inguinal ligament which is aponeurosis of external oblique muscle.

 

 

Boundaries of Femoral Triangle:

  • The inguinal ligament forms the base of the femoral triangle.
  • The medial border of the adductor longus forms the medial boundary.
  • The medial border of Sartorius forms the lateral boundary.
  • Floor is formed by adductor longus, pectineus and iliacus.

 Content of femoral triangle :-The femoral artery, femoral vein, femoral nerve and lymphatics.

Incorrect statements

  • Statement 2: Medial border of the sartorius. It's a false statement, as the medial border of Sartorius makes the lateral boundary of the femoral triangle.
  • Statement 3: Medial border of adductor longus: The medial border of the adductor longus forms the medial boundary of the femoral triangle.
  • Statement 4: Iliacus. The floor is formed by the adductor longus, pectineus, and iliacus.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with a family history of glaucoma visits the ophthalmology clinic for a comprehensive eye examination. The ophthalmologist decides to perform an investigation to assess the patient's iridocorneal angle without inducing pupil dilatation. Which of the following investigations is most suitable for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Gonioscopy:

  • Gonioscopy is a technique used to examine the iridocorneal angle (the angle between the iris and the cornea) and is commonly performed without pupil dilation. It allows for the assessment of the drainage angle and is important in diagnosing and managing conditions such as glaucoma.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Fluorescein Angiography:

  • Fluorescein angiography typically requires pupil dilation. This procedure involves injecting a fluorescent dye into the bloodstream to highlight the blood vessels in the retina. Pupil dilation enhances the visualization of the retinal vasculature during this imaging study.

Option C - Fundoscopy:

  • Pupil dilation is often recommended for fundoscopy. The procedure is generally more effective and comprehensive when the pupil is dilated. Dilation provides a wider and clearer view of the retina and optic nerve head, enhancing the ability to detect various eye conditions.

Option D - Goldmann applanation tonometry:

  • Goldmann applanation tonometry is a method used to measure intraocular pressure (IOP). However, it doesn't involve assessing the iridocorneal angle, and pupil dilatation is not required for this procedure

questions.text: Which of the following complications of myocardial infarction is expected between 3-7 days after the infarction?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Myocardial rupture:

  • Complications of Myocardial Infarction

  • Myocardial rupture occurs in 1-5% of cases and is usually fatal.
  • The most common site of rupture is the left ventricular wall. The free wall rupture leads to hemopericardium and cardiac tamponade, which is rapidly fatal.
  • Ventricular septal rupture may cause ventricular septal defect with a left-to-right shunt.
  • Papillary muscle rupture causes severe mitral regurgitation.
  • It occurs between 3-7 days after infarction when the necrotic myocardium is being lysed, and the infarct is converted to soft, friable granulation tissue.
  • Risk factors for myocardial rupture include age greater than 60 years, anterior or lateral wall infarction, female gender, absence of left ventricular hypertrophy, and first myocardial infarction.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Arrhythmia:

  • MI-associated arrhythmia includes asystole, bradycardia, supraventricular tachyarrhythmias, and ventricular fibrillation.
  • The risk of arrhythmias is greatest after 1 hour of MI and decreases after that.

Option B - Mural thrombosis:

  • Any infarct combined with decreased contractility, chamber dilation, and endocardial damage can cause the formation of a mural thrombus.
  • This can lead to left-sided thromboembolism.
  • The risk of mural thrombus formation is high in the first 3 months after MI.

Option C - Pericarditis:

  • Pericarditis usually occurs after 2-3 days of MI.
  • The risk decreases afterwards.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe respiratory distress due to upper airway obstruction. His vital signs are as follows: Heart rate 120 bpm, blood pressure 90/60 mmHg, respiratory rate 28 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation 85% on room air. Physical examination reveals stridor and significant use of accessory muscles. Intubation attempts have failed. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D: Perform cricothyrotomy

  • Cricothyrotomy involves piercing the cricothyroid membrane during an emergency to access the airway directly. This procedure is indicated when traditional methods of securing the airway, such as endotracheal intubation, have failed or are not feasible.
  • Cricothyrotomy provides a reliable and rapid means of establishing an airway in critical situations.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Administer intravenous steroids:

  • While intravenous steroids may be beneficial in certain cases of upper airway obstruction, they do not address the immediate need for securing the airway. This patient is in severe respiratory distress, and prompt airway management is essential.

Option B- Perform endotracheal intubation again:

  • If initial intubation attempts have failed, repeating the procedure may not be successful and can lead to further delay in securing the airway. It's crucial to consider other options.

Option C- Initiate bag-mask ventilation:

  • Bag-mask ventilation is an effective temporary measure for ventilating a patient with a compromised airway. However, in this case, the patient's condition is critical, and a more definitive airway management technique is required.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man post orthotopic liver transplantation presents with decreased bile production during the first 3 days. Reperfusion injury is thought to be the cause of Poor graft function in this patient. Which of the following substances is most likely to cause reperfusion injury in the transplanted liver?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Reactive oxygen species:

  • Ischemia/reperfusion injury is a common clinical problem in occlusive cardiovascular disease, transplantation, infection, shock, and many other circumstances.
  • The beginning of injury caused by ischemia and reperfusion is linked to the interaction between the temporary lack of blood flow and the restoration of blood flow. When ischemia occurs, it damages the cells and generates free radical species.
  • Subsequently, reperfusion provides abundant molecular oxygen (O2) combined with free radicals to form reactive oxygen and nitrogen species. Oxygen radicals are formed inside cells through the xanthine oxidase pathway and cause reperfusion injury.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cationic proteins:

  • Cationic proteins, which are eosinophilic, are found in the body fluids of patients with allergic and inflammatory diseases. Their secretions are induced by immunoglobulins, complement factors, and serum-opsonized particles.

Option B - Free ferric iron:

  • Transition metals such as iron and copper donate or accept free electrons during intracellular reactions and catalyze free radical formation. This is done by ferrous(Fe2+) and not ferric(3+).

Option C - Hydrochlorous acid:

  • Hydrochloric acid is a weak acid that forms when chlorine dissolves in water and partially dissociates.
  • It is a weak acid that does not have any reactive properties, so it is not involved in reperfusion injury.

questions.text:
Below are the X-ray images of the fracture of the femoral neck. Categorize them according to Garden classification.



       C.                                                                   D. 

 

1) Non-aligned trabecular pattern

2) Valgus imapacted

3) Parallel trabecular pattern

4) Undisplaced fracture
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - A-2, B-4, C-1, D-3:

Gardens classification:

  • Grade 1-Valgus impacted
  • Grade 2-Undisplaced fracture
  • Grade 3-Non-aligned trabecular pattern
  • Grade 4-Parallel trabecular pattern with external rotation of distal fragment

Incorrect Options:

Option A - A-4, B-3, C-2, D-1

Option B - A-4, B-2, C-3, D-1

Option C - A-2, B-1, C-4, D-3

questions.text: Which of the following is a condition involving a patient with chronic Daytime hypoventilation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Obesity Hypoventilation Syndrome: 

Obesity Hypoventilation Syndrome

  • Patient has Chronic Daytime hypoventilation.

Incorrect Options:

Option B- Obstructive Sleep Apnea-Hypopnea Syndrome (OSAHS): Associated with hypoventilation in the night time

Option C & D- Central Hypoventilation Syndrome and ONDINE’s curse: These are same -Absent response of sensors to hypoxia

questions.text: A 15-month-old boy is brought to the hospital for a burn injury. Baby fell into a tub of hot water, father pulled him out and poured water at room temparture over affected areas of lower extremities, abdomen and torso. The burns were initially described as not too bad but later developed into blisters. The best method to assess burns caused by boiling water in a child is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Modified Lund and Browder chart:

Modifiedlund and Browder Chart

  • Takes into account different proportional body surface areas in children according to age.
  • Different percentages are used as the ratio of head and neck surface to the body surface is greater in children than in adults.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Palm method:

  • In the case of smaller burns or patches of burn
  • The palmar surface of the hand of the person who is burned (not the fingers or wrist area) accounts for 1 % of total body surface area (TBSA) and is useful for calculating the percentage of burns

Option B - Rule of 9:

  • It is not the most accurate method for the calculation of TBSA.
  • The ‘rule of nines’ is adequate for a first approximation only.
  • It is a crude but quick and effective method of estimating burn size.

Option D - Parkland formula:

  • Parkland formula is used to calculate the amount of fluid needed for resuscitation.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presented with pain, redness, and blurred vision in his left eye. On examination, there is miosis, aqueous cells, and flare in the anterior chamber. What is the direct role of cycloplegics in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Increase the production of aqueous humor
To prevent the formation of posterior synechiae

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - To prevent the formation of posterior synechiae :

  • Cycloplegics help prevent the formation of posterior synechiae by keeping the iris mobile in a patient suffering from anterior uveitis. Cycloplegics can also break recent posterior synechiae.

  • Other role of cycloplegics:

    • Cycloplegics give rest to ciliary muscles. Therefore, relieves pain.

    • Prevents posterior synechiae by keeping the iris mobile.

    • Breaks fresh posterior synechiae.

    • Improves blood supply- Leads to better healing.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Increase the production of aqueous humor: Cycloplegics do not have a direct effect on the production of aqueous humor.

Option C - To decrease intraocular pressure: Cycloplegics do not directly decrease intraocular pressure. They primarily affect the ciliary muscle and accommodation.

Option D - To promote corneal healing: Cycloplegics are not directly involved in promoting corneal healing. Their primary role is related to managing inflammation and accommodation in the context of uveitis.

questions.text: What's the likely diagnosis for a 57-year-old woman presenting with left breast pain and redness, which on examination were swollen, tender, and erythematous, showing a peau d'orange appearance and a completely retracted left nipple, despite no prior medical visits in the past decade?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Inflammatory carcinoma:

  • Inflammatory carcinoma is caused by carcinoma plugging lymphovascular spaces, resulting in swelling and nipple retraction.

  • Although it is called inflammatory carcinoma, there is no inflammation present.

  • This is usually of high grade and has distant metastasis.

  • It has a very poor prognosis.

  • Common symptoms are

    • Pain

    • Erythema

    • Dimpling of skin (peau d'orange)

    • Skin thickening

    • Usually, no palpable mass is present

  • "Peau d'orange" refers to the appearance of skin that resembles the texture of an orange peel. This effect is caused by cutaneous lymphatic edema, the presence of sweat ducts in the affected skin area prevents swelling, resulting in a dimpled appearance similar to that of orange skin.

  • The presentation is similar to breast infections, resulting in delayed diagnosis.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Granulomatous mastitis:

  • It is a rare breast disease that can manifest  in case of systemic granulomatous disease (Sarcoidosis, Tuberculosis, and so on).

  • The presence of granulomas adjacent to lobules is the histologic pattern, which may contain lipids.

  • Histologically, the pattern resembles cystic neutrophilic granulomatous mastitis.

  • It should be treated with antibiotics and, in some cases, steroids.

Option B - Micropapillary carcinoma:

  • Micropapillary carcinoma forms a cell ball that floats in intercellular fluid.

  • It forms a structure similar to true papillae.

Option C - Fibrocystic disease of the breast:

  • Fibrocystic disease is characterised by the formation of cysts and stromal fibrosis.

  • Smaller cysts then combine to form larger cysts.

  • It is a benign breast condition.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with severe refractory dysmenorrhea; she says she has been getting painkiller injections for the past 8 months for this condition. The doctor advises her diagnostic laparoscopy that reveals black-brown powder burn-like lesions on peritoneal surfaces and also covering bilateral tubes, which is sent for biopsy. The report says there is a presence of haemorrhage and the endometrial glands. Which of the following is the LEAST likely mechanism for her dysmenorrhea?

choices.text: Collection of shed menstrual blood in implants

questions.solution:
Option D : SEPTIC SEEDING OF IMPLANTS:

History of dysmenorrhea, powder burn like lesions and biopsy with endometrial glands are all suggestive of a diagnosis of endometriosis. Endometriotic implants are aseptic in nature that cause deep peritoneal inflammation, which on healing causes adhesions and fibrosis. Possible mechanisms causing pain in patients with endometriosis include:-

  • Local peritoneal inflammation,
  • Deep infiltration with tissue damage,
  • Adhesion formation,
  • Fibrotic thickening,
  • Collection of shed menstrual blood in endometriotic implants, resulting in painful traction with the physiologic movement of tissues.

Option A : LOCAL PERITONEAL INFLAMMATION:

  • There is local peritoneal inflammation at the site of implants

Option B : DEEP INFILTRATION WITH TISSUE DAMAGE:

  • These implants infiltrate the tissues deeply which along with inflammation, is responsible for pain.

Option C :COLLECTION OF SHED MENSTRUAL BLOOD IN IMPLANTS:

  • These implants containing endometriotic glands and stroma and are therefore associated with collection of blood at each menstrual cycle.

questions.text: Which step in MLPA (Multiplex Ligation dependent Probe Amplification) aids in the detection of mutations in the CFTR gene, contributing to the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Ligation of two probes:

  • The ligation of 2 probes is the crucial step in MLPA as suggested by the name Multiplex Ligation-dependent Probe Amplification.

  • Steps involved in MLPA (Multiplex Ligation-dependent Probe Amplification)

    Step

    Description

    Denaturation

    Separation of double-stranded DNA into single strands to prepare for further processing.

    Annealing

    Use of multiple probes to bind to specific DNA sequences within the sample.

    Ligation

    Joining of two adjacent probes if properly annealed, indicating specific DNA sequences.

    Amplification

    Multiplication of ligated probes for further analysis, enabling detection of mutations.

Here's how this step is significant in mutation detection within the CFTR gene:

  1. Probe Design: Multiple probes are designed to target specific sequences within the CFTR gene associated with cystic fibrosis. These probes are designed to bind to their complementary sequences in the patient's DNA sample.
  2. Annealing and Ligation: During the annealing step, the probes attach to their respective target sequences. Following this, if two adjacent probes have successfully bound to their respective sequences, the ligation step involves the joining or ligating of these probes when they are in close proximity. This step occurs only when the two specific probes have successfully hybridized to adjacent DNA sequences in the patient's sample.
  3. Mutation Detection: The successful ligation of two probes indicates the absence or presence of specific sequences in the patient's DNA. The presence or absence of these sequences, determined through the ligation of probes, helps in identifying mutations or variations in the CFTR gene associated with cystic fibrosis

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Denaturation process: This step involves the separation of the double-stranded DNA into single strands, which is an initial preparatory step. Denaturation helps to make the DNA accessible for further processing, but it doesn’t directly contribute to mutation detection.

Option B - Annealing using multiple probes: In this step, multiple probes specifically designed to target particular sequences within the CFTR gene attach or hybridize to their complementary sequences in the patient's DNA sample. While this step is crucial for targeting specific gene regions associated with cystic fibrosis, it alone doesn't identify mutations; rather, it prepares the DNA for further steps.

Option D - Amplification for probe analysis: After the ligation step, the resulting products, if formed, are amplified. This amplification creates multiple copies of the ligated probes, which are then analyzed for the presence or absence of specific sequences. Although essential for obtaining a quantifiable amount of the DNA sequence of interest, the amplification step itself doesn't directly detect mutations in the CFTR gene.

questions.text: A 39-year-old female presents to Gynecology OPD with complaints of menorrhagia and irregular cycles for the last 8 months. She has been married for 6 years and has 3 children. Her pelvic examination is unremarkable. She is counselled on using Mirena (LNG-IUCD) as a contraceptive method and treatment for her long-standing menorrhagia. Which of the following mechanisms is irrelevant for a reduced risk of upper genital tract infection?
questions.solution:
Option B: Decreased ovulation

  • It is the correct option. She is suffering from PID. Reducing ovulation will not affect the incidence of PID.
  • The pathophysiology of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) involves an ascending infection of microorganisms, of which the most important pathogens are Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • Reducing ovulation is under hormonal control, which is regulated by the hypothalamus.

  • Any woman's ovarian cycle plays a role in susceptibility to infection.
  • These women are most prone to infection during ovulation, such as Candida Albicans or other sexually transmitted diseases.

Option A: Reduced retrograde menstruation

  • Reducing menstruation with progesterone will eventually also reduce the amount of retrograde menstruation.

Option C: Thickened cervical mucus

  • All other factors help reduce the physical transport of bacteria, like the thick cervical mucus.

Option D: Decrease the incidence of surgical abortion

  • It decreases the incidence of surgical abortions by preventing unwanted pregnancies.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman attended the outpatient department with a lump measuring 5x4cm in the upper outer quadrant of her right breast. A fine needle aspiration cytology of the lump revealed invasive ductal carcinoma. As a result, she underwent a Patey's modified radical mastectomy. During the procedure, which structure is preserved?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Pectoralis major:

  • In Patey’s modified mastectomy, the pectoralis major is preserved.
  • En-bloc removal of nipple, areola, skin, breast tissue, breast mass + removal of  Level 1, 2, & 3 lymph nodes + excision of pectoralis minor

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C & D Are not preserved.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a burn injury 2 hours ago. Examination reveals second-degree burns covering 20% of the total body surface area. The patient is immediately resuscitated with fluids. Which of the following fluids is most commonly used in the patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Ringer lactate

  • Ringer Lactate is the most commonly used fluid in burn patients.
  • Hartmann’s solution or Ringer’s lactate is the most commonly used crystalloid as it most closely replicates the osmolality of plasma. It is considerably less expensive than colloid and can maintain intravascular volume.
  • There are three main fuids used in the resuscitation stage: crystalloid (by far the most common), colloid and, in some centres, hypertonic saline.
  • Intravenous resuscitation is appropriate for any child with a burn greater than 10% of total body surface area (TBSA) and 15% TBSA for adults
  • Rule of 9 is used to calculate the body surface area with a burn.
  • The most widely used and simplest formula to calculate fluid requirement is the Parkland formula in adults
    • Volume = total percentage body surface area x weight (kg) x 2
    • Half this volume is given in the first 8 hours, and the second half is given in the subsequent 16 hours

Option A: Dextrose 5%

  • Dextrose 5 % is a hypotonic fluid.
  • It is used to cover the free water deficit. It is not the best choice for burn patients.

Option B: Normal saline

  • Normal saline is not used in burn patients as it contains chloride in an increased amount, and it can lead to hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis.
  • Normal saline also increases the risk for hypercoagulability.

Option D: Albumin 5%

  • Albumin 5% is a colloid. It is used in patients with hepatorenal syndrome and spontaneous bacterial peritonitis.
  • Although it can be used in burn patients,  it is not the most commonly used fluids.

questions.text: During which phase of the cardiac cycle is the second heart sound (S2) generated?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Isovolumetric relaxation:

  • The second heart sound happens at the start of the isovolumic relaxation. The duration of this heart sound is 0.12 seconds. It occurs due to the closure of the semilunar valve.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Isovolumetric contraction:

  • The first heart sound occurs at the beginning of isovolumic contraction, not the second.

Option C - First rapid filling:

  • The second heart sound is not generated during the first rapid-filling phase.

Option D - Diastasis:

  • The second heart sound is not generated during the Diastasis phase.

questions.text: A 17-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe abdominal pain. The pain initially started in the umbilical region and is now located in the right lower quadrant. He was diagnosed with acute appendicitis after an initial workup, and surgery is scheduled. During the procedure, the surgeon uses an instrument to hold the inflamed appendix, as shown below. What is the name of the following instrument?
questions.solution:
Option A: Babcock’s forceps

  • The image given above is of Babcock’s forceps.
  • It has the following features:
    • The terminal part is curved
    • It has fenestrations to accommodate delicate structures
    • It is a non-traumatic instrument

Option B: Ovum forceps

  • Ovum Forceps grip, hold, manipulate, and remove uterine tissue, including the ovum and placenta.
  • Ovum forceps are used as a hemostat during surgeries such as cesarean section, hysterectomy, and uterine repair.

Option C: Allis tissue forceps

  • An Allis clamp, also known as an Allis forceps, is a popular surgical device.
  • The Allis clamp is a sharp-toothed surgical device to grip or grab thick tissue. It may also grip fascia and soft tissues like breast or bowel tissue
  • Because Allis clamps can cause harm, they are frequently utilised in tissue that will be removed.
  • When used to hold the cervix to support the uterus, such as when inserting an intrauterine device, an Allis clamp causes less bleeding than the more regularly employed tenaculum.

Option D: Sponge holding forceps

 

  • During surgical operations and inspections, plastic sponge forceps are used to grab and hold sponges and swabs.
  • Surgeons and physicians can use sponge forceps to insert and keep dressings in place.

questions.text: A 43-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of joint pain and stiffness, particularly in her hands, for the past six months. On examination, there is tenderness and swelling noted in multiple joints in the hands. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated levels of inflammatory markers. Additionally, her serum lipid profile shows decreased levels of eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA). Which of the following is a source of eicosapentaenoic acid?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Fish oil:

  • The patient in the clinical vignette most likely has an inflammatory disease. Chronic inflammatory diseases are often associated with anemia and nutritional deficiencies.
  • Eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) is a type of omega-3 fatty acid known for its anti-inflammatory properties.
  • It is commonly found in fish oil. Fish oil is derived from the tissues of oily fish such as salmon, mackerel, herring, and sardines.
  • It is a rich source of EPA and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA), both of which are essential for overall health, particularly cardiovascular health and reducing inflammation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Sunflower oil:

  • Sunflower oil is predominantly composed of omega-6 fatty acids, particularly linoleic acid. While omega-6 fatty acids are also essential for health, they are not a significant source of eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA).

Option C - Flaxseed oil:

  • Flaxseed oil is a plant-based source of omega-3 fatty acids, specifically alpha-linolenic acid (ALA).
  • However, the conversion of ALA to EPA and DHA in the body is limited, making flaxseed oil less effective in providing eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) than fish oil.

Option D - Soybean oil:

  • Soybean oil is rich in omega-6 fatty acids (linolenic acid) and contains minimal amounts of omega-3 fatty acids.
  • Similar to sunflower oil, it is not a significant source of eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA).

questions.text: A 9-year-old child is exhibiting symptoms of inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity. The symptoms have been present for the past 8 months and are observed both at school and at home. The parents are seeking advice regarding the most appropriate medication for their child. The child does not have any known cardiac issues, and the family history is negative for cardiac problems. What is the drug of choice for the patient in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Methylphenidate (ADHD): Methylphenidate is the drug of choice for the treatment of ADHD, as mentioned in the provided information. It is a CNS stimulant and is commonly used as the first-line pharmacotherapy for ADHD in children. It helps improve attention, reduce hyperactivity, and manage impulsivity.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Atomoxetine (ADHD): Atomoxetine is a non-stimulant medication used in the treatment of ADHD. While it can be an alternative for individuals who cannot tolerate stimulant medications or have specific contraindications, such as cardiac issues, it is not the first-line drug of choice according to the information provided.

Option C - Clonidine (ADHD): Clonidine is an α-2 agonist that can be used as an adjunctive treatment for ADHD, particularly in cases where stimulant medications exacerbate tics or in individuals with comorbid tic disorders. However, it is not the first-line drug of choice for ADHD, as mentioned in the information provided.

Option D - Amphetamine (ADHD): Amphetamine, similar to methylphenidate, is a CNS stimulant and can be used in the treatment of ADHD. However, it is not the first-line drug of choice, as mentioned in the provided information. It may be considered as an alternative when methylphenidate fails to provide an adequate response.

questions.text: Forty-five years old women experience lower abdominal pain and foul-smelling vaginal discharge. Which of the following is INCORRECT for the clinical presentation of a patient with puerperal fever?

choices.text: Most persistent fevers after childbirth are caused by genital tract infection.
Breast engorgement can be a cause of fever in puerperium
Occurrence of puerperal mastitis requires abandoning breast feeding

questions.solution:
Option D : Clinical presentation of a patient with puerperal fever -

  • Fever of 38.0°C (100.4°F) or higher—in the puerperium.
  • Puerperal fever can be due to -
    • Pelvic infection or endometritis
    • Breast engorgement, mastitis or abscess
    • Urinary tract infections
    • Infected episiotomy, abdominal incisions, or perineal lacerations
    • Respiratory complications
    • Thrombophlebitis

Acute puerperal mastitis presents as fever with chills, myalgia, malaise, engorged and tender breast and is mostly unilateral.Approximately 10 percent of women with mastitis develop an abscess which requires incision and drainage.Rx- Breast milk expression, antibiotics. Breast feeding must be continued.

Puerperal fever is a fever that occurs after childbirth, usually within the first 10 days postpartum. It is often caused by infection in the genital tract. The common signs and symptoms of puerperal fever include a temperature of 38.0°C (100.4°F) or higher, lower abdominal pain, foul-smelling vaginal discharge, and uterine tenderness.

Breast engorgement, which is the swelling and discomfort of the breasts due to an increased blood flow and milk production after childbirth, can also cause fever. However, this condition does not require abandoning breastfeeding. In fact, frequent breastfeeding and proper latching techniques can help relieve breast engorgement and prevent complications like mastitis, which is inflammation of the breast tissue. Mastitis can also cause fever and is usually treated with antibiotics while continuing breastfeeding. Therefore, option d is incorrect in the context of puerperal fever.

Option A : Fever of 38.0°C (100.4°F) or higher—in the puerperium.

Option B : Most persistent fevers after childbirth are caused by genital tract infection.

Option C : Breast engorgement can be a cause of fever in puerperium. It occurs when the milk production exceeds milk extraction by the baby. It is easily treated with hot fomentation and frequent breast feeding or breast milk expression.

questions.text: What is the base sequence of RNA formed from the template strand during mRNA synthesis?
questions.solution:
Correct option A: CGGUAAAGCUUA

DNA and RNA:

  • DNA is the basic unit of life. At the same time, RNA is involved in the synthesis of proteins.
  • DNA is deoxyribonucleic acid, while RNA is ribonucleic acid.
  • DNA is divided into nuclear DNA and mitochondrial DNA. Transfer RNA, messenger RNA, and ribosomal RNA are the main types of RNA.
  • The bases present in DNA are adenine, guanine, cytosine, and thymine. In RNA, thymine is replaced by uracil.
  • DNA is a double-stranded structure, while RNA is single-stranded.
  • DNA contains an antiparallel helix while RNA structure is a hairpin and loops.
  • The process by which DNA is converted into RNA is known as transcription.
  • During this process, the coding strand, also known as the template strand of DNA, is used to synthesize RNA.
  • The direction of new RNA is always the same as the non-template strand; however, the thymine is replaced by uracil.

Incorrect options

Option B: AUUCGAAAUGGC

  • It does not show the transcription of the non-template stand shown above.
  • Therefore, this is not the right answer.

Option C: GCCATTTCGAAT

  • This sequence shows the template strand and not the translation of the non-template strand.
  • The direction of new RNA is always the same as the non-template strand; however, the thymine is replaced by uracil during transcription.

Option D: UAAGCUUUACCG

  • This sequence does not show the translation of the non-template strand.
  • The direction of new RNA is always the same as the non-template strand; however, the thymine is replaced by uracil during transcription.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of precocious puberty in girls??
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A: Idiopathic

  • Pubertal changes before 8 years in girls and boys before 9 years are considered precocious puberty.
  • The clinical features include early sexual development.
  • Continous GnRH agonist is the most effective treatment for precocious puberty treatment.
  • Other causes:
    • Congenital lesions of the hypothalamus-pituitary.
    • Acquired lesions
      • Infection
      • Neoplasm: ovarian, adrenal, pituitary
    • Part of a specific syndrome—McCune Albright (5%), von Recklinghausen’s neurofibromatosis.
    • Endocrine/metabolic disorders.
  • Treatment of precocious puberty: GnRH analogues

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Gonadal tumors

  • Gonadal tumors secreting sex hormones may lead to precocious puberty in both girls and boys.
  • However these are not common causes.

Option C: McCune-Albright syndrome

  • It is caused by the mosaic mutation in G-protein which causes the continuous stimulation of endocrine function.
  • It causes precocious puberty, polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, and café-au-lait spots.
  • However it is not the most common cause of precocious puberty.

Option D: Hypothyroidism

  • It causes the deficiency of thyroid hormones T3 and T4.
  • It causes fatigue, cold intolerance, bradycardia, and weight gain.
  • It causes delayed puberty until the 12-13 years of age of epiphyseal maturation.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male is admitted to the ward. He is a chronic alcoholic and has been diagnosed with liver cirrhosis. He is scheduled for removal of his  9th segment of the liver. Which of the following marked structure is known as the 9th segment of the liver?
questions.solution:
Option B: B

  • In the given image, the marked structure ''B'' depicts Segment IX
  • Segment IX is the paracaval portion of the caudate lobe.
  • According to the latest study, the liver has nine segments.
  • The dorsal sector is made up of two segments:
    • Segment I to the left and in front of the inferior vena cava and segment IX to the right and front of the cava; are joined inferiorly by the caudate process.
    • Segment IX is located on the right liver's posterior side. Small dorsal pedicles protrude from the posterior edge of the major portal components and climb upward.
    • Segment IX is divided into three subsegments.
      • IXb is located between the middle and right superior hepatic veins.
      • IXc is located underneath the right hepatic vein.
      • IXd is to the right of a vertical plane that passes through the right superior vein.
    • Hepatic veins, particularly the middle and left hepatic veins, enter the cava directly.

Options A and C do not represent segment IX.

questions.text: A 51-year-old patient visits the clinic again, expressing gastric irritation and diarrhea, despite recurrent duodenal ulcers and multiple treatments. After a secretin stimulation test shows elevated serum gastrin levels, which medication would the doctor prescribe to manage this condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: Omeprazole

  • This is a case of Zollinger-Ellison syndrome with an increase in gastrin level after administration of secretin and recurrent ulcers in the duodenum. 
  • Zollinger Ellison syndrome:
    • It is a Pancreatic or duodenal gastrinoma, which produces large amounts of gastric acid, causing severe ulcers and hyperchlorhydria. PPI is better than H2 blockers in this condition.
    • Omeprazole and all related "-prazoles" are irreversible and direct inhibitors of a proton pump (K+ /H+ antiport) in gastric parietal cells.
    • Other proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) drugs include Esomeprazole, Pantoprazole, and Rabeprazole.
    • Rabeprazole is safe during pregnancy.
    • Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) are the drugs of choice for peptic ulcer disease (PUD) due to any etiology (even NSAID-induced).
    • These are also the agents of choice for gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome (ZES), as they prevent the action of gastrin by blocking H+ ATPase.

Option A: Cimetidine

  • Cimetidine is an H2 Antagonist; other agents in this class include Ranitidine and Famotidine.
  • Mechanism of Action: Reversible blockade of histamine H2-receptors and ultimately decrease H+ secretion by parietal cells.
  • Uses: Peptic ulcers, GERD.
  • While it can reduce gastric acid secretion, it is less effective than PPIs like omeprazole in managing Zollinger-Ellison syndrome.

Option C: Misoprostol

  • Mechanism of Action: Prostaglandin E1  (PGE1) synthetic analog, which is cytoprotective and increases the secretion of bicarbonate and mucus and decreases the secretion of HCL.
  • Uses for NSAID-induced ulcers and termination of pregnancy with a mifepristone combination.
  • While misoprostol can help protect the gastric mucosa and promote ulcer healing, it is not the first-line treatment for Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. PPIs are the preferred choice.

Option D: Aluminum hydroxide

  • Aluminum hydroxide is an antacid with constipation, the most common side effect in the antacid class; it also causes hypophosphatemia, proximal muscle weakness, and seizures.
  • However, it does not address the underlying cause of Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, gastric acid hypersecretion. PPIs like omeprazole are necessary to suppress acid secretion effectively.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female has been experiencing muscle twitches in her left eyelid and cheek for two days. She previously had a similar episode three months ago and has been experiencing weakness, making it difficult to lift weights during her gym sessions for the past two months. A neurological exam revealed a Babinski sign and an electric shock sensation when flexing her neck. Her cerebrospinal fluid analysis showed elevated protein levels (110 mg/dl) and presence of oligoclonal bands, with all other parameters normal. What drug is effective in reducing the frequency of attacks for her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Natalizumab:

  • Based on the patient's clinical presentation and the findings of elevated protein in CSF, the presence of oligoclonal bands, Babinski sign, Lhermitte's sign (Upon flexion or movement of the neck, a transient electric shock sensation may extend down the spine and extremities), and history of muscle weakness, it suggests a diagnosis of multiple sclerosis (MS).
  • The drug that can reduce the mean attack rate of MS is Natalizumab.
  • Natalizumab is a monoclonal antibody that stops lymphocytes from crossing the blood-brain barrier and entering the central nervous system. It targets the α4 subunit of α4β1 integrin, a cellular adhesion molecule found on the surface of lymphocytes. This medication helps reduce inflammation within the brain and spinal cord.

Incorrect Options:

All options are drugs used in the treatment of MS; 

Option A and Option B are highly effective against MS but are not as effective as Natalizumab in reducing attack rates.

Option D - Glatiramer Acetate: Glatiramer Acetate is only a modestly effective drug used only in resource intermediate settings.

questions.text: Identify the procedure shown below that can be performed for a 40-year-old female with toxic nodular goiter.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Total Thyroidectomy:

  • Total Thyroidectomy – Removal of all visible thyroid tissue.
    • The case mentioned above underwent a total thyroidectomy shown in the picture.
    • There are various thyroidectomy indications, including thyroid cancer, multinodular toxic goiter, and hyperthyroidism.
    • Removal of the whole thyroid gland or a part of the thyroid gland depends on the underlying condition.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Near-total Thyroidectomy:

  • Complete resection on one side while leaving a remnant of thyroid tissue (< 1g) on the contralateral side adjacent to the recurrent laryngeal nerve at the ligament of the berry.

Option B - Hartley Dunhill Procedure:

  • Leaving 4-6 grams of thyroid in one lobe with the removal of the rest of the thyroid gland is done in Hartley Dunhill Procedure.

Option D - Subtotal Thyroidectomy:

  • Leaving 3-4 grams of thyroid tissue in each lobe with the removal of the rest of the thyroid gland. The typical reason to leave a remnant at the berry's ligament is to preserve the recurrent laryngeal nerve and blood supply to the parathyroid.

questions.text: A 5-month-old baby has been declared dead on arrival. The parents claim that the baby was found breathless and unresponsive in the morning when the mother had tried to wake him up for breastfeeding. The baby had been healthy and had not shown signs of any discomfort or disease. Which statement among the following, is not true about this condition??

choices.text: Cigarette smoking by pregnant mothers increase the risk

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Incidence common in females:

  • Incidence is more common in males

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A/B/D - Also known as cot/crib death/ Threefold increase in twins/ Cigarette smoking by pregnant mothers increase the risk:

  • Sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) is also known as cot death or crib death.
  • There is three fold increased in the twins
  • Cigarette smoking and drug abuse by pregnant women increase the risk
